headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2015 Mettler-Toledo International Earnings Conference Call. My name is Kyle, and I'll be your audio coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I'd now like to turn the presentation ov
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2015 Mettler-Toledo International Earnings Conference Call. My name is Kyle, and I'll be your audio coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] 
I'd now like to turn the presentation over to your hostess for today's call, Ms. Mary Finnegan. Please proceed, ma'am.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kyle, and good evening, everyone. I'm Mary Finnegan. I'm the Treasurer, and I'm responsible for Investor Relations at Mettler-Toledo. I'm happy that you're joining us this evening. I am joined by Olivier Filliol, our CEO; and Bill Donnelly, our Ex
componenttext:
Thanks, Kyle, and good evening, everyone. I'm Mary Finnegan. I'm the Treasurer, and I'm responsible for Investor Relations at Mettler-Toledo. I'm happy that you're joining us this evening. I am joined by Olivier Filliol, our CEO; and Bill Donnelly, our Executive Vice President. 
I need to cover just a couple of administrative matters. First, the call is being webcast and is available on our website. A copy of the press release and the presentation we refer to are also available on the website. 
On Page 1, we have our Safe Harbor language. Let me just summarize that. Statements in this presentation, which are not historical facts, constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the U.S. Securities Act of 1933 and the U.S. Securities Exchange Act of 1934. These statements involve risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause our actual results, level of activity, performance or achievements to be materially different from those expressed or implied by any forward-looking statements. For a discussion of these risks and uncertainties, please see our recent Form 8-K. All of our forward-looking statements are qualified in their entirety by reference to the factors discussed under the captions Factors Affecting Our Future Operating Results and in The Business and Management Discussion and Analysis in sections of our Form 10-K.
Just one last item. On today's call, we may use non-GAAP financial measures. More detailed information with respect to the use of and differences between non-GAAP and the most directly comparable GAAP measures is provided in our 8-K.
Let me now turn the call over to Olivier.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mary, and welcome to everyone on the call. I will start with a summary of the quarter, and then Bill will provide details on our financial results and guidance. I will then have some additional comments before we open the line for Q&A.The hig
componenttext:
Thank you, Mary, and welcome to everyone on the call. I will start with a summary of the quarter, and then Bill will provide details on our financial results and guidance. I will then have some additional comments before we open the line for Q&A.
The highlights for the quarter are on Page 2 of the presentation. We ended the year with a solid fourth quarter. Market conditions throughout the world developed as we expected, and I'm very pleased with our continued strong execution. Growth in the Americas was very strong and broad-based. Europe had good growth in laboratory instruments, which was somewhat hidden by a decline in retail due to strong prior year comparisons. Sales in China and Brazil declined meaningfully in the quarter, while Russia's decline was modest. Growth in emerging markets outside these countries was solid. Overall, we continue to gain share through our field turbo program, Spinnaker marketing initiatives and our exciting product offering. 
With strong execution on our margin enhancement and productivity improvement program, we again had good margin expansion in the quarter. Despite the challenging currency environment in the quarter and for the full year 2015, we delivered 10% EPS growth, which equates to 15% before the estimated impact of currencies.
We are pleased with these results, particularly given the headwinds from currency and certain emerging markets. Equally important, we continue to make investments for growth, which position us well for 2016 and beyond.
Now let me turn it to Bill to cover the numbers.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Olivier, and hello, everybody. Sales were $673.5 million in the quarter. That's an increase of 3% in local currency, and on $1.00 basis, sales decreased by 3% as currencies reduced sales by 6% in the quarter. If you turn now to Page 3 of the pre
componenttext:
Thanks, Olivier, and hello, everybody. Sales were $673.5 million in the quarter. That's an increase of 3% in local currency, and on $1.00 basis, sales decreased by 3% as currencies reduced sales by 6% in the quarter. 
If you turn now to Page 3 of the presentation, we outline sales by geography. In the quarter, local currency sales increased by 9% in the Americas. They were flat in Europe and declined by 2% in Asia/Rest of World as compared to the prior year. China was down 8% in the quarter, which was in line with our expectations. Brazil was down 12%, while we saw some improvement in Russia as their sales decline was only 1%. Excluding these 3 countries, we had a growth of 5% in the quarter.
Turning to the next slide. We have full year sales, which also increased 3% in local currency. By region in 2015, local currency sales increased by 8% in the Americas, 2% in Europe and were flat in Asia/Rest of World. Brazil, Russia and China were down 11% in 2015. Excluding these countries -- 3 countries, we had a sales growth of 7% in local currency for the full year.
Turning now to Slide #5. We outline sales growth by product line. Laboratory had a growth of 6% in local currency, while Industrial was flat in the quarter and our food retailing business declined 8% in the fourth quarter. 
Full year sales growth is shown on the next slide. Laboratory increased by 7% in local currency, while Industrial was flat and our food retailing business grew by 2%.
Turning to now to Slide #7. Let me walk you through key items on the P&L for the quarter. Our gross margins reached 58%, a 150 basis point increase over the prior year margin of 56.5%. We're, of course, very pleased with this increase. Currencies contributed about 80% to the increase and includes the benefit of the gain we have on the Swiss franc-euro hedges. In constant currency, our gross margins were up by 70 basis points. Pricing and material cost reductions contributed to the margin improvement. These improvements were offset in part by our investments in the field service organization.
R&D amounted to $31.1 million. That's a 3% increase in local currency. SG&A amounted to $177.4 million, which is constant with the prior year in local currency. Increased investments in our field service organization and employee benefit costs were offset by our cost-saving programs and lower variable compensation. Our adjusted operating income was $182.2 million in the quarter, and that's a 3% increase over the prior year amount of $176.3 million. Currency reduced operating profit by approximately $7.8 million in the quarter. Excluding this headwind, operating profit increased by 8% in the quarter.
Our operating margins were 27.1%. That's an increase of 180 basis points over the prior year. Currencies benefited margins by 50 basis points as the percentage impact of currency on sales was larger than the impact on operating profit. The core underlying margin improvement was approximately 130 bps. Incremental OP margins reached 75% before currencies this quarter, which is particularly impressive, given the meaningful investments we're making in our field turbo program. 
A couple of comments on the -- final comments on the P&L. Our amortization amounted to $8.0 million in the quarter. Our interest expense was $6.8 million in the quarter. Our effective tax rate continues to be 24%. It was slightly less in the fourth quarter, and that added about $0.02 to our earnings in the quarter. Fully diluted shares for the quarter were $27.8 million. That's a 4.4% decline from the prior year, reflecting the impact of our share repurchase program. Adjusted EPS was $4.65 per share, and that's an increase of 10% over the prior year amount of $4.24 per share. Excluding the impact of currency, adjusted EPS increased by 15% in the quarter.
On a reported basis, earnings per share were $4.44 per share as compared to $4.17 per share, and reported EPS includes restructuring charges of $0.17 per share and $0.04 per share of purchased intangible amortization.
The next slide provides our full year results for 2015. Our local currency sales increased by 3%, while gross margins grew by 170 basis points. Currency benefited gross margins by about 90 basis points, resulting in a strong 80 basis point improvement on a constant currency basis. Operating profits increased by 5%, and margins, on a constant currency basis, increased by 120 bps. Incremental margins exceeded 50% for the full year. Our adjusted EPS grew by 10%, which reflects a growth of approximately 15%, excluding currency.
Now let's turn to cash flow. In the quarter, our free cash flow was $126.4 million or $4.60 per share. On a per share basis, that's a 23% increase over the prior year amount. We achieved further improvement in DSO, which was reduced to 39 days at the end of the year compared to 40 days in the prior year. Our ITO was 4.6. 
Full year free cash flow amounted to $364.8 million or $12.90 per share, which is an increase of 11%. We converted 100% of our adjusted net income to cash flow in 2015, and we're, of course, pleased with that. 
Now let's turn to guidance. Forecasting continues to be very challenging, given the uncertainty in certain emerging markets. We expect market conditions to remain soft in our China Industrial business, and we don't expect to achieve growth in China for the full year. Russia appears to have bottomed, while Brazil has a ways to go. For the Rest of the World, we expect continued growth, but less than what we achieved in 2015, given economic forecasts and some tougher comps. We expect continued share gains globally driven by our Spinnaker sales and marketing program, our field turbo programs and a strong product pipeline. Taken all these factors together, we continue to expect local currency sales growth to be between 3% and 4% in 2016, and our adjusted earnings per share to be in the range of $14.10 to $14.30. This is a growth of 9% to 11%. We expect currencies to reduce earnings growth by about 1.5 points, which represents a growth of 10.5 to 12.5, excluding currencies. This guidance remains unchanged from what we reported on our last call.
Now let me turn to the first quarter. In the first quarter, we expect local currency sales growth of approximately 4%, while our adjusted earnings per share should be in the range of $2.40 to $2.45 per share. We expect currencies to reduce EPS growth in the quarter by about 2.5%. Excluding the impact of currency, our guidance reflects an EPS growth of 9.5% to 11.5% in the quarter. 
A couple of additional comments on guidance. First, our sales guidance for the first quarter is at the top end of the range, principally due to comparisons in China. We expect China to have flattish local currency sales growth in Q1. While for the full year, we expect China sales growth to be down low single digits.
Let me cover currency. With respect to sales growth, we expect currency to reduce sales growth in Q1 by about 4.5% and reduce it for the full year by about 3%. As already mentioned, we expect currencies to reduce EPS growth in 2016 by approximately 1.5% with the greater impact in the first half of the year.
Finally, let me comment on cash flow. We expect cash flow to be in the range of $355 million to $360 million for the full year, and we would expect to repurchase shares of approximately $500 million in 2016.
Okay. That's it from my side, and I want to turn it back over to Olivier.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Let me start with summary comments on business conditions. Lab finished the year strong and had a great year. Sales growth for the quarter was 6% and for the full year was 7%. Most product lines showed good growth. As mentioned in multiple o
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Let me start with summary comments on business conditions. Lab finished the year strong and had a great year. Sales growth for the quarter was 6% and for the full year was 7%. Most product lines showed good growth. As mentioned in multiple occasions, our product pipeline in Lab is very strong. They were also a major beneficiary of the field turbo program. We expect continued solid growth in 2016. 
Industrial was flat in the quarter and for the full year. Product Inspection grew 6% in the fourth quarter and for the full year. Market dynamics for Product Inspection continue to be very good. We have strong leadership position, the most comprehensive offering in the market and very strong product pipeline, which positions us well for 2016 and beyond. 
Core Industrial declined 3% in the quarter and for the full year. In the quarter, we had good growth in the Americas and Europe also had growth while China declined. You can see that many peers to our core Industrial business are having struggles. In this light, we performed well and gained share. I expect more of the same in 2016. A challenging environment, but us performing relatively well and gaining some share.
Finally, retail declined 8% in the quarter. Americas and Asia had good growth, while Europe was down due to very strong quarter in the previous year. For the year, retail had growth of 2%. We would expect retail to be down modestly in 2016 due to timing of project activity. It is worth noting that retail had record levels of profit and profit margin in 2015, so we believe our strategy for retail is sound and well executed.
Now let me make some additional comments by geography. Europe sales were flat in the quarter in line with our expectations, given the good growth in the prior year. I am pleased with the solid growth in Lab and core Industrial in Europe during the quarter. For the full year, sales growth in Europe was up 2%. Overall, we continue to execute well in this region, and our field turbo investment should help us continue to gain share. 
Americas had another excellent quarter with sales growth of 9%. We had good growth in most product lines, especially where we made field turbo investments. Our outlook for Americas remains solid, and although we will have tougher comparisons this year, we expect continued solid growth.
Asia/Rest of the World decreased 2% in the quarter while increased 5%, excluding China. As Bill mentioned, China declined 8% in the quarter. Lab was flat in the quarter in China, while Industrial was down 17%. The order picture was better for China Lab in the quarter, and we expect China Lab to grow in 2016. 
As Bill mentioned earlier, although we expect China sales to be down this year, but not to the level we saw in 2015.
Outside China, in the fourth quarter, we had very good growth in India and solid growth in Southeast Asia. We expect market conditions in Asia outside of China to remain solid in 2016.
Let me make some additional comments on 2016. Last year proved more challenging than we had anticipated, and it also demonstrated our resiliency and agility as we delivered solid financial results despite sizable sales declines in Brazil, Russia and China and significant currency headwinds. Our ability to navigate the various economic environments around the globe is the result of our long-standing core strategy and our discipline in executing them. These strategies, which we have talked about with you for many years, are well understood and embraced within the organization. We believe that [indiscernible] us for many years as 2015 gave us ample opportunities to show its benefit.
In 2016, you will see more of the same, that is, we are more than happy to stick to our core strategy and focus on execution when we come in every day.
Let me provide some additional details to give you a better understanding of our key priorities in 2016. First, the field turbo program has a good start in 2015, and we expect to add another 200 front-end resources in 2016. Importantly, we are funding these investments through the productivity improvement and cost management elsewhere in the business. The investments are aimed at underpenetrated markets and are yielding tangible results, as evidenced by our growth in 2015 outside of Brazil, Russia and China. Adding field resources is a high-leverage investment for us and particularly important, given our organic growth focus. 
Second, our Spinnaker sales and marketing program continue to drive share and productivity gains. We are now entering the fifth wave of Spinnaker, and one of the key focus areas for us in 2016 is to use data analytics to identify sales opportunities which are actionable. One example is an initiative for replacement of all products. Our installed base, consisting of millions of instruments, is a highly valuable assets to our franchise. Our marketing teams work diligently to clean and enrich the information stored about these instruments in our comprehensive database called iBase. Using data analytics, we can identify customers in our IBase who would benefit from having there all the products upgraded to newest generation, which can provide significantly more functionality and translates into real value for our customers. To be successful, data transparency down to the model level needs to be extracted from the iBase and targeted marketing campaigns develop. We support this initiative through telesales resources we have added to our field turbo program.
Key account management is another key priority for our Spinnaker marketing programs in 2016. We're further developing our top 100 key account program with a focus of further penetrating key customers in food, pharmaceuticals and chemical industry. As a market leader, we have a wide range of product and service solutions and a large direct sales force presence that enables us to be a true partner for our global customers with the various needs in many locations.
Third, we have a large number of new products introduced in 2015 and expect similar trends in 2016 as well. In particular, Balances, Analytical Instruments, Process Analytics, Automated Chemistry and Product Inspection have robust pipelines. We continue to lead at the market and technology advances that provides competitive edge to our customers and keep us at the forefront of innovation in our industry.
Finally, it is a core aspect of our word. You can even say it is part of our DNA to continuously look for ways to optimize our cost structure. This drive for continuous improvement is at the foundation of our franchise and gives us the resiliency and agility to remain successful, even when market conditions are not as favorable as we might have expected. Many productivity programs and cost initiatives in various areas add up to significant savings and efficiencies. These efforts include lean initiatives in manufacturing and back office, leveraging low-cost countries for R&D, marketing support and manufacturing and utilizing shared service centers for operational activities.
That covers my comments on our strategic focus in 2016. Let me make some summary comments before opening it up for questions. We remain cautious on China and some of the other emerging markets as market conditions are challenging, and it will take some time for these markets to recover. Our priority in these countries is to protect margin and ensure resources are targeted to long-term growth opportunities. Our Auto businesses, which account for more than 80% of total sales, are performing well. Market demand is solid and we are leveraging our excellent product pipeline, proven sales and marketing programs and investment in field resources to gain share. Our margin enhancement and productivity initiatives are well on track that allow us to make additional growth in Mettler. We believe this positions us well for continued share gains in 2016 and beyond. 
I want to now ask the operator to open the line for questions.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Tim Evans from Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Tim Evans from Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would like to try to get a sense for some of the sensitivities in guidance. I mean, we've obviously been in a challenging macro environment now for some time, and you've done a great job managing through that. As you're thinking about your 2016 guidance
componenttext: I would like to try to get a sense for some of the sensitivities in guidance. I mean, we've obviously been in a challenging macro environment now for some time, and you've done a great job managing through that. As you're thinking about your 2016 guidance, what are some of the downside risks that you think are the most -- things that are on the front of your mind at this point? Is it just -- is it still kind of emerging market? Or is it more kind of global GDP that you're thinking about? Just give us a sense of some of the things that could go wrong in 2016.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I would start with global -- the global economy, right? We have certain assumptions about how the world should play out. We're using the same data that you guys are, seeing the same information that you guys are. We continue to be a little worried abou
componenttext: So I would start with global -- the global economy, right? We have certain assumptions about how the world should play out. We're using the same data that you guys are, seeing the same information that you guys are. We continue to be a little worried about some of the emerging markets. We also see some weakness in some manufacturing data, which impacts our business. I mean, I would qualify that to say if you dig a layer deeper into that, you would see that actually some areas like food and chemical, are actually -- there is more -- those are the more positive ones, for example, within -- those are actually growth areas within the U.S. PMI number as opposed to, for example, the oil and gas area or metals area are much more difficult at this time. A second area would be currency. I think we've all experienced together ourselves the peer companies and you guys, how currencies can move things around. And we have an assumption based on where rates are basically today. And if those should continue, if the economy should continue, we would feel good about our guidance for 2016. And I would highlight Olivier and I both feel that the things we can control, the execution of our business plan, are things that we feel very good about for 2016.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Knight from Janney Montgomery Scott.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Knight from Janney Montgomery Scott.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Bill John for Paul. Maybe first could you speak to what you're seeing in China in terms of flat Lab may be where you could see some upside into 2016 and what you're seeing on the Industrial side as well.
componenttext: This is actually Bill John for Paul. Maybe first could you speak to what you're seeing in China in terms of flat Lab may be where you could see some upside into 2016 and what you're seeing on the Industrial side as well.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, I expect 2016 a little bit what we have also seen in 2015. We had in 2015, actually good pocket of growth in the Lab area, particularly in the aeronautics post to the industrial world. I expect that to go on. I do on the Industrial piece, however, al
componenttext: Hey, I expect 2016 a little bit what we have also seen in 2015. We had in 2015, actually good pocket of growth in the Lab area, particularly in the aeronautics post to the industrial world. I expect that to go on. I do on the Industrial piece, however, also expect that the challenge goes on in 2016. The challenge that we have experienced last year is that there is overcapacity in many of our end-user industries that we serve. That overcapacity remains. And the high volatility that we just see in general in China is going on. What it's -- today, probably too early to really have a good outlook for China. We want to see kind of Chinese New Year and how the business starts after that. And we will certainly have a higher confidence level in our outlook when we talk next time about China. So May time is simply giving us then better visibility. We saw that also last year. The impact of how business does before and after Chinese New Year is actually quite important.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then just as a follow-up. May be what playing out in the food retailing segment with the decline this quarter. And then as you look out into next year to see tougher comp even though food and chemical seems to be an area of somewhat streng
componenttext: Understood. And then just as a follow-up. May be what playing out in the food retailing segment with the decline this quarter. And then as you look out into next year to see tougher comp even though food and chemical seems to be an area of somewhat strength in the applied markets.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So food retail, I think important to see is really a solution going to the big food retailers key accounts around the world. We have seen a decline here in Q4, but that was expected. Actually, we did talk about this happening because we had a strong previ
componenttext: So food retail, I think important to see is really a solution going to the big food retailers key accounts around the world. We have seen a decline here in Q4, but that was expected. Actually, we did talk about this happening because we had a strong previous year, particularly in Europe. We had 1 or 2 big projects. For 2016, we expect also some declines in food retail. That's because we talk about a key accounts, and they plan their rollouts actually a couple of quarters in advance. And so we have a certain visibility about the big projects. And just the way it's coming together makes us believe that 2016 will be more difficult. But I want also to remind the way we are running this retail from a strategic standpoint is really a focus also on profitability and not just on growth. And we accept, in that sense, also the volatility that we have in that business. But I did highlight in my prepared remarks that I'm really happy how the profitability is evolving of this business. So I feel we are on a good track, and I'm not irritated by the fact that we expect some sales decline for that business.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: This is actually Harris on behalf of John. So first one, in terms of pricing, what do you expect in 2016? I think your prior guidance was 180 [ph] basis points. So curious FX and macro are today versus when you last reported what expectations are.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we still think the 150 basis points is a good assumption here. Note even that macro environments, inflation and so on wouldn't mess our befits environment for price increases. We feel definitely comfortable with that. Our customers' value, the value ad
componenttext: So we still think the 150 basis points is a good assumption here. Note even that macro environments, inflation and so on wouldn't mess our befits environment for price increases. We feel definitely comfortable with that. Our customers' value, the value add that our products are bringing, we have well-differentiated solutions. And this allows us also to have some price increases. We do that in a differentiated way across the world. We do it differentiated across the product lines. The tools that we have in place, the processes that we have in place should really enable us to increase prices independent of the macroeconomic environment. You might also recall that price increases even in economic crisis. I feel we can do also price increases in low-inflation environments.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then one additional question. You mentioned in the past various initiatives to drive the sale more service contracts at the point of product sale. Can you comment on the progress here and any initiatives you're pursuing on that front through 2
componenttext: Got it. And then one additional question. You mentioned in the past various initiatives to drive the sale more service contracts at the point of product sale. Can you comment on the progress here and any initiatives you're pursuing on that front through 2016?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So our focus is still very much on this topic. I would maybe also more broadly. Of course, we want to sell more service contracts at the point of sale. So we have efforts here that first we always include service in our quotes. And then we train and incen
componenttext: So our focus is still very much on this topic. I would maybe also more broadly. Of course, we want to sell more service contracts at the point of sale. So we have efforts here that first we always include service in our quotes. And then we train and incentivize our salespeople to really also convert on that. That's an ongoing effort. And the big benefit comes when we accumulate all that contract business over many years. But in parallel, we have actually very significant efforts to go on the whole installed base and make sure that we can capture as much of the installed base on the service contract. So I want to make sure that we emphasize really both things. We are making good progress, but I want also to try to point that it's a journey. The service business, growing the service business, in particular, the contract business, is every quarter, every year, capturing a few hundreds of additional customers. It's not just a bold strategy that you can implement within 1 or 2 years.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Isaac Ro from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Isaac Ro from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Joel in for Isaac. Just wondering if you guys have seen any improved demand from your customers who actually benefit from lower oil prices. And if not, when do you think we might actually see that?
componenttext: This is actually Joel in for Isaac. Just wondering if you guys have seen any improved demand from your customers who actually benefit from lower oil prices. And if not, when do you think we might actually see that?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's an interesting question in the sense that I'm observing a little bit the chemical industry in particular who could be one of the beneficiary the plastic industry and so on. I don't see strong signals yet. And in that sense, I don't have much expectat
componenttext: It's an interesting question in the sense that I'm observing a little bit the chemical industry in particular who could be one of the beneficiary the plastic industry and so on. I don't see strong signals yet. And in that sense, I don't have much expectation that we're really going to benefit from this. I would say that's probably a general comment. We don't see that many consumers or industry segments that are really benefiting from the lower oil prices.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then maybe just one on M&A. Is the focus still on bolt-ons? Or are you guys thinking about anything larger in the context of some of the valuations we're seeing in the market today? And then maybe any update on how the board's thinking about th
componenttext: Great. And then maybe just one on M&A. Is the focus still on bolt-ons? Or are you guys thinking about anything larger in the context of some of the valuations we're seeing in the market today? And then maybe any update on how the board's thinking about the optimal leverage for the company.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on M&A, we very much still pursue the same strategy, strategy of looking at opportunities. We have our radar. And we nurture these opportunities and sometimes, somewhat materializing and that the timing of this is difficult. So the strategic target is
componenttext: So on M&A, we very much still pursue the same strategy, strategy of looking at opportunities. We have our radar. And we nurture these opportunities and sometimes, somewhat materializing and that the timing of this is difficult. So the strategic target is to go for companies where we can add value and where it's strengthening our franchise. And in that sense, there are not that many big companies that would really fall in that category. And the few ones that are bigger might not just be available. So I think what you're going to see from us is to do more of what we have done in recent years and this focus on really being able to strengthen the franchise has generate great results actually in the past. And I want to continue to pursue that. On the balance sheet, Bill, you might want to quickly comment on that one.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as you know, we've bought a little bit more in the share repurchase program than our free cash flow this past year. We're going to do that again in 2016. And I think beyond that period of time, I think we'll comment 12 months from now or something.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Beuchaw for Morgan Stanley.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually Michael Clerico on for Steve. Could you elaborate a little bit more on what's driving larger FX headwind? I know any currencies outside of the majors that are having a larger-than-expected impact. Also, if you could quantify the impact of he
componenttext: It's actually Michael Clerico on for Steve. Could you elaborate a little bit more on what's driving larger FX headwind? I know any currencies outside of the majors that are having a larger-than-expected impact. Also, if you could quantify the impact of hedges on the '16 outlook and also how those hedges will lead into '17.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So just to clarify, there has not been any change in the FX environment since we last talked to you guys in November. I mean, there's been changes, but they've basically netted out. In terms of the Swiss franc hedges, they will -- we have less of th
componenttext: Sure. So just to clarify, there has not been any change in the FX environment since we last talked to you guys in November. I mean, there's been changes, but they've basically netted out. In terms of the Swiss franc hedges, they will -- we have less of them this year. I think we were protecting maybe 85% of our exposure in 2015. That dropped to about 70% this year and then falls off completely in 2017. And the impact of it falling out completely is about $5 million or so.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then secondly, just want to ask about guidance again. With stronger expected growth this quarter and the 1Q guide coming in at the top of the range, the full year implies deceleration throughout the year as we go. We know from last quarte
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then secondly, just want to ask about guidance again. With stronger expected growth this quarter and the 1Q guide coming in at the top of the range, the full year implies deceleration throughout the year as we go. We know from last quarter you baked in a level of conservatism into that guidance. So I'm wondering what the biggest deltas are in the end markets that you saw since we last got the update. And what's giving you pause in change in the outlook, given the stronger-than-expected quarter this quarter and the top of the range outlook for Q1?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, I wouldn't read too much into that. If we gave a guidance of 3% to 4%. We said 4% for the full year. We said 4% for Q1. I think it very much reflects our more detailed look at how comps are going to go in particular. We see China's probably got to do
componenttext: Hey, I wouldn't read too much into that. If we gave a guidance of 3% to 4%. We said 4% for the full year. We said 4% for Q1. I think it very much reflects our more detailed look at how comps are going to go in particular. We see China's probably got to do a little better in Q1 than we expect it to do for the full year. And I think that's largely explained by some specific comp considerations that they have. So I'm careful, I think the word you used to position the question was deceleration. I think to say that going from 4 to 3.5 is a deceleration is probably, I don't think the right analytical conclusion, I think. There's a little bit of a comp topic into one that benefits us. And we largely think that what we see today is playing out very much in line with what the information that we had at the time we updated you guys in November.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: I'm asking about linearity in the quarter. So just sequential monthly trends throughout the quarter. And then in January, if you can provide any commentary, both for the overall business as well as emerging markets.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I think the guys, both years for Chinese New Year is February. So in both periods, it was February. The month of January is solid, so it's not that we are expecting to race at the finish. We haven't -- we entered the year with more backlog, decen
componenttext: Okay. So I think the guys, both years for Chinese New Year is February. So in both periods, it was February. The month of January is solid, so it's not that we are expecting to race at the finish. We haven't -- we entered the year with more backlog, decent order trend stuff seem in line. I think it's a realistic expectation we have from the quarter. Maybe in terms of budget flash topics at the end of the year, you -- I think ourselves and many of the peer guys felt very good about 2015's budget flush. And I think how we saw it play out in 2016 was solid, but solid -- or relative vis-Ã -vis a relatively stronger Q4 of last year. So the pharma guys seem to be spending some money on businesses that are most oriented towards pharma had a good finish to the year.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I would also add, it's not easy to look at the trend on a monthly base. A month can be impacted by bigger projects, number of working days and so on. We don't necessarily look at monthly results to identify a trend. I think we prefer to take avera
componenttext: I think I would also add, it's not easy to look at the trend on a monthly base. A month can be impacted by bigger projects, number of working days and so on. We don't necessarily look at monthly results to identify a trend. I think we prefer to take averages across at least the month, if not 6 months.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I hate to harp on China because I know disproportionate number of questions. But you did have flat orders there yet you're guiding for a little bit decline in the year. So are you expecting orders to drop off over the next couple of quarters? I'
componenttext: Okay. And I hate to harp on China because I know disproportionate number of questions. But you did have flat orders there yet you're guiding for a little bit decline in the year. So are you expecting orders to drop off over the next couple of quarters? I'm just understanding why you're projecting a decline of flat orders this quarter.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think so maybe similar to where Olivier finished up the answer to the previous piece, we don't read too much into the shorter period. If we kind of look out on the China business, there's nothing that's happened, let's say, positive since we talked to y
componenttext: I think so maybe similar to where Olivier finished up the answer to the previous piece, we don't read too much into the shorter period. If we kind of look out on the China business, there's nothing that's happened, let's say, positive since we talked to you guys in November about the China economic outlook. And I think we always have a little bit of a late cycle economically our business, so we're impacted by investment decisions. And I don't think anybody's rushing to make positive investment decisions in China based on what they heard recently. So we think it's prudent to be cautious. And we're happy it's going to be off to a good start. We prefer that than trying to explain to you guys why we're going to catch up later in the year. But we're not -- we prefer what we got for the first quarter versus the alternative, but we're not so excited yet about a turnaround. And we never -- we don't expect when the turnaround does come, Tycho, that it's got to be a jump back. It's got to be a bottoming for a while. There's over -- that overcapacity will take some time.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just lastly, wondering if you could talk a little bit more, Olivier, on the fifth wave of Spinnaker. I'm particularly interested on a replacement opportunity you alluded to. Is there anything you can kind of guide us to the age of the insta
componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly, wondering if you could talk a little bit more, Olivier, on the fifth wave of Spinnaker. I'm particularly interested on a replacement opportunity you alluded to. Is there anything you can kind of guide us to the age of the installed base or which part of the business you'll see maybe disproportionate benefits?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, the fifth wave will not bring big revolution. It's like the first 4 waves evolution. So we are strengthening all the different dimensions that we have been working on and bringing some additional sophistication. So topics around key account managemen
componenttext: Hey, the fifth wave will not bring big revolution. It's like the first 4 waves evolution. So we are strengthening all the different dimensions that we have been working on and bringing some additional sophistication. So topics around key account management, IBase management, and this installed base topic, all will remain in the center. I think where we get a little more sophisticated is in the area of Big Data analytics and leveraging it for sales and marketing initiatives. And the example that I used in the prepared remarks we're going in that direction, that we are really applying more sophisticated analytics to the information that we have on the millions of installed instruments. And the analytics allows us to better recognize the potential and based on the potential also use the right go-to-market approach. So meaning understanding if this is an opportunity where we use telesales or are we using a field salesperson and with what kind of value proposition we approach the customers. And there is certainly an area where we bring more sophistication with this fifth wave of Spinnaker.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: For then just curious how you're thinking about material cost for the year given what's happening in the commodity complex and how you see gross margins shaking out for the full year.
componenttext: For then just curious how you're thinking about material cost for the year given what's happening in the commodity complex and how you see gross margins shaking out for the full year.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, again, we'll have a good year. Our material costs were down on an apples-to-apples basis about 3% in '15. I think we should have a good year. It's important note to remember our commodity prices. For not buying that much that's, if you look, for
componenttext: I think, again, we'll have a good year. Our material costs were down on an apples-to-apples basis about 3% in '15. I think we should have a good year. It's important note to remember our commodity prices. For not buying that much that's, if you look, for example, machine part of a fabrication, labor time, machine time would be a bigger cost element than the steel or the fabricating material itself. So we didn't get hurt by material in any way imply that it certainly we like it going this way more than the other. But it's -- for example, of the 3% that we saved this year, I think less than 1% is directly attributable to lower material costs.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ross Muken from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ross Muken from Evercore ISI.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Luke in for Ross. I guess, talk a little bit more about the returns you're seeing from your field -- the field turbo program. I guess, what kind of inning we're in? And if you guys have any plans to make any additional investments passed what earl
componenttext: This is Luke in for Ross. I guess, talk a little bit more about the returns you're seeing from your field -- the field turbo program. I guess, what kind of inning we're in? And if you guys have any plans to make any additional investments passed what early goals were?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as we discussed it on the November call, we have done a very successful wave of field turbos in 2015, and we want to repeat that in 2016. We are on track to implement about the same amount in terms of additional resources, so roughly 200 field resource
componenttext: So as we discussed it on the November call, we have done a very successful wave of field turbos in 2015, and we want to repeat that in 2016. We are on track to implement about the same amount in terms of additional resources, so roughly 200 field resources. We are very encouraged by the results that we have last year. And we also want to approach it in a similar way this year in terms of funding also through cost measures that we have in other areas of the company. The projects or the field ambitions are very similar to last year in terms of the business priorities. So of course, the territories might be different, but the geographic focus remains on the markets that have reasonable growth momentum. So we are adding again quite a sizable number of resources in Americas as well as selectively in Europe. And yes?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And I guess, turning to emerging markets. We're seeing a lot of mixed signals over there, and you guys are seeing some strength and some weaknesses. I was hoping you get more color into the various customer segments that you're seeing these t
componenttext: Okay. Great. And I guess, turning to emerging markets. We're seeing a lot of mixed signals over there, and you guys are seeing some strength and some weaknesses. I was hoping you get more color into the various customer segments that you're seeing these trends in and kind of where you see any turnarounds and reversals in any of these trends.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if we exclude China for a minute, in all the other emerging markets, I wouldn't talk too much industry specific. I think it's actually more the geography than the industry. When we talk about Brazil and Russia and the challenges and the headwinds we ha
componenttext: So if we exclude China for a minute, in all the other emerging markets, I wouldn't talk too much industry specific. I think it's actually more the geography than the industry. When we talk about Brazil and Russia and the challenges and the headwinds we had last year, it's actually very difficult to attribute that to a certain industry segment. We saw it actually pretty much across the business lines and across industry segments. And what we have seen is -- however, that across the different emerging markets there are big differences. We have seen actually emerging markets that did very well for us. And we talked about India, Mexico did well. Southeast Asia did actually well. So we have multiple emerging markets that did well last year. And I expect actually that this year, it's also going to be mixed. We're going to have emerging markets do well, and they're going to be emerging markets that will be more challenging. Partially, I would attribute also the good results that we had in certain emerging markets last year to an excellent performance of our local teams. I would, for example, highlight countries like Mexico and Southeast Asia that did really exceptionally well. And that's certainly also attributable to programs that we have in place. Some of the emerging markets, the economic environment might be a little more challenging, but we consciously want to invest in these markets because we believe also in the long term, I would name here, for example, Turkey but also Indonesia, Vietnam and so on, where you can see a certain cooldown from a macroeconomic environment. Nevertheless, we continue to invest there because we feel we can win market share and in the long term, these economies will continue to develop well.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Dan Arias from Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Dan Arias from Citi.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Bryan Kipp on behalf of Dan. Olivier, I just wanted to step back and go to 4Q last year when the Swiss National Bank removed the peg. You guys were talking about looking at your cost structure, especially in light of hedging starting to r
componenttext: This is actually Bryan Kipp on behalf of Dan. Olivier, I just wanted to step back and go to 4Q last year when the Swiss National Bank removed the peg. You guys were talking about looking at your cost structure, especially in light of hedging starting to roll off in 2016. Now that we're seeing volatility in emerging markets, currencies a little bit more than we're seeing in Europe, what are your thoughts there? Have you guys gone through a plan? Have you started to reallocate resources into Europe, maintaining Switzerland or move into emerging markets? Just wanted to get color they are.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay. I think we need to differentiate here between resources and cost base that we have that is associated with producing products and with serving local markets. When we talk about the cost base that we had in Switzerland and the currency exposure,
componenttext: Yes. Okay. I think we need to differentiate here between resources and cost base that we have that is associated with producing products and with serving local markets. When we talk about the cost base that we had in Switzerland and the currency exposure, this wasn't the cost associated with serving Switzerland as a market, but actually in terms of having a cost base because we do R&D product development and production in Switzerland. And this is true for Switzerland. This is true for our manufacturing base in China and so on. But we don't have this strengthening of a currency that is a headwind except in Switzerland. And so this was specific to Switzerland. Now in the other markets of where we serve a country and there is a currency exposure, we do a little bit of cost measures, but typically it's more on the pricing side that we would actually work. And with one big exception, and that's China. In China, we have taken cost measures, not because of currency, but because of market dynamics. And there, it is very much about resource shifting. We have business lines that have -- that growth prospects and others. So probably not surprising, we have done restructuring in the Industrial business in China. As for the Lab business, we continue to invest into it, and we are adding resources.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Appreciate it. And piggybacking off of Tycho's question. I know the Spinnaker fifth wave is early stages. But if you guys have done any beta testing at all yet? And when do you expect to kind of fully ramp that if you haven't done beta testing and start t
componenttext: Appreciate it. And piggybacking off of Tycho's question. I know the Spinnaker fifth wave is early stages. But if you guys have done any beta testing at all yet? And when do you expect to kind of fully ramp that if you haven't done beta testing and start to convert some of those orders?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the beta testing wouldn't necessarily apply to Spinnaker. The way we develop things is we go out to all the different market organization and we study different best practices. And when we see that we have a best practice a certain sophistication in an
componenttext: So the beta testing wouldn't necessarily apply to Spinnaker. The way we develop things is we go out to all the different market organization and we study different best practices. And when we see that we have a best practice a certain sophistication in an approach and so on, we qualify that in the toolbox. We qualify it in training, and then we roll it out. So in that sense, it's not beta testing. It's already reality. We have these pilots, these Crusaders of teams out there that have gone good stuff that we are scaling up and rolling out. The scale-up takes place over about a year. We go normally with this more sophisticated levels to the countries that are more mature, and then we follow up with the other countries. There are a few things that we drive from the center rather than bottom-up from the units, like the Big Data analytics things. There are from the center. And there I would say yes, we start with prototypes and then we industrialize the things. So there I am with you with this beta testing. I feel comfortable where we stand on that one, and I know we're going to have the results out of it.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I guess, it was in context data analytics stuff. So you're in kind of like a beta testing type phase, evaluating what methodologies you should use in the marketing realm versus actually out in reaching out to customers on a broad base. That's correc
componenttext: Okay. I guess, it was in context data analytics stuff. So you're in kind of like a beta testing type phase, evaluating what methodologies you should use in the marketing realm versus actually out in reaching out to customers on a broad base. That's correct?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's correct. Hey, in this area, it's also about we really try to innovate in this area. We try to come up with new approaches, tools, various technologies, tools, databases and all that stuff that we are combining. And there is a very small team t
componenttext: Yes. That's correct. Hey, in this area, it's also about we really try to innovate in this area. We try to come up with new approaches, tools, various technologies, tools, databases and all that stuff that we are combining. And there is a very small team that is leading the thinking process on that one. And that's the prototype part. And when we have cracked that analytics, scaling it up afterwards or industrializing is normally not the challenging part.

componenttext: Appreciate it. If I can sneak one more in. Bill, did you see any gross margin benefit able to clean out any gross margin benefit from oil on freight, et cetera? Or is that something that's probably a little too word?

componenttext: Hey, we had a great freight number. Savings year-on-year. But I doubt it would be big enough to move the needle. Could it be 5 basis points, maybe something like that.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then just, Bill, I know you guys have a large number of different products and SKUs. But I was wondering if the creation or development of any new products that you guys have been adding over the past year or 2 or into 2016 is there anythin
componenttext: All right. And then just, Bill, I know you guys have a large number of different products and SKUs. But I was wondering if the creation or development of any new products that you guys have been adding over the past year or 2 or into 2016 is there anything worth discussing as it relates to the overall impact on the company?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, in the sense that we need to constantly come out with products innovations, upgrades to existing products and so on. That's just part of our business model. And it's typically an individual product helps us to increase pricing and have better margins
componenttext: No, in the sense that we need to constantly come out with products innovations, upgrades to existing products and so on. That's just part of our business model. And it's typically an individual product helps us to increase pricing and have better margins and keep the growth going. But it's not that it's going to really change our overall number. An individual product will not really change the needle.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I was thinking more in the kind of expanding into new types of products that you guys haven't done and offered in the past at all.
componenttext: Okay. I was thinking more in the kind of expanding into new types of products that you guys haven't done and offered in the past at all.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Even the new product categories, it typically takes multiple quarters that it adds up to millions of dollars. Yes. It's actually, Bill, correctly years. So we need to be realistic on that one. Even -- yes. What I have seen when we expand in new produ
componenttext: Yes. Even the new product categories, it typically takes multiple quarters that it adds up to millions of dollars. Yes. It's actually, Bill, correctly years. So we need to be realistic on that one. Even -- yes. What I have seen when we expand in new product categories, up to 5, 10 years it becomes really something attractive. So yes, let's be.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And then just one quick follow-up. Just wondering if you have any thoughts on the difference in growth between the Americas and Europe. I understand in the Americas the pharma is driving a lot of the growth there. Is there any reason their thoughts
componenttext: Sure. And then just one quick follow-up. Just wondering if you have any thoughts on the difference in growth between the Americas and Europe. I understand in the Americas the pharma is driving a lot of the growth there. Is there any reason their thoughts on why you're not seeing similar type of growth in Europe?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, I would clearly say North America is much more healthy in terms of economy than Europe definitely. But I want also to say that I'm very happy with the results that we have in Europe last year, particularly as I look at the 2-year phase. And then if
componenttext: First, I would clearly say North America is much more healthy in terms of economy than Europe definitely. But I want also to say that I'm very happy with the results that we have in Europe last year, particularly as I look at the 2-year phase. And then if you exclude Russia. And that's in -- that's something that had to do in Q4 as we exclude retail, it's actually good performance. But nevertheless, America's been doing better and I expect 2016 to be the same. Americas have more dynamic than Europe. In terms of team performance, in terms of share gain, I feel excellent.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Actually, our service growth wasn't that high in Q4. I think it was 2% or so. Consumables might 2% or 3%. And the reason for that was we had about [ph] 11% growth in Q4 a year ago. So the products business modestly outgrew the service business. But I think that, that's more word.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay. Understand. And Olivier, just maybe you could just do just a quick deeper dive on the Product Inspection business. And I'm a little bit curious, the macro trends in food inspection have been prevailingly positive here for some time. And so when
componenttext: Yes. Okay. Understand. And Olivier, just maybe you could just do just a quick deeper dive on the Product Inspection business. And I'm a little bit curious, the macro trends in food inspection have been prevailingly positive here for some time. And so when you look at that market, what's your sense of the market's growth? And then, is there some new products you spoke to there? Are there any technology trends that are boosting content within that marketplace? I'm just kind of getting out what the growth Product Inspection growth should be for '16 and what your expectation is to perhaps outgrow the favorable macro there.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. First, on the macro, I would differentiate by geography. The long-term trends are very favorable across the world for this business segment. And we are extremely well positioned. But there are temporary things happening. For example, China, we clear
componenttext: Okay. First, on the macro, I would differentiate by geography. The long-term trends are very favorable across the world for this business segment. And we are extremely well positioned. But there are temporary things happening. For example, China, we clearly see that also the food industry is holding back. There is an overcapacity and the whole food industry is challenged right now in China, also in terms of margin. So you see the big foreign companies, but also local companies like cutting back significant on their CapEx, and that impacts our Product Inspection business. While in U.S., for example, we have very good dynamic and we have very good growth, for example, last year. So I would say globally, long term, very favorable, short term, we need to differentiate by geography. In terms of our market position, we are -- have an excellent position because we are the leader in all the core technologies. We are a leader across the globe as typically we have competitors that are more regional. And typically in one or the other technology. In terms of technology development, the checkweighing and metal detection business is a relatively mature technology. The X-ray technology is -- has still an adoption rate that is growing, meaning that not all their production lines are equipped today with X-ray technology even in Western markets metal detection that's a more mature technology and have been widely applied, and so we live also quite some replacement business. And then the fourth technology is Vision Inspection. Vision Inspection has multiple applications, but that's one that is more developing. It's more than early stage and also for us, it's still a smaller and will hopefully develop well over the next 5, 10 years.

componenttextpreview: This is -- the customers that have the money are usually spending on more sophisticated applications that we make more money on. It's always the businesses that have the least amount of customer value proposition that get hit the hardest. And it's partly
componenttext: This is -- the customers that have the money are usually spending on more sophisticated applications that we make more money on. It's always the businesses that have the least amount of customer value proposition that get hit the hardest. And it's partly a reflection of who the buyers are, partly a reflection of the nature of the application. So you're right, our margins have held up reasonably well in China despite some of the sales declines. And we're working hard to continue to do that going forward as well.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. It's actually -- it has much more to do with the customers. We have good differentiated products. And as long as we do price increases every year, actually we operate on are and they accept that. And of course, they differentiate significantly across
componenttext: No. It's actually -- it has much more to do with the customers. We have good differentiated products. And as long as we do price increases every year, actually we operate on are and they accept that. And of course, they differentiate significantly across the world by geography as well as the business lines. And we're going to execute it in a very similar way as we did in the past of course, every year, getting a little bit more sophisticated. But the approaches that we use to it is very similar. And it's a line that I've used at many times, but the biggest obstacle for price increases are often not the customers, but our internal organization, salespeople. And that's something we can work on and can control. So I feel comfortable from that end.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So one of your strategies in terms of growth outlook has been that your China business is more heavily Industrial at the moment and overtime, you expect China to look like the rest of the global business and have more of a Lab focus. Is -- given the curre
componenttext: So one of your strategies in terms of growth outlook has been that your China business is more heavily Industrial at the moment and overtime, you expect China to look like the rest of the global business and have more of a Lab focus. Is -- given the current economic situation in China and the slowing macro economy, is -- are you worried that it may take longer to sort of get that conversion going on right now? I guess, how ever you're looking at that what's going on in China right now into your longer-term plans for your strategies in that market?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that there are things kind of going both ways, right? So Derek, maybe give you 2 examples. So because our Industrial business has been shrinking, we're moving more towards the corporate and versus the alternative. But then maybe to your point, Oli
componenttext: I think that there are things kind of going both ways, right? So Derek, maybe give you 2 examples. So because our Industrial business has been shrinking, we're moving more towards the corporate and versus the alternative. But then maybe to your point, Olivier made this point on master comp cut cutting their CapEx levels, the largest food company in China. And that certainly has slowed the move to more consumer safety in the food inspection area. So probably both of us would say that if the economy was going better, the move towards more consumer safety food inspection considerations would happen at a more accelerated pace than China does now, given the overall economic circumstances. So a little bit of both ways.
