headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to our First Quarter 2016 Mettler-Toledo International Earnings Conference Call. My name is Jennifer, and I will be your audio coordinator. [Operator Instructions] And I would now like to turn the presentation o
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to our First Quarter 2016 Mettler-Toledo International Earnings Conference Call. My name is Jennifer, and I will be your audio coordinator. [Operator Instructions] And I would now like to turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Ms. Mary Finnegan. Please proceed, ma'am.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jennifer, and good evening, everyone. I am Mary Finnegan. I am the treasurer, and I'm also responsible for Investor Relations at Mettler-Toledo. I'm happy you're joining us for this call. I am joined tonight by Olivier Filliol, our CEO; and Bill D
componenttext:
Thanks, Jennifer, and good evening, everyone. I am Mary Finnegan. I am the treasurer, and I'm also responsible for Investor Relations at Mettler-Toledo. I'm happy you're joining us for this call. I am joined tonight by Olivier Filliol, our CEO; and Bill Donnelly, our executive Vice President.
I need to cover just a couple of administrative matters. This call is being webcast and is available for replay on our website. A copy of the press release and the presentation is also available on the website.
On Page 1, we have our safe harbor language. Let me just cover it quickly. Statements in this presentation, which are not historical facts, constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the U.S. Securities Act of 1933 and the U.S. Securities Exchange Act of 1934. These statements involve risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause our actual results, level of activity, performance or achievements to be materially different from those expressed or implied by any forward-looking statements.
For a discussion of these risks and uncertainties, please see our recent Form 8-K. All of the forward-looking statements are qualified in their entirety by reference to the factors discussed under the captions Factors Affecting Our Future Operating Results and in The Business and Management Discussion and Analysis in our Form 10-K.
Just one other item. On today's call, we may use non-GAAP financial measures. More detailed information with respect non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures is provided in our 8-K.
I will now turn the call over to Olivier.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mary, and welcome to everyone on the call. I will start with a summary of the quarter, and then Bill will provide details on our financial results and guidance. I will have some additional comments before we open the lines for Q&A. The highli
componenttext:
Thank you, Mary, and welcome to everyone on the call. I will start with a summary of the quarter, and then Bill will provide details on our financial results and guidance. I will have some additional comments before we open the lines for Q&A. 
The highlights for the quarter are on Page 2 of the presentation. We had a solid start to the year with our first quarter results. Local currency sales increased 4%. We had another quarter of good growth in America, while Europe came in a little weaker than expected. Emerging markets growth was solid, and we are pleased that we had sales growth in China in the quarter. With strong execution and the benefit of productivity initiatives, we achieved good growth in EPS, which increased 9% in the quarter. This equates to 11.5% growth excluding the impact of currency. We are pleased with these results and that the year is off to a good start.
Now let me turn it to Bill to cover the numbers.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Olivier, and hello to everybody. Sales were $539.7 million in the quarter. That's an increase of 4% in local currency. On a U.S. dollar basis, sales increased by 1% as currency reduced sales by 3% in the quarter.Turning to Page 3 of the presenta
componenttext:
Thanks, Olivier, and hello to everybody. Sales were $539.7 million in the quarter. That's an increase of 4% in local currency. On a U.S. dollar basis, sales increased by 1% as currency reduced sales by 3% in the quarter.
Turning to Page 3 of the presentation, we'll outline sales by geography. In the quarter, local currency sales increased by 6% in the Americas and 4% in Asia/Rest of World and were flat in Europe. Regarding the Europe number, we may have underestimated a little the impact of Easter being in March this year versus April last year. April should -- Europe should do better in the second quarter. 
China had sales growth of 6% in the quarter, which is better than we expected.
Turning to Slide #4. We outlined sales growth by product line. Laboratory had local currency growth of 5%. industrial increased 2%, and food retailing was up 5%. All comparisons are versus the prior year quarter.
Turning to the next slide, let me walk you through the key items in the P&L for the quarter. Our gross margins were 55.6% as compared to 55.8% in the prior year. We're pleased with the good -- continued good contributions from pricing and from our material cost reduction programs. Offsetting this were negative mix and some targeted investments in our service business. Currency was neutral to gross margins in the quarter. As a reminder, gross margins had a very tough comp. In Q1 last year, our gross margins were up 270 basis points, of which 170 basis points of the increase was on a constant currency basis. 
R&D amounted to $29 million. That's a 5% increase in local currency, while SG&A amounted to $168.9 million, and that's an increase of 1% in local currency over the prior year. Investments in our field turbo program and higher variable comp were offset in part by cost-saving initiatives. Adjusted operating income amounted to $102 million in the quarter. That's a 5% increase over the prior year amount of $97.3 million. Reduced operating profit -- currency reduced operating profit by $2 million. Absent currency headwinds, growth in operating income would have been 7%. Our operating margin was 18.9%. That's a 70 basis point increase over the prior year. 
A couple of final comments on the P&L. Amortization amounted to $8.4 million in the quarter. Interest expense was $6.6 million in the quarter. Our effective tax rate continues to be 24%. Fully diluted shares for the quarter were 27.4 million, which is a 4.7% decline from the prior year, reflecting the impact of our share repurchase program. Adjusted earnings per share were $2.46 per share, a 9% increase over the prior year amount of $2.25 per share. Excluding the impact of currency, adjusted EPS increased by 11.5% in the quarter. On a reported basis EPS was $2.40 as compared to $2.19 in the prior year. Reported EPS includes $0.04 of purchased intangible amortization and $0.02 of restructuring charges.
Now turning to cash flow. In the quarter, free cash flow amounted to $29.1 million as compared to $41.3 million in to the prior year. We're pleased with our working capital management and further improvement in DSO, which was reduced by 1 day to 43 days as compared to the prior year. ITO was 4.6. The decline in cash flow versus the prior year is due primarily to the timing of working capital items, which were somewhat impacted by Easter falling in March this year as compared to April last year. We are on target for the full year goal.
Now let me turn to guidance. We're raising our full year local currency sales guidance to 4% versus the 3% to 4% guidance we provided in February. This reflects a better view on China overall, somewhat offset by an expectation that Europe could be a little weaker than we expected. Overall, we feel very good about our product offering and our sales execution, in fact, better than we did 3 months ago. We also have raised our earnings per share guidance and now expect adjusted EPS to be in the range of $4.25 per share to $4.35 per share, and that's a growth of 10% to 11%. This compares to the previous guidance of 9% to 11% or $4.10 to $4 -- $14.30 per share.
Let me provide some additional background on our guidance for the remainder of the year. We now estimate that currency will have minimum impact on EPS for the full year. Previously, we had estimated that currency would be a headwind to EPS growth for the last 3 quarters of this year of approximately 1% or about $0.11 per share. Now we estimate a positive $0.04 impact over the last 3 quarters. We expect to have continued gross margin expansion for the full year but at a lower rate than we originally assumed. For the coming 3 quarters, year-over-year gross profit margins should be up about 40 -- about 50 basis points on average.
We also plan to expand our field turbo program further in the second half of this year as compared to our original assumption. We like the program's results so far and believe the environment is improving. This will offset some of the productivity gains we have and you saw in our Q1 results. 
One final item. Our share count will be a little higher than maybe your models had, given our recent stock price performance year-to-date. This is a smaller adjustment to our forecast. It reduces EPS by approximately $0.06, but since you're updating your models, we thought it was worth mentioning. To incorporate these factors, we are raising the midpoint of our guidance range by $0.10. We now assume EPS will increase 10% to 11% as compared to the 9% to 11% previously.
Now let's look at the second quarter. We expect local currency sales growth of approximately 4% and adjusted EPS in the range of $3.09 to $3.14. This reflects a growth rate of 10% to 12%. We do not expect currency to meaningfully impact EPS growth in the second quarter. In terms of currency sales -- currency impact on sales growth, we would expect currency to reduce sales growth by 1.5% in the second quarter and 1% for the full year. 
One final miscellaneous item. In the second quarter, we're going to take a noncash pension accounting charge of approximately $8 million related to a lump sum offering to former employees of our U.S. plan. This plan is frozen. In fact it's been frozen for a long time, and the timing was advantageous to cash out divested portion of these former employees. There is no cash flow impact to the company as we used pension plan assets to fund the payments.
Okay. That's it from my side, and now I want to turn it back over to Olivier.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill. Let me start with summary comments of business conditions. lab had good growth with 5% local currency sales growth, which is on top of strong growth in the prior year. Pipette and AutoChem had very strong growth, while balances also had g
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill. Let me start with summary comments of business conditions. lab had good growth with 5% local currency sales growth, which is on top of strong growth in the prior year. Pipette and AutoChem had very strong growth, while balances also had good growth. Good product pipeline, benefit of field turbo investments and continued strong sales marketing program are well contributing to strong lab performance. Spending by our biopharma customers were strong. 
industrial increased 2% in the quarter, driven by Product Inspection, which was up 7%. Product Inspection has good growth in most regions, and we continue to benefit from solid market condition and very strong competitive advantages in this market. Core industrial was down slightly in the quarter. Finally, retail was up 5% with strong performance in the Americas and Asia, offset by decline in Europe. 
Now let me make some additional comments by geography. Sales growth in the Americas increased 6% with good growth in most product lines. Core industrial was now modestly, however, it was again strong comparisons in the prior year period of 8%. We continue to feel good about our growth in the Americas, but they will face tougher comparisons, particularly in the back half of the year. Europe sales growth was flat in the quarter, a little weaker than we expected. We had good growth in lab and Product Inspection but declines in core industrial and strong decline in retail. As mentioned earlier, there was some impact of Easter holiday timing. Asia/Rest of World had growth of 4% in the quarter. As Bill mentioned, China had growth of 6%. While we are pleased with the good start, overall economic environment remains challenging in China. In particular, overcapacity remains in the industrial sector, which will take time to resolve. However, we are seeing good results in market segments such as life sciences. We had -- we have had recent wins in our Process Analytics and pipette business since with research organizations such as the CDC and China National Biotech Corporate. Our technology centered on intelligent sensors and Process Analytics and our systems and pipettes helps us beat competition. Our industrial team also had some successes. For example, we received an important order at the new pharmaceutical facility to provide a comprehensive solution to integrate formulation software with the bench count. These are a couple of small examples, but I thought they're worth sharing as they demonstrate that the price of our product offering provides as good opportunities to target the growth segments of the Chinese market even when many segments struggle.
I recently visited Southeast Asia and had business reviews with our teams from Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia and Philippines. I'm impressed with the good growth we are at achieving in this region despite economic conditions, which are challenging. We have strong management teams with proven success capitalizing of field turbo investment and our spend at sales service and marketing initiatives. I'm pleased how we continued to create and develop market organizations in new countries. Recent examples include Turkey, Indonesia, Philippines, New Zealand. All of these markets delivered strong results as we benefit from our direct presence. Our international customers really value our direct presence in these countries, particularly customers of our product inspections, Process Analytics and lab business. 
Those are all my comments on business trends. I wanted to spend a few minutes a day providing an update on our Automated Chemistry business. AutoChem provides enabling technology and software to develop and transfer scale chemistry into commercial processes. We are the clear market leaders in automated lab reactors and associated analytical tools that analyze chemical reactions in realtime. Our solutions provide customers increased R&D productivity, better products and process quality and ensure commercial processes deliver higher yield at lower cost. Driven by the reality that biopharma and chemical companies are increased -- are under ever-increasing pressure to bring products markets -- to market faster, customers have increased their adoption of our AutoChem technology to increase R&D productivity. AutoChem had excellent sales growth in 2015, driven by increased adoption of our technology by our traditional customers combined with greater penetration in the biopharma large molecule segment.
The prospect for Automated Chemistry remains strong, and we estimate the majority of potential users still use in-house engineered solutions, which have fundamental limitations. We're increasingly seeing the adoption of our EC Max and Opti Max as an enabling platform for automated lab reactors and are making great inroads in migrating chemists, engineers and biopharma scientists to adopt this technology to substantially improve productivity.
Expanding our product offering is core to our market leadership in this segment. As our technology gains greater adoption, we see continued opportunity to provide a wider range of solutions. For example, we fill the gap in our offering with the plug-and-play control unit that provides automation for already installed manual high-volume low-cost reaction system. has an easy-to-use interface that enhances data capture, increases automation and reinforces our automated lab reactors as the tool of choice in chemical development labs. This month, we will also introduce a new software package, which reduces process complexity, including for data analysis which allows the tool to be used by non-experts. Our market-leading technology, combined with the larger service force in this market, provides excellent competitive advantages for us. Our spend in sales and marketing programs along with field turbo resources are positioning us well for further growth. For those of you that will be attending our investor meeting in July, you will have an opportunity to hear a little more about this business and see firsthand some of our innovative technology for this market.
That concludes our prepared remarks. Let me make some summary comments before opening it up for questions. We feel good about the start to 2016 but remain cautious of the global economy, given the uncertainties that exist. Our initiatives are well on track as we expect to continue to benefit from our strong product pipeline, field turbo investments, spend up in sales and marketing program and our margin and productivity measures. Our focus is on execution and driving above-market growth.
I want now to ask the operator to open the questions for us.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Dan Arias with Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Dan Arias with Citigroup.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, China during the quarter, to what extent do you feel like the results there, relative to your guidance, were driven by better market conditions, better demand versus maybe your expectations on sales force or sales manager activities and internal thi
componenttext: Bill, China during the quarter, to what extent do you feel like the results there, relative to your guidance, were driven by better market conditions, better demand versus maybe your expectations on sales force or sales manager activities and internal things?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So certainly, they did a little bit better than we expected. And just as a reminder, we talked to you little bit last quarter about how we have done some things in terms of the sales teams to try to get them in the field a little bit more. Often in the ea
componenttext: So certainly, they did a little bit better than we expected. And just as a reminder, we talked to you little bit last quarter about how we have done some things in terms of the sales teams to try to get them in the field a little bit more. Often in the early part of the year, we have sales meetings, training sessions, things, and so we did expect to do -- frankly in our original models, we thought Q1 would be the best quarter of the year. And at this stage, we feel like we're going to get full year growth, and that's an improvement, probably low single-digit growth, maybe a little upside to that but low single-digit growth for the full year. That compares to a low single-digit decline that we would have guided you to before. If you look at the different pieces of business, of course, our lab business did particularly well during the quarter. It had solid growth and -- but even our industrial business showed some signs of improving. If I were to look at order entry, maybe the lab numbers were a little bit better than the order entry. And then the other piece of the surprise was our retail business did well in China. That's always a little bit lumpy there as it is in other parts of the world as well. So we expect another positive number in China next quarter, maybe not quite as good as what we saw this quarter. And I think maybe in 3 months, we can give you guys a better sense if it's the bottom or if we could see more lumpiness going forward. There's still a lot of fundamental issues in China around overcapacity and some fragility and some of the financial markets, but it's nice to get some good surprises there in China. We haven't had them in a long time, and we'll take that, and we feel like the team executed real well, particularly vis-Ã -vis competition.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's very helpful. And if I sort of stick with the geographic view here, I think the comps get easier in the back half of the year for Europe. So should we be thinking about sequential improvement through the quarters there? And then maybe in the
componenttext: Okay. That's very helpful. And if I sort of stick with the geographic view here, I think the comps get easier in the back half of the year for Europe. So should we be thinking about sequential improvement through the quarters there? And then maybe in the emerging regions, just curious what the outlook for Russia is in terms of a pickup and maybe what Brazil you're feeling like you might have found the bottom on that.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So let's start with Europe. I actually think Q2 will be a solid quarter. We see that already kind of an April. I think it's pretty clear to us that we had a little move in Europe between March and April due to the change in Easter. It impacts some o
componenttext: Okay. So let's start with Europe. I actually think Q2 will be a solid quarter. We see that already kind of an April. I think it's pretty clear to us that we had a little move in Europe between March and April due to the change in Easter. It impacts some of those European countries, although I look at Olivier, and it didn't have any impact in Switzerland because they were there -- they were there throughout. So Europe -- if I look kind of at multiyear growth rates, I'm not sure if your comment -- I think your comment maybe applies on 2-year growth rates, but I think a little bit less so if you were to look at 3-year growth rates, Dan. So maybe at this point, Q2 might be one of the better quarters for Europe, given what moved to between March and April. In terms of Brazil, we had -- maybe I'll let Olivier give a couple of comments about Brazil.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: In general, emerging markets outside of China had actually growth in Q1 and -- but certainly, Brazil and Russia are still challenging. Actually, Brazil was down mid-teens, so significantly down. But when I look forward, I would expect Russia to do better.
componenttext: In general, emerging markets outside of China had actually growth in Q1 and -- but certainly, Brazil and Russia are still challenging. Actually, Brazil was down mid-teens, so significantly down. But when I look forward, I would expect Russia to do better. We had good order entry growth, and so I am a bit more optimistic for Russia, and Brazil will continue to be challenging. But it is good to see -- as I mentioned in my prepared remarks, I also expect Asia doing well. So for the remainder of the year, emerging markets should do actually okay, probably with the exception of Brazil.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Tycho Peterson with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Tycho Peterson with JPMorgan.

componenttext: It's actually Patrick Donnelly on for Tycho. Just on the service front, Bill, I think you noticed some increased investments there. We went into that decision and does that get a little more competitive as other companies kind of increase focus in that area where you've always been a strong entrenched player?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Services is one area where we really want to get stronger and we want to have growth about the product because it strengthens the franchise and it's good in terms to have customer access and of course, from a profitability standpoint, it's very attractive
componenttext: Services is one area where we really want to get stronger and we want to have growth about the product because it strengthens the franchise and it's good in terms to have customer access and of course, from a profitability standpoint, it's very attractive. We have service generates actually both group average profitability. So service is a strategic priority for us. We have given a lot of attention to service in the recent years and will continue to do so. In recent years, we had to invest heavily in service related to harmonizing our service product offering across the world, and we wanted also to streamline our processes. We wanted to prepare service also to bring it to our platform. And more recently, we thought to invest now in service in the growth area and so also about adding telesales people to self-service contracts and also have better coverage. So the investment goes there. We see actually good results. We were happy to see that in Q1, service in consumer was actually up 6% so as you can see, higher than what we had on products and I am optimistic that we will continue to do well in service. And so the investment and the attention that business gets is well-deserved.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then in field turbo, another place you kind of talked about increasing investment. I think last quarter, you talked about adding something around 200 front-end resources for 2016. I mean, how much has that number shifted higher now that you're focus
componenttext: Okay. Then in field turbo, another place you kind of talked about increasing investment. I think last quarter, you talked about adding something around 200 front-end resources for 2016. I mean, how much has that number shifted higher now that you're focusing some investments in there?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the 200 that we were talking about last time was kind of across the whole year. What we're doing now is we're doing additional opportunities, and it's also something that goes across my table, and that will be then going into the second half of the yea
componenttext: So the 200 that we were talking about last time was kind of across the whole year. What we're doing now is we're doing additional opportunities, and it's also something that goes across my table, and that will be then going into the second half of the year and particular also impacting next year. So there's always a lag between our into and until it goes really an effect you can imagine the teams are developing these business cases, and then we review, we commit to it, fund it, but then it takes a couple of months to recruit the people, train the people, onboard the people, so there's always a lag. So the additional commitment that we had goes to with the second part of the year and its a pre-investment also for next year.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe one last quick one for Bill in gross margins. I know you said face a tough comp, can you talk about the contribution pricing FX some of the other factors there?
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe one last quick one for Bill in gross margins. I know you said face a tough comp, can you talk about the contribution pricing FX some of the other factors there?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So in terms of pricing, net realized prices were up about 180 basis points. That helped gross profit margin itself by about 80 basis points. Our material costs on an apples-to-apples basis were down about 120 basis points, and that contributed about
componenttext: Sure. So in terms of pricing, net realized prices were up about 180 basis points. That helped gross profit margin itself by about 80 basis points. Our material costs on an apples-to-apples basis were down about 120 basis points, and that contributed about 20 basis points to gross profit margin. And then in terms of whether we had some negative mix and, as I mentioned, some investment on the service side that they'll get -- will pickup in activity levels in the second half of the year.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Evans with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, I wanted to step back and ask a bigger picture philosophical question on share repurchases. The point you have this year to repurchase shares at a rate greater than your free cash flow, is that something you see continuing kind of definitely or is t
componenttext: Bill, I wanted to step back and ask a bigger picture philosophical question on share repurchases. The point you have this year to repurchase shares at a rate greater than your free cash flow, is that something you see continuing kind of definitely or is that more of a one-year thing?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's something that we look at all the time. We do an intrinsic value calculation over various scenarios with the board, and we monitor how that goes. We are, of course, looking at what might come up in terms of acquisitions or maybe more si
componenttext: Well, I think it's something that we look at all the time. We do an intrinsic value calculation over various scenarios with the board, and we monitor how that goes. We are, of course, looking at what might come up in terms of acquisitions or maybe more significant capital expenditures. We would say sitting here today, I think, we're going to repurchase about $1.5 billion this year, and we still have some of those building investments that was kind of spread over '16 and '17. And I think a number -- my guess best guess at this point will be another number in 0.5 billion next year, but that could change and we'll give specific guidance as we get closer. In terms of it being an indefinite thing I wouldn't think of it as into infinity that we would buy by more than free cash flow.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't read too much in the first quarter. As we also mentioned before, there is the Easter impact and so on. When I look at the project pipeline, I don't think we are expecting a cool down in the industrial business.  Of course, I do expect lab to do
componenttext: I wouldn't read too much in the first quarter. As we also mentioned before, there is the Easter impact and so on. When I look at the project pipeline, I don't think we are expecting a cool down in the industrial business.  Of course, I do expect lab to do better than industrial, but that's not a particular timing aspect of it. It's more kind of the whole environment that we have, the opportunities that we have. So I do actually expect that the second part of the year, industrial will actually look different than the first quarter.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to spend a minute on China. Appreciate your comments in the script, but hope you could put a little more color as the reasons why you're maybe a little bit more optimistic for the balance of the year than you were [indiscernible] 3 or 4 months ago
componenttext: Wanted to spend a minute on China. Appreciate your comments in the script, but hope you could put a little more color as the reasons why you're maybe a little bit more optimistic for the balance of the year than you were [indiscernible] 3 or 4 months ago obviously, the outlook was a little tougher, if you maybe highlight a couple fundamental items that you're seeing in the marketplace that have given you confidence, that would be great.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess one obvious element, Isaac, is the fact that we have Q1 under our belt and a pretty decent forecast for Q2. So we have after the year we'll probably finish the first half of the year with mid-single-digit growth, and we had predicted for the full
componenttext: I guess one obvious element, Isaac, is the fact that we have Q1 under our belt and a pretty decent forecast for Q2. So we have after the year we'll probably finish the first half of the year with mid-single-digit growth, and we had predicted for the full year, previously, a low single-digit decline. So some of it is just the math piece. The second is I would comment on the fact that it wasn't that long ago that we were talking to you about we had last year in our China core industrial business, we had 20% decline for the full year last year, and it varied between minus 7 and minus 23. And while I'm not sure we're going to get growth in core industrial for the full year in China, it's pretty clear to me it won't be that kind of number and just now that we're this far into the year, we feel a little bit better than that. In terms of what we see in terms of activity with customers, Olivier commented on some of the progress we're making, particularly in the life science area, so we do see money getting awarded there. We see ourselves getting a good share without any kind of government preferencing that might hurt people in certain industries. So overall, mostly good news about China relative to where we were 3 months ago.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's really helpful color. Follow-up, Bill, for you on pricing. I think there has been a run-up year-to-date in fuel prices. So from the commodity standpoint, I'm curious how that factors into your plans to drive pricing. And maybe actually as par
componenttext: Okay. That's really helpful color. Follow-up, Bill, for you on pricing. I think there has been a run-up year-to-date in fuel prices. So from the commodity standpoint, I'm curious how that factors into your plans to drive pricing. And maybe actually as part of that, from a cost of goods standpoint, I know that there are enough has been relatively recent and relatively quick. Is that a factor that goes into gross margin for the year?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the area we would see what impact us the most, Isaac, would be in our vehicle business because of the and the way we kind of do pricing in that market is we are quoting based on current market prices for steel. So we would kind of push that price incre
componenttext: So the area we would see what impact us the most, Isaac, would be in our vehicle business because of the and the way we kind of do pricing in that market is we are quoting based on current market prices for steel. So we would kind of push that price increase through with a little bit of margin. And so while it might look cosmetically like a little bit more price realization on the gross margin, there wouldn't be too big of an impact to that. In terms of the other pieces of our business, we do buy some fabrication and of course, we buy a lot of machine parts, but those costs are mostly kind of locked down in terms of annualized pricing and -- but certainly, something we need to think about next year and let's see how these commodity prices hold out and whether that might provide some opportunity because of what it does to produce your price indexes for us to try to do a little bit more pricing in the second half. But I think at this stage, it's probably -- we have nothing definitive.

componenttext: Okay. So in terms of our -- we grew 4%. The service business grew at a little faster than the product business, and I think our consumable because I don't have it in front of me, but raining did well, so I just had to assume that our consumable business is the biggest piece, must have done at least as well as the service business. And then, of course, Product Inspection business, in particular, had good service growth, I would say, among the different divisions.

componenttext: All right. And about -- what about operating leverage as your organic growth is improving, with all the restructuring, cost-cutting initiatives, what does it look like in terms of how much organic -- like what operating leverage do you get as your organic is expanding?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think on a currency-neutral basis, we're looking at contribution margins in the mid-30s. So every couple dollar sales, we should be able to do something in the mid-30s. And historically, that's a pretty good number off this base. 4% growth for the fu
componenttext: So I think on a currency-neutral basis, we're looking at contribution margins in the mid-30s. So every couple dollar sales, we should be able to do something in the mid-30s. And historically, that's a pretty good number off this base. 4% growth for the full year, so not quite that mid-single-digit because each extra dollar of sales growth usually has some more. And then I would comment that we're making pretty significant investments on the field turbo program that we're delivering -- we're still delivering this type of incremental margins despite those investments.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And one last one real quick. You mentioned you remain a little cautious on the global economy. There's a macro uncertainty but at the same time we stop a little bit about how China grew 6% in Q1. You saw strong April the expect mid-single-digit
componenttext: All right. And one last one real quick. You mentioned you remain a little cautious on the global economy. There's a macro uncertainty but at the same time we stop a little bit about how China grew 6% in Q1. You saw strong April the expect mid-single-digits at least through the first half. So what indicators are you looking for until you're able to sort of revised your just macro outlook? Are you looking for a longer duration or is there something else that you're waiting to see an uptick in?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's really tough to point to one single factor, right? There's a lot of different data points we get from the market: what are we seeing in terms of our direct business, what are we seeing in terms of economic data that you guys look at, and it w
componenttext: I think it's really tough to point to one single factor, right? There's a lot of different data points we get from the market: what are we seeing in terms of our direct business, what are we seeing in terms of economic data that you guys look at, and it would be really hard to the net on 1 or 2 specific things. We're always looking at capacity utilization in China. We're looking at how they are doing from an export perspective. Maybe one of the new factors that's come out recently is a 5-year -- the new 5-year plan, probably since the last time we talked and that's certainly was kind of more the same at least as it relates to our piece of the business. So I think, just the passage of time and continued positive results there would be one of the factors we'd look to the most. Let's be honest. We have a very much a short-cycle business including in China, even if China is maybe slightly longer cycle than the rest of the world, but it's tough for us to maybe be the guy to make the first call.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of Steve Beuchaw with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Steve Beuchaw with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick clarifications. First, on selling days, there was a comment in the prepared remarks around Easter. I wonder if you thought much about what the impact might have been in basis points and was that isolated to Europe? And were there an
componenttext: Just a couple of quick clarifications. First, on selling days, there was a comment in the prepared remarks around Easter. I wonder if you thought much about what the impact might have been in basis points and was that isolated to Europe? And were there any other selling day anomalies that you might spike out here?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you look overall for the entire business, we felt reasonably good about that it was flattish for selling days. I think the comment related more to geographically the impact in Europe and that the Easter holidays tend to lead to our sales force as we
componenttext: So if you look overall for the entire business, we felt reasonably good about that it was flattish for selling days. I think the comment related more to geographically the impact in Europe and that the Easter holidays tend to lead to our sales force as well as customers just being out of the office for that week, and it moving between March and April adds a little bit of impact in terms of European sales and a little bit of impact in terms of cash flow collections.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And in your prepared remarks, Bill, I wanted to say that I caught the comment that suggested that, in total, there's not much change the way you're thinking about the overall margin expansion for the year, but you seem to think that the operating
componenttext: Got it. And in your prepared remarks, Bill, I wanted to say that I caught the comment that suggested that, in total, there's not much change the way you're thinking about the overall margin expansion for the year, but you seem to think that the operating margin expansion might be a little more concentrated in terms of the rate of operating expense spend as opposed to gross margins. Am I interpreting that correctly? And can you give us a sense for what some of the underlying moving parts there?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And I'm kind of looking at Mary, too, to make sure I quote some of the numbers right, but I think I understand So the first comment is gross margin came in a little less than our model, probably a little bit less than some of your guys models in Q1.
componenttext: Sure. And I'm kind of looking at Mary, too, to make sure I quote some of the numbers right, but I think I understand So the first comment is gross margin came in a little less than our model, probably a little bit less than some of your guys models in Q1. If we look at now the remaining 3 quarters of the year, our best estimate at this point would be on a currency-neutral basis or actually, I think, there's maybe only 10 basis points anyway difference between actual and constant currency. But looking at something like 50 basis points on average in the remaining 3 quarters of the year could be a little bit better than something in that range. That, of course, is a good number, and so we're happy with that number but I think the comparison little bit. If you look at what that means in terms of our full year model, it means they be a little bit less gross profit margin for the full year than most people were expecting, so that's kind of maybe a slight negative. Slight positive is that we put the midpoint of our sales guidance up from by 50 basis points. The next item is that you could see in our operating expenses that our various cost savings, cost reengineering initiatives continue to go well. Our operating expenses, as we view it internally, were only up about 1% in the quarter despite having, I think, 250 more field personnel between sales and service than we had in Q1 a year ago, so we feel good about that and partly because we're happy with how the field turbo programs are going. Olivier mentioned we're starting to approve already a few more field turbos that will start to add a little bit of operating expense growth more than we had in the original model in the second half of the year. And then the final [indiscernible] thing is that we had a -- the share price has performed well recently and that for most of you guys will probably have some impact on us spending $0.5 billion on share repurchases. We'll get a few less shares purchased because of that. That impact for us, at least in our model, was about $0.06. And of course, one of the bigger impacts, Steve, is that if you look at where currencies are as of yesterday, I guess, as compared to what we told you in February and you look at that over the last 3 quarters of the year, I say the last 3 quarters because the first quarter is already behind us, we estimated about $0.15 per share impact as the delta between those 2, that's a positive delta. So taking all those things together, that's how we got to this $0.10 per share movement in terms of the midpoint of our guidance.

componenttextpreview: Okay. So in terms of your question on gross profit margin, so maybe I gave the overall picture. So the overall picture, 180 basis points price realization, that translates to about plus 80 bps on gross margin. Material costs were down 120 bps. That transl
componenttext: Okay. So in terms of your question on gross profit margin, so maybe I gave the overall picture. So the overall picture, 180 basis points price realization, that translates to about plus 80 bps on gross margin. Material costs were down 120 bps. That translates to 20 bps in terms of year-on-year movement in gross profit margin. Then the rest is kind of equally split between a mix topic, series of little mix things kind of adding up, so maybe kind of some of the highlight ones where a little less sales than in terms of the overall composition, a less European direct sales and a little less Southeast Asian sales, and those are 2 highly profitable markets. And if I look at within the lab product categories titration, for example, is one of our highest gross margin products that some of their sales move a little bit into the latter part of the year due to some new product introductions. And then the service was the other half of the kind of the negative. And in service, we just -- Olivier talked about that earlier. We really see service as an important part of our growth in terms of profit going forward, but also it's just one of the great competitive barriers and advantages that we want to build on, and we invested a little bit more in service technicians. Usually takes service technicians, depends on product category, but 2 to 4 quarters to be breakeven, and we added a few more in a couple of very targeted areas that are going to help us and they very much fit in with how we made our field turbo investments in very much support those.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: On Americas, so Q1, we had actually good quarter. We were up 6%. Particular happy actually was the performance in lab products in the retail. Or industrials was slightly down but against the strong comparison in prior year. So all in all, the growth was i
componenttext: On Americas, so Q1, we had actually good quarter. We were up 6%. Particular happy actually was the performance in lab products in the retail. Or industrials was slightly down but against the strong comparison in prior year. So all in all, the growth was in line with our expectations, and our outlook continues to be generally positive, but I would acknowledge that we start to have a strong comparison in the second part of the year and biopharma -- when I think about particular strong end-user markets, it was certainly biopharma, I saw that pick up very nicely now results from our pipette business and Automated Chemistry that strongly exposed to the market and did extremely well. And I did mention that the product expansion did well certainly also because the whole food safety topic is an ongoing hot topic, and we see our customer base having a high investment rate on that one. All in all, actually good, and I definitely expect it continue to do well but higher comparisons will also start to kick in.

componenttext: It did, and it had some bigger orders coming through, and that's a little bit, clear some of our hesitancy is we're going to keep getting those. Is that part of it? headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to our First Quarter 2016 Mettler-Toledo International Earnings Conference Call. My name is Jennifer, and I will be your audio coordinator. [Operator Instructions] And I would now like to turn the presentation o
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to our First Quarter 2016 Mettler-Toledo International Earnings Conference Call. My name is Jennifer, and I will be your audio coordinator. [Operator Instructions] And I would now like to turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Ms. Mary Finnegan. Please proceed, ma'am.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jennifer, and good evening, everyone. I am Mary Finnegan. I am the treasurer, and I'm also responsible for Investor Relations at Mettler-Toledo. I'm happy you're joining us for this call. I am joined tonight by Olivier Filliol, our CEO; and Bill D
componenttext:
Thanks, Jennifer, and good evening, everyone. I am Mary Finnegan. I am the treasurer, and I'm also responsible for Investor Relations at Mettler-Toledo. I'm happy you're joining us for this call. I am joined tonight by Olivier Filliol, our CEO; and Bill Donnelly, our Executive Vice President.
I need to cover just a couple administrative matters. This call is being webcast and is available for replay on our website. A copy of the press release and the presentation is also available on the website.
On Page 1, we have our safe harbor language. Let me just cover it quickly. Statements in this presentation, which are not historical facts, constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the U.S. Securities Act of 1933 and the U.S. Securities Exchange Act of 1934. These statements involve risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause our actual results, levels of activity, performance or achievements to be materially different from those expressed or implied by any forward-looking statements. For a discussion of these risks and uncertainties, please see our Form 8-K. All of the forward-looking statements are qualified in their entirety by reference to the factors discussed under Factors Affecting Our Future Operating Results and Management Discussion and Analysis in our Form 10-K.
Just one other item. On today's call, we may use non-GAAP financial measures. More detailed information with respect to non-GAAP financial measures are -- and the most directly comparable GAAP measure is provided in our Form 8-K.
I will now turn the call over to Olivier.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mary, and welcome to everyone on the call. I will start with a summary of the quarter, and then Bill will provide details on our financial results and guidance. I will then have some additional comments before we open the lines for Q&A. The h
componenttext:
Thank you, Mary, and welcome to everyone on the call. I will start with a summary of the quarter, and then Bill will provide details on our financial results and guidance. I will then have some additional comments before we open the lines for Q&A. 
The highlights for the quarter are on Page 2 of the presentation. We had a solid start to the year with our first quarter results. Local currency sales increased 4%. We had another quarter of good growth in America while Europe came in a little weaker than expected. Emerging markets growth was solid, and we are pleased that we had sales growth in China in the quarter. 
With strong execution and the benefit of productivity initiatives, we achieved good growth in EPS, which increased 9% in the quarter. This equates to 11.5% growth, excluding the impact of currency. We are pleased with these results and that the year is off to a good start.
Now let me turn it to Bill to cover the numbers.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Olivier, and hello to everybody. Sales were $539.7 million in the quarter. That's an increase of 4% in local currency. On a U.S. dollar basis, sales increased by 1% as currencies reduced sales by 3% in the quarter.Turning to Page 3 of the presen
componenttext:
Thanks, Olivier, and hello to everybody. Sales were $539.7 million in the quarter. That's an increase of 4% in local currency. On a U.S. dollar basis, sales increased by 1% as currencies reduced sales by 3% in the quarter.
Turning to Page 3 of the presentation, we'll outline sales by geography. In the quarter, local currency sales increased by 6% in the Americas and 4% in Asia/Rest of World and were flat in Europe. Regarding the Europe number, we may have underestimated a little the impact of Easter being in March this year versus April last year. April should -- Europe should do better in the second quarter. China had sales growth of 6% in the quarter, which is better than we expected.
Turning to Slide #4, we outlined sales growth by product line. Laboratory had local currency growth of 5%, industrial increased 2% and food retailing was up 5%. All comparisons are versus the prior year quarter.
Turning to the next slide, let me walk you through the key items in the P&L for the quarter. Our gross margins were 55.6% as compared to 55.8% in the prior year. We're pleased with the good -- continued good contributions from pricing and from our material cost reduction programs. Offsetting this were negative mix and some targeted investments in our service business. Currency was neutral to gross margins in the quarter. As a reminder, gross margins had a very tough comp. In Q1 last year, our gross margins were up 270 basis points, of which 170 basis points of the increase was on a constant currency basis. 
R&D amounted to $29 million, that's a 5% increase in local currency, while SG&A amounted to $168.9 million, and that's an increase of 1% in local currency over the prior year. Investments in our field turbo program and higher variable comp were offset in part by cost-saving initiatives. Adjusted operating income amounted to $102 million in the quarter. That's a 5% increase over the prior year amount of $97.3 million. Reduced operating profit -- currency reduced operating profit by $2 million. Absent currency headwinds, growth in operating income would've been 7%. Our operating margin was 18.9%. That's a 70 basis point increase over the prior year. 
A couple of final comments on the P&L. Amortization amounted to $8.4 million in the quarter. Interest expense was $6.6 million in the quarter. Our effective tax rate continues to be 24%. Fully diluted shares for the quarter were 27.4 million, which is a 4.7% decline from the prior year, reflecting the impact of our share repurchase program. Adjusted earnings per share were $2.46 per share, a 9% increase over the prior year amount of $2.25 per share. Excluding the impact of currency, adjusted EPS increased by 11.5% in the quarter. On a reported basis EPS was $2.40 as compared to $2.19 in the prior year. Reported EPS includes $0.04 of purchased intangible amortization and $0.02 of restructuring charges.
Now turning to cash flow. In the quarter, free cash flow amounted to $29.1 million as compared to $41.3 million in to the prior year. We're pleased with our working capital management and further improvement in DSO, which was reduced by one day to 43 days as compared to the prior year. ITO was 4.6. The decline in cash flow versus the prior year is due primarily to the timing of working capital items, which was somewhat impacted by Easter falling in March this year as compared to April last year. We are on target for the full year goal.
Now let me turn to guidance. We're raising our full year local currency sales guidance to 4% versus the 3% to 4% guidance we provided in February. This reflects a better view on China overall, somewhat offset by an expectation that Europe could be a little weaker than we expected. Overall, we feel very good about our product offering and our sales execution, in fact, better than we did 3 months ago. We also have raised our earnings per share guidance and now expect adjusted EPS to be in the range of $4.25 per share to $4.35 per share, and that's a growth of 10% to 11%. This compares to the previous guidance of 9% to 11% or $4.10 (sic) [ $14.10 ] to $4 -- $14.30 per share.
Let me provide some additional background at our guidance for the remainder of the year. We now estimate that currency will have minimum impact on EPS for the full year. Previously, we had estimated that currency would be a headwind to EPS growth for the last 3 quarters of this year of approximately 1% or about $0.11 per share. Now we estimate a positive $0.04 impact over the last 3 quarters. We expect to have continued gross margin expansion for the full year, but at a lower rate than we originally assumed. For the coming 3 quarters, year-over-year gross profit margins should be up about 40 -- or sorry, 50 basis points on average. We also plan to expand our field turbo program further in the second half of this year as compared to our original assumption. We like the program's results so far and believe the environment is improving. This will offset some of the productivity gains we have and you saw in our Q1 results. 
One final item. Our share count will be a little higher than maybe your models had, given our recent stock price performance year-to-date. This is a smaller adjustment to our forecast. It reduces EPS by approximately $0.06. But since you're updating your models, we thought it was worth mentioning. To incorporate these factors, we are raising the midpoint of our guidance range by $0.10. We now assume EPS will increase 10% to 11% as compared to the 9% to 11% previously.
Now let's look at the second quarter. We expect local currency sales growth of approximately 4% and adjusted EPS in the range of $3.09 to $3.14. This reflects a growth rate of 10% to 12%. We do not expect currency to meaningfully impact EPS growth in the second quarter. In terms of currency sales -- currency impact on sales growth, we would expect currency to reduce sales growth by 1.5% in the second quarter and 1% for the full year. 
One final miscellaneous item. In the second quarter, we're going to take a noncash pension accounting charge of approximately $8 million related to a lump sum offering to former employees of our U.S. plan. This plan is frozen. In fact, it's been frozen for a long time, and the timing was advantageous to cash-out divested portion of these former employees. There is no cash flow impact to the company as we used pension plan assets to fund the payments.
Okay. That's it from my side, and I now want to turn it back to Olivier.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill. Let me start with summary comments on business conditions. Lab had good growth with 5% local currency sales growth, which is on top of strong growth in prior year. Pipette and AutoChem had very strong growth while Balances also had good g
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill. Let me start with summary comments on business conditions. Lab had good growth with 5% local currency sales growth, which is on top of strong growth in prior year. Pipette and AutoChem had very strong growth while Balances also had good growth. Good product pipeline, benefit of field turbo investments and continued strong sales marketing programs, are well contributing to strong lab performance. Spending by our biopharma customers was strong. Industrial increased 2% in the quarter, driven by Product Inspection, which was up 7%. Product Inspection has good growth in most regions, and we continue to benefit from solid market condition and very strong competitive advantages in this market. Core industrial was down slightly in the quarter. Finally, retail was up 5% with strong performance in the Americas and Asia, offset by decline in Europe. 
Now let me make some additional comments by geography. Sales growth in the Americas increased 6% with good growth in most product lines. Core industrial was down modestly, however, it was against strong comparisons in the prior year period of 8%. We continue to feel good about our growth in the Americas, but they will face tougher comparisons, particularly in the back half of the year. 
Europe sales growth was flat in the quarter, a little weaker than we expected. We had good growth in lab and Product Inspection but declines in core industrial and strong decline in retail. As mentioned earlier, there was some impact of Easter holiday timing. 
Asia/Rest of the World had growth of 4% in the quarter. As Bill mentioned, China had growth of 6%. While we are pleased with the good start, overall economic environment remains challenging in China. In particular, overcapacity remains in the industrial sector, which will take time to resolve. However, we are seeing good results in market segments, such as life sciences. 
We had -- we have had recent wins in our Process Analytics and pipette business since -- with research organizations, such as the CDC and China National Biotec Corporate. Our technology is centered on intelligent sensors and process analytics, and our LiteTouch systems and pipettes helped us beat competition. 
Our industrial team also have some successes. For example, we received an important order at the new pharmaceutical facility to provide a comprehensive solution to integrate formulation software with the bench and floor scales. These are only a couple of small examples, but I thought worth sharing as they demonstrate that the breadth of our product offering provides us good opportunities to target the growth segments of the Chinese market even when many segments struggle.
I recently visited Southeast Asia and had business reviews with our teams from Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia and Philippines. I'm impressed with the good growth we're achieving in this region despite economic conditions, which are challenging. We have strong management teams with proven success capitalizing on field turbo investments and our Spinnaker sales service and marketing initiatives. 
I'm pleased how we continued to create and develop market organizations in new countries. Recent examples include Turkey, Indonesia, Philippines, New Zealand. All of these markets delivered strong results as we benefit from our direct presence. Our international customers really value our direct presence in these countries, particularly customers of our Product Inspections, Process Analytics and lab business. 
Those are all my comments on business trends. I wanted to spend a few minutes today providing an update on our Automated Chemistry business. AutoChem provides enabling technology and software to develop and transfer bench scale chemistry into commercial processes. We are the clear market leaders in automated lab reactors and associated analytical tools that analyze chemical reactions in real time. Our solutions provide customers increased R&D productivity, better products and process quality and ensure commercial processes, deliver higher yields at lower costs.
 Driven by the reality that biopharma and chemical companies are under ever-increasing pressure to bring products markets -- to market faster, customers have increased their adoption of our AutoChem technology to increase R&D productivity. AutoChem had excellent sales growth in 2015, driven by increased adoption of our technology by our traditional customers, combined with greater penetration in the biopharma large molecule segment.
The prospect for Automated Chemistry remained strong as we estimate the majority of potential users still use in-house engineered solutions, which have fundamental limitations. We're increasingly seeing the general adoption of our EasyMax and OptiMax as the enabling platforms for automated lab reactors and are making great inroads in migrating chemists, engineers and biopharma scientists to adopt this technology to substantially improve productivity.
Expanding our product offering is core to our market leadership in this segment. As our technology gains greater adoption, we see continued opportunity to provide a wider range of solutions. For example, we fill the gap in our offering with the plug-and-play control unit that provides automation for already-installed manual high-volume, low-cost reaction systems. RX-10 has an easy-to-use interface that enhances data capture, increases automation and reinforces our automated lab reactors as the tool of choice in chemical development labs. This month, we will also introduce a new software package, which reduces process complexity, including for data analysis, which allows the tool to be used by non-experts. 
Our market-leading technology, combined with the largest service force in this market, provides excellent competitive advantages for us. Our Spinnaker sales and marketing programs, along with field turbo resources, are positioning us well for further growth. For those of you that will be attending our Investor Meeting in July, you will have an opportunity to hear a little more about this business and see firsthand some of our innovative technology for this market.
That concludes our prepared remarks. Let me make some summary comments before opening it up for questions. We feel good about the start to 2016 but remain cautious on the global economy, given the uncertainties that exist. Our initiatives are well on track, and we expect to continue to benefit from our strong product pipeline, field turbo investments, Spinnaker sales and marketing programs and our margin and productivity measures. Our focus is on execution and driving above-market growth.
I want now to ask the operator to open the questions for us.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
