headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Europe. I wanted to focus on Europe. I hear you that the lab side of the business is doing better than the industrial. Can you offer any more color there as to just how tough the industrial market is in Europe right now and how much visibility you have to
componenttext: Europe. I wanted to focus on Europe. I hear you that the lab side of the business is doing better than the industrial. Can you offer any more color there as to just how tough the industrial market is in Europe right now and how much visibility you have to the back half of the year in the industrial piece of the business, specifically?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't read too much into -- in the first quarter. As we also mentioned before, there is a little bit of an Easter impact and so on. And when I look at the project pipeline, I don't think that we are expecting a cool down in the industrial business or
componenttext: I wouldn't read too much into -- in the first quarter. As we also mentioned before, there is a little bit of an Easter impact and so on. And when I look at the project pipeline, I don't think that we are expecting a cool down in the industrial business or so. Of course, I do expect lab to do better than industrial, but that's not a particular timing aspect of it. It's more kind of the whole environment that we have and the opportunities that we have. So I do actually expect that the second part of the year, industrial will actually look different than the first quarter.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Isaac Ro with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Isaac Ro with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to spend a minute on China. Appreciate your comments in the script, but hoping you could put a little more color as to the reasons why you're maybe a little bit more optimistic for the balance of the year than you were, I don't know, maybe 3 or 4 m
componenttext: Wanted to spend a minute on China. Appreciate your comments in the script, but hoping you could put a little more color as to the reasons why you're maybe a little bit more optimistic for the balance of the year than you were, I don't know, maybe 3 or 4 months ago when, obviously, the outlook was a little tougher. If you could maybe highlight a couple fundamental items that you're seeing in the marketplace that have given you confidence, that would be great.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess one obvious element, Isaac, is the fact that we have Q1 under our belt and a pretty decent forecast for Q2. So we have half of the year. We'll probably finish the first half of the year with mid-single-digit growth, and we had predicted for the fu
componenttext: I guess one obvious element, Isaac, is the fact that we have Q1 under our belt and a pretty decent forecast for Q2. So we have half of the year. We'll probably finish the first half of the year with mid-single-digit growth, and we had predicted for the full year, previously, a low single-digit decline. So some of it is just the math piece. The second is I would comment on the fact that it wasn't that long ago that we were talking to you about we had -- last year, in our China core industrial business, we had 20% decline for the full year last year, and it varied between minus 17% and minus 23%. And while I'm not sure we're going to get growth in core industrial for the full year in China, it's pretty clear to me it won't be that kind of number. And just now that we're this far into the year, we feel a little bit better than that. In terms of what we see in terms of activity with customers, Olivier commented on some of the progress we're making, particularly in the life science area. So we do see money getting awarded there. We see ourselves getting a good share without any kind of government preference things that might hurt people in certain industries. So overall, mostly good news about China relative to where we were 3 months ago.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's really helpful color. Follow-up, Bill, for you on pricing. I think there has been a bit of a run-up year-to-date in fuel prices. So from the commodity standpoint, I'm curious how that factors into your plans to drive price. And maybe actually
componenttext: Okay. That's really helpful color. Follow-up, Bill, for you on pricing. I think there has been a bit of a run-up year-to-date in fuel prices. So from the commodity standpoint, I'm curious how that factors into your plans to drive price. And maybe actually as part of that, from a cost of goods standpoint, I know that the run-off has been relatively recent and relatively quick. Is that a factor that goes into gross margin for the year?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the area that you would see that impact us the most, Isaac, would be in our vehicle business because of the decks, and the way we kind of do pricing in that market is we are quoting based on current market prices for steel. So we would kind of push tha
componenttext: So the area that you would see that impact us the most, Isaac, would be in our vehicle business because of the decks, and the way we kind of do pricing in that market is we are quoting based on current market prices for steel. So we would kind of push that price increase through with a little bit of margin. And so while it might look cosmetically like a little bit more price realization on the gross margin, there wouldn't be too big of an impact to that. In terms of the other pieces of our business, we do buy some fabrications, and of course, we buy a lot of machine parts, but those costs are mostly kind of locked down on -- in terms of annualized pricing and -- but certainly, something we need to think about next year. And let's see how these commodity prices hold out and whether that might provide some opportunity because of what it does to producer price indexes for us to try to do a little bit more pricing in the second half. But I think at this stage, it's probably -- we have nothing definitive.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of Derik De Bruin with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Derik De Bruin with Bank of America.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually Mike Ryskin for Derek. I had a couple of questions for you. First, you gave some commentary on the consumables and services in the quarter. Could you just follow up with what you saw in terms of instruments or how that was trending?
componenttext: It's actually Mike Ryskin for Derek. I had a couple of questions for you. First, you gave some commentary on the consumables and services in the quarter. Could you just follow up with what you saw in terms of instruments or how that was trending?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So in terms of our -- we grew 4%. The service business grew a little faster than the product business, and I think our consumable -- because I don't have it in front of me, but Rainin did well, so I just have to assume that our consumable business i
componenttext: Okay. So in terms of our -- we grew 4%. The service business grew a little faster than the product business, and I think our consumable -- because I don't have it in front of me, but Rainin did well, so I just have to assume that our consumable business is that the biggest piece must have done at least as well as the service business. And then -- of course, the Product Inspection business, in particular, had good service growth, I would say, among the different divisions.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And about -- what about operating leverage? As your organic growth is improving, with all the restructuring, cost-cutting initiatives, what does it look like in terms of how much organic -- like what operating leverage do you get as your organi
componenttext: All right. And about -- what about operating leverage? As your organic growth is improving, with all the restructuring, cost-cutting initiatives, what does it look like in terms of how much organic -- like what operating leverage do you get as your organic is expanding?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think on a currency-neutral basis, we're looking at contribution margin in the mid-30s. So for every little [ph] dollar of sales, we should be able to do something in the mid-30s. And historically, that's a pretty good number off this base of 4% grow
componenttext: So I think on a currency-neutral basis, we're looking at contribution margin in the mid-30s. So for every little [ph] dollar of sales, we should be able to do something in the mid-30s. And historically, that's a pretty good number off this base of 4% growth for the full year, so not quite that mid-single-digit because each extra dollar of sales growth usually has some more. And then I would comment that we're making pretty significant investments on the field turbo program that we're delivering -- we're still delivering these type of incremental margins despite those investments.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And one last point real quick. You mentioned that you remain a little cautious on the global economy. There some macro uncertainty, but at the same time, you just talked a little bit about how China grew 6% in Q1. You saw strong April so you ex
componenttext: All right. And one last point real quick. You mentioned that you remain a little cautious on the global economy. There some macro uncertainty, but at the same time, you just talked a little bit about how China grew 6% in Q1. You saw strong April so you expect mid-single-digits at least through the first half. So what indicators are you looking for until you're able to sort of revise your just macro outlook? Are you looking for a longer duration? Or is there something else that you're waiting to see an uptick in?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's really tough to point to one single factor, right? There's a lot of different data points we get from the market, what are we seeing in terms of our direct business, what are we seeing in terms of the economic data that you guys look at, and
componenttext: I think it's really tough to point to one single factor, right? There's a lot of different data points we get from the market, what are we seeing in terms of our direct business, what are we seeing in terms of the economic data that you guys look at, and it would be really hard to pin it on 1 or 2 specific things. We're always looking at capacity utilization in China. We're looking at how they're doing from an export perspective. Maybe one of the new factors that's come out recently is a 5-year -- the new 5-Year Plan, probably since the last time we talked, and that, certainly, was kind of more of the same, at least as it related to our piece of the business. So I think just the passage of time and continued positive results there would be one of the factors we'd look to the most. Let's be honest. We have very much a short-cycle business, including in China even if China is maybe slightly longer cycle than the rest of the world. But it's tough for us to be the -- maybe the guy to make the first call.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes the line of Steve Beuchaw with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And your next question comes the line of Steve Beuchaw with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick clarifications. First, on selling days. There was a comment in the prepared remarks around Easter. I wonder if you have thought much about what the impact might've been in basis points? And was that isolated to Europe? And were ther
componenttext: Just a couple of quick clarifications. First, on selling days. There was a comment in the prepared remarks around Easter. I wonder if you have thought much about what the impact might've been in basis points? And was that isolated to Europe? And were there any other selling day anomalies that you might spike out here?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if we look, overall, for the entire business, we felt reasonably good about that it was flattish for selling days. I think the comment related more to, geographically, the impact in Europe and that the Easter holidays tend to lead to our sales force as
componenttext: So if we look, overall, for the entire business, we felt reasonably good about that it was flattish for selling days. I think the comment related more to, geographically, the impact in Europe and that the Easter holidays tend to lead to our sales force as well as customers just being out of the office for that week. And it moving between March and April had a little bit of impact in terms of European sales and a little bit of impact in terms of cash flow collections.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then in the prepared remarks, Bill, I want to say that I caught a comment that suggested that, in total, there's not much change the way you're thinking about overall margin expansion for the year, but you seem to think that the operating marg
componenttext: Got it. And then in the prepared remarks, Bill, I want to say that I caught a comment that suggested that, in total, there's not much change the way you're thinking about overall margin expansion for the year, but you seem to think that the operating margin expansion might be a little more concentrated in terms of the rate of operating expense spend as opposed to gross margins. Am I interpreting that correctly? And can you give us a sense for what are some of the underlying moving parts there?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And I am kind of looking at Mary, too, to make sure I quote some of the numbers right, but I think I understand you. So the first comment is gross profit margin came in little less than our model, probably a little bit less than some of your guys' m
componenttext: Sure. And I am kind of looking at Mary, too, to make sure I quote some of the numbers right, but I think I understand you. So the first comment is gross profit margin came in little less than our model, probably a little bit less than some of your guys' models in Q1. If we look at now the remaining 3 quarters of the year, our best estimate at this point would be on a currency-neutral basis, or actually, I think there's maybe only 10 basis points, anyway, difference between actual and constant currency. But look at something like 50 basis points, on average, in the remaining 3 quarters of the year could be little bit better than that, but something in that range. That, of course, is a good number, and so we're happy with that number, but I think it compares a little bit. And if you look at what that means in terms of our full year model, it means maybe a little bit less gross profit margin for the full year than most people were expecting. So that's kind of maybe a slight negative. A slight positive is that we took the midpoint of our sales guidance up from -- by 50 basis points. The next item is that you could see in our operating expenses that our various cost savings, cost reengineering initiatives continue to go well. Our operating expenses, as we view it internally, were only up about 1% in the quarter despite having, I think, 250 more field personnel between sales and service than we had in Q1 a year ago. So we feel good about that and partly because we're happy with how the field turbo program's going. Olivier mentioned that we're starting to approve already a few more field turbos that'll start to add a little bit of operating expense growth more than we had in the original model in the second half of the year. And then a final minor thing is that we had a -- the share price has performed well recently and that, for most of you guys, will probably have some impact on us spending $0.5 billion on share repurchases. We'll get a few less shares purchased because of that. That impact for us, at least in our model, was about $0.06. And of course, one of the bigger impacts, Steve, is that if you look at where currencies are as of yesterday, I guess, as compared to what we told you in February and you look at that over the last 3 quarters of the year, I say the last 3 quarters because, of course, the first quarter is already behind us, we estimated about a $0.15 per share impact as the delta between those 2, and of course, that's a positive delta. So taking all those things together, that's how we got to this $0.10 per share movement in terms of the midpoint of our guidance.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jonathan Groberg with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jonathan Groberg with UBS.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, so just to clarify, in the first quarter, you answered the question that gross margin was maybe a little less than you were expecting. And could you maybe just say what surprised you in the quarter? Was it mix? Or was it something else that you didn
componenttext: Bill, so just to clarify, in the first quarter, you answered the question that gross margin was maybe a little less than you were expecting. And could you maybe just say what surprised you in the quarter? Was it mix? Or was it something else that you didn't get as much price as you maybe thought you were going to? And then Olivier, in the U.S., everyone's kind of ignoring that the U.S., how strong it is for all these companies. What drove the strength for you? Is it mainly -- from an end market or a customer standpoint, was it mainly pharma? Or was it broad-based?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: You want to go first?
componenttext: You want to go first?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So in terms of the -- your question on gross profit margin, so we -- maybe I can give the overall picture. So the overall picture, 180 basis points price realization, that translates to about plus 80 bps on gross margin. Material costs were down 120
componenttext: Okay. So in terms of the -- your question on gross profit margin, so we -- maybe I can give the overall picture. So the overall picture, 180 basis points price realization, that translates to about plus 80 bps on gross margin. Material costs were down 120 bps. That translates to 20 bps in terms of year-on-year movement in gross profit margin. Then the rest is kind of equally split between a mix topic, a series of little mix things kind of adding up. So maybe kind of some of the highlight ones were a little less sales than -- in terms of the overall composition, a less European direct sales and a little less Southeast Asian sales, and those are 2 highly profitable markets. And if I look at within the lab product categories, titration, for example, is one of our highest gross margin products, that some of their sales, move a little bit into the latter part of the year due to some new product introductions. And then the service was the other half of the kind of the negative. And in service, we just -- Olivier talked about it earlier. We really see service as an important part of our growth in terms of profit going forward, but also it's just one of the great competitive barriers and advantages that we want to build on. And we invested a little bit more in service technicians. It usually takes service technicians, depends on product category, but 2 to 4 quarters to be breakeven, and we added a few more in a couple of very targeted areas that are going to help us. And they very much fit in with how we made some of our field turbo investments and so we very much support those.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: On Americas, so Q1, we had actually good quarter. We were up 6%. Particular, actually, I was happy about the performance in Lab, Product Inspection and Retail. Core industrials was slightly down, but against a strong comparison in the prior year. So all i
componenttext: On Americas, so Q1, we had actually good quarter. We were up 6%. Particular, actually, I was happy about the performance in Lab, Product Inspection and Retail. Core industrials was slightly down, but against a strong comparison in the prior year. So all in all, the growth was in line with our expectations, and our outlook continues to be generally positive. But I would acknowledge that we start to have a strong comparison in the second part of the year. And yes, biopharma -- when I think about a particular strong end-user market, it was certainly biopharma. I saw that very nicely in our results from our pipette business and Automated Chemistry that are strongly exposed to that market and did extremely well. And I did mention that Product Inspection did well. That's certainly also because of the whole food safety topic is an ongoing hot topic, and we see our customer base having a high investment rate on that one. So all in all, actually good, and I definitely expect it going -- continuing to do well, but higher comparisons will also start to kick in.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your next question comes from the line of Richard Eastman with Robert W Baird.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your next question comes from the line of Richard Eastman with Robert W Baird.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, could you just talk -- in terms of Europe, I think you explained maybe why that came in flattish here in the first quarter. But you did kind of referenced some puts and takes to the 4% core growth rate, and you did mention maybe Europe comes in a li
componenttext: Bill, could you just talk -- in terms of Europe, I think you explained maybe why that came in flattish here in the first quarter. But you did kind of referenced some puts and takes to the 4% core growth rate, and you did mention maybe Europe comes in a little bit softer than you thought for the full year. Did I miss where -- which of the piece of the business in Europe do you expect maybe for the full year to come in a little bit softer? Is that core industrial or retail?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Core industrial. Product Inspection -- actually, Product Inspection in Europe is going to have a tough comp in Q2, but the business overall does well. I mean, on a normalized basis, it does well. We also have tough comps in Retail, and that's one we've be
componenttext: Core industrial. Product Inspection -- actually, Product Inspection in Europe is going to have a tough comp in Q2, but the business overall does well. I mean, on a normalized basis, it does well. We also have tough comps in Retail, and that's one we've been talking about since -- I think when we gave our original guidance in November, that we're not going to have a predictably good year in Retail. We had some large orders, I think, in the Netherlands and Germany and -- a year ago. And -- but the lab business looks solid in Europe, and we'll have a better -- we'll put a -- overall, we're going to -- our forecast would say we'll do better in Q2 than we did in Q1.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I see, okay. And then in China, did the core industrial business -- I mean, it has such weak comps throughout this year. Did the core industrial business grow, though, in China or -- in the first quarter?
componenttext: I see, okay. And then in China, did the core industrial business -- I mean, it has such weak comps throughout this year. Did the core industrial business grow, though, in China or -- in the first quarter?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It did. It had some bigger orders coming through, and that's a little bit -- I'm unclear if -- some of our hesitancy is we're going to keep getting those or is that part of it, Rick -- I think I remember talking, I think, to you and specifically to you a
componenttext: It did. It had some bigger orders coming through, and that's a little bit -- I'm unclear if -- some of our hesitancy is we're going to keep getting those or is that part of it, Rick -- I think I remember talking, I think, to you and specifically to you a year ago when we were putting up the minus 17s and minus 20s in core industrial in China. There just was no big projects. And we got a couple of big projects. It's in the backlog. Some delivered in Q1, a few more coming in Q2, and we need to see a little bit more of that before it's easy for us to say, "Okay, now there's a more solid base there."

componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to our Second Quarter 2016 Mettler-Toledo International Earnings Conference Call. My name is Nicole, and I will be your audio coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn our presentation over to your host for today's call, Ms. Mary Finnegan. Please proceed, ma'am.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nicole, and good afternoon, everyone. I am Mary Finnegan. I'm the Treasurer, and I'm responsible for Investor Relations at Mettler-Toledo. I'm happy that you're joining us this evening. I'm joined by Olivier Filliol, our CEO; and Bill Donnelly,
componenttext:
Thanks, Nicole, and good afternoon, everyone. I am Mary Finnegan. I'm the Treasurer, and I'm responsible for Investor Relations at Mettler-Toledo. I'm happy that you're joining us this evening. 
I'm joined by Olivier Filliol, our CEO; and Bill Donnelly, our Executive Vice President.
I need to cover just a couple administrative matters. The call is being webcast and is available for replay on our website. A copy of the press release and the presentation that we refer to on this call is also available on the website.
Let me summarize the Safe Harbor language, which we have on Page 2 of the presentation. Statements in this presentation, which are not historical facts, constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the U.S. Securities Act of 1933 and the U.S. Securities Exchange Act of 1934. These statements involve risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause our actual results, levels of activity, performance or achievements to be materially different from those expressed or implied by any forward-looking statements. For a discussion of these risks and uncertainties, please see our recent Form 8-K. All of the forward-looking statements are qualified in their entirety by reference to the factors discussed under the caption Factors Affecting Our Future Operating Results and in the Business and MD&A of our Financial Conditions and Results of Operations in our Form 10-K.  And just one last thing, on today's call, we may use non-GAAP financial measures. More detailed information with respect to the differences between the non-GAAP financial measure and the most directly comparable GAAP measure is provided in the Form 8-K. I will now turn the call over to Olivier.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mary, and welcome to everyone on the call. I will start with the summary of the quarter, and then the Bill will provide details on our financial results and guidance. I will then have some additional comments before we open the lines for Q&A.
componenttext:
Thank you, Mary, and welcome to everyone on the call. I will start with the summary of the quarter, and then the Bill will provide details on our financial results and guidance. I will then have some additional comments before we open the lines for Q&A. 
The highlights for the quarter are on Page 3 of the presentation. Local currency sales growth was 6% in the quarter and better-than-expected. We continue to generate a very solid growth in the America. Asia / Rest of World, including China, had very good growth. Europe growth was solid. With the benefit of our margin and cause initiatives, we had good growth in margins, which contributed to excellent growth in the earnings-per-share. Cash flow was also strong in the quarter. We are very happy with our performance as well our outlook for the remainder of the year. We will cover this shortly, but let me now turn it to Bill to cover the numbers.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Olivier, and hello, everybody. Sales were $608.3 million in the quarter, and that's an increase of 6% in local currency. On a U.S. dollar basis, sales increased by 5% as currencies reduced sales by about 1% in the quarter. On Slide #4, which sho
componenttext:
Thanks, Olivier, and hello, everybody. Sales were $608.3 million in the quarter, and that's an increase of 6% in local currency. On a U.S. dollar basis, sales increased by 5% as currencies reduced sales by about 1% in the quarter. 
On Slide #4, which show local currency sales growth for the quarter. Sales grew by 6% in the Americas, 4% in Europe and 8% in Asia / Rest of World. 
On the next slide, we show local currency sales growth of 5%. On a year-to-date basis, that includes the Americas at 6%, Europe at 2% and Asia / Rest of World has increased 6% in the first half. 
Starting on Slide #6, we'll outline sales by product area. Laboratory had very good growth with local currency sales, up 10%, industrial increased by 3% and food retail declined by 2%. All these comparisons are of course to the prior year. 
On the next slide, you will see our year-to-date sales summary by product line. Lab has grown 7% in the first half, industrial 3% and food retail increased by 1%. 
Now I'd like to turn to Slide #8 and walk through the rest of the P&L. Our gross margins were 57.1%, that's a 160 basis-point improvement over the prior year amount of 55.5%. We are very happy with the strong performance in the quarter. On a year-to-date basis, our gross margins have increased in line with the expectations we had for our expansion for the full year. 
Pricing, material costs and mix all contributed to the increase in the quarter and was partly offset by some additional targeted investments in our service business. Currency had no impact on gross margins in the quarter. 
R&D amounted to $30.7 million in the quarter, and that's a 5% increase in local currency. SG&A was $187.8 million, that's a 9% increase in local currency over the prior year. Investment in our field turbo program and higher variable comp were offset in part by cost-saving initiatives. 
Adjusted operating income was $129.1 million in the quarter, that's a 9% increase over the prior year amount of $118.3 million. Currency reduced operating profits by approximately $800,000 in the quarter. Adjusted operating profit margins were 21.2%, a 90 basis-point increase over the prior year and, of course, a level of which we were pleased with. 
A couple of final comments on the P&L. Amortization was $8.7 million in the quarter, while interest expense was $6.9 million. Our effective tax rate was 24%. You'll notice our reported tax rate was lower at 22.9%, which is due to the tax impact of the one-time pension charge, which I'll cover in a minute. 
Fully diluted shares for the quarter were 27.1 million, which is a 4.6% decline from the prior year amount and reflects the impact of our share repurchase program. Adjusted earnings per share was $3.22 per share, that's a 15% increase over the prior year amount of $2.80 per share. 
On a reported basis, earnings per share were $2.93 per share as compared to $2.73 per share. As we mentioned on our last call during the quarter, we took a onetime, noncash pension settlement charge of $8 million before tax or $0.19 per share after tax. This relates to offering former employees of our U.S. plan a lump sum payout. The plan that we're talking about is frozen and the timing was advantageous to cash out divested proportion for these former employees. There is no cash flow impact to the company as we use pension plan assets to fund the payments. 
Reported EPS also includes $0.04 of purchased intangible amortization and $0.06 of restructuring charges. 
The next Slide shows the P&L for the first half of the year. We had local currency sales growth of 5%, operating income increased by 7% and adjusted earnings per share increased by 12%. Absent currencies, growth for the first half of the year would have been 14%. 
Now turning to cash flow. In the quarter, free cash flow was $108.9 million, which compares to $89.9 million in the prior year. We're pleased with our working capital management and achieved further improvements in DSO, which was reduced by 2 days to 38 days as compared to the prior year. ITO was 4.6. Cash flow for the 6 months was $138 million as compared to $131.3 million from the prior year. 
In the third quarter, we expect to complete the acquisition of substantially all of the assets of the business called Troemner  which is focused in 2 areas: Weights and weighed calibration, cell as the manufacturing of basic lab equipment. We paid approximately 10x EBITDA for the business, and it should add about 1% to the sales on a full year basis. 
It's a unique strategic fit to our business, and we are very happy to be able to close the business shortly. Olivier will provide some additional background on Troemner shortly. 
Now let's turn to guidance. We are raising our full year local currency sales guidance to approximate 5% versus 4% previously. We estimate that Troemner will contribute about 50 basis points of sales growth for the half-year, so for 2016, Or to say it different, we raised our organic growth expectations for the full year by 50 basis points to approximately 4.5%. We've also raised our EPS guidance, and now expect adjusted EPS to be in the range of $14.40 per share to $14.50, which represents a growth rate of 11% to 12%. This compares to previous guidance of 10% to 11% EPS growth or $14.25 per share to $14.35 per share. We are raising the midpoint of our guidance by $0.15 to reflect our strong performance, as well as the acquisition of Troemner.
With respect to the third quarter, we expect local currency sales growth between 5% and 6%. This includes about 75 basis points of growth from Troemner. We assume adjusted EPS will be in the range of $3.65 per share to $3.70 per share, which is a growth rate of 12% to 13%. 
In terms of currency, let me first comment on sales growth. We would expect currency to reduce sales growth by approximately 2% in the third quarter and 2% for the full year. In terms of the impact of currency on EPS, we do not expect it to have a meaningful impact on Q3 or for the full year. 
That's it from my side, and I now want to turn it back to Olivier.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Let me start with summary comments on business conditions. Lab had very good growth in the quarter with 10% increasing. Pipette analytical instruments and process analytics had excellent growth, with balances and auto also had good growth. G
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Let me start with summary comments on business conditions. Lab had very good growth in the quarter with 10% increasing. Pipette analytical instruments and process analytics had excellent growth, with balances and auto also had good growth. Growth was strong across all regions and reflects our robust product pipeline, benefit of field turbo investments and continued strong sales and marketing programs. 
Spending by our biopharma customers continues to be very favorable. Industrial increased 3% in the quarter, driven by a 6% increase in core industrial. Growth in core industrial was particularly strong in the Americas, which benefited from some project activities in transportation and logistics. We also had growth in core industrial in Europe and Asia, including China. 
Product expansion was down slightly in the quarter. This business continues to perform well, but was impacted by timing of some activity and a strong comparison from the prior year. Product Inspection have strong order growth in the quarter, and we expect good sales growth in Q3. 
Finally, sales declined 2% in retail. This was pretty much as expected. We had growth in Europe and Asia, but decline in the Americas against good growth in the prior year. 
Now let me make some additional comments by geography. Sales growth in the Americas continues to be very solid with 6% growth. We had very good growth in lab and industrial, while sales declined in retail. Demand continues to be solid in the Americas, but tougher comps will impact the second half. 
Europe grew 4% in the quarter, an improvement over the first quarter, which we think was in part due to timing of the Easter holiday. Lab had excellent growth in Europe, while quarter industrial and retail also grew. Product Inspection was down, which would improve in the quarter. 
Asia / Rest of World had growth of 8% in the quarter. China is very well and better than we expected as compared to the last time we spoke. Lab growth in China was double digits, with almost all product lines showing very good growth. We are pleased with the performance, which reflects some improving demand and also the benefit of our actions to  reduce -- to redirect resources to fast-growing market segment. While industrial in China had modest growth, the fact is that overcapacity in industrial manufacturing sector remains. 
While we're also pleased with our results in China, we expect growth in the second half to be in the mid-single digit range. 
Let me make some comments on service, which grew 5% in the quarter and on an year-to-date basis. Service represents about 23% of total sales, and it is a competitive advantage and an important source of revenue growth. This is the fifth year in a row, which service growth is outpacing product growth. Although this might not occur each and every quarter, over the medium term, we expect service growth to exceed product growth. We have a service force of approximately 2,600 personnel which is, by far, larger than our direct competitor. Our service team is specialized by product area, and we have made significant investments, including training of tools, which supports the daily activity. 
Core to our service growth, strategy is increasing the percentage of our installed base under service contract and increasing the amount of service sold at a point of product sale. The long-term objective interchange mix of our service business to be largely contract business versus great fix. Today, contract represent approximately 1/3 of our service sales. There are several reasons why this migration is a strategic imperative, including the increasing quality of our products, reducing the need for repair, contract work -- sorry, and on the other half, contract work is all easily planned. So therefore, our technicians can be more productive. And finally, our study show that service contracts leads to higher levels of cost customer satisfaction, and therefore, retention. 
The globalization and harmonization of our service offering, which we undertook several years ago, led the groundwork to drive the contract business. Our marketing campaigns under Spinnaker initiative and our field turbo investments are helping to drive this strength. Overall, we continue to make very good progress. We believe service is one of our most important competitive advantage and should continue to be an important source of sales and profit growth. 
Those are all my comments on business plan. I now want to provide some context to our acquisition of Troemner. Located in the Philadelphia area, Troemner is a U.S. market leader for weights and weights calibration and a great strategic fit to our leadership position in Europe. Together, we are now the global leader in this niche market. Weights and weight recalibration services is an attractive market. It has a strong barriers to entry as it requires very specialized know-how and expertise. We have 14 calibration labs worldwide, and the acquisition Troemner firmly positions us as the U.S. market leader. Troemner is a very strong brand in U.S. based on its word class metrology competence and solid infrastructure. 
Service, which consists primarily of weight calibration is almost 20% of Troemner business and growing quite well. This is an attractive business as customers must calibrate weights on a regular basis and have few players have the expertise to do it correctly. This is a good example of the kind of service business that fits well into our goal and of moving our service business to more contract value-added service. 
Troemner is also a provider of basic lab product such as [indiscernible] mixers and shakers, which will be a good strategic fit to all house offering. As a reminder, all houses is our second brand used for indirect distribution for laboratory products of certain industrial weighing products. 
Troemner will help us strengthen the life science portfolio for All House, which we have worked to expand over the last few years in terms of channel presence and product portfolio. We also believe we can further expand this equipment offering internationally, particularly in emerging markets. We think this is a great opportunity to extend the offering of Ohaus. Troemner would add about 1% to sales growth with similar margins to our own. We anticipate synergy potential from top line growth, as well as potential in operational synergies. We expect to complete the acquisition shortly and have already begun integration plan. We believe this is a solid strategic acquisition, and are excited about the potential development in this attractive market segment. 
That concludes our prepared remarks. We have kept our comments brief, as we will see many of you tomorrow at our Investor Meeting. Let me make some summary comments before opening it up for question. 
We are very pleased with strong results in the second quarter. Our outlook for the remainder of the year is good, but we acknowledge the uncertainty in the global economy. Our focus remains on fact that we can control, namely the successful execution of our initiatives. We feel very good about our new product launches, field turbo investment, Spinnaker marketing initiatives and productivity measures. We believe with that unit strong execution, we can continue to gain share. I want now to ask the operator to open the line for questions.

componenttextpreview: Yes, so maybe a little bit of clarification in terms of the incremental margin. I think, at least where we calculate it, it was 31% in -- measured in actual balance, but it's actually 34%, 35% in constant currency. So probably closer to may be what you'd
componenttext: Yes, so maybe a little bit of clarification in terms of the incremental margin. I think, at least where we calculate it, it was 31% in -- measured in actual balance, but it's actually 34%, 35% in constant currency. So probably closer to may be what you'd expect it. And then what was included in there was a catch up in payment in terms of our this DNA increase. And so we did trigger some reevaluation of where we expect at the end of the year target. And maybe the point would be along the lines of that we been talking about for a while is that we do like the effectiveness to date the field turbo program so there's certainly some with regard to our field turbo program in the quarter end, and we'll see a little bit of that going forward. In terms of our incremental margin, I continue to think that the numbers in the type curve are very realistic and, frankly, [indiscernible] absent the adjustment [indiscernible] in the current quarter, which won't impact full year numbers in a material way would've been there.

So if you look at our year-to-date number, we are plus 5% and we were saying that by the end of the year we should finish 4.5% at the midpoint of the range and, I guess, closer to 5% of the high end of the range. So let's see how China and some of these comps play out. Biopharma has been a strong market for a while. I'd like to think that there is upside to the numbers, but we'll see at the quarter end when second half plays out.

componenttextpreview: So, hey, I  maybe, on the economics, I'm not sure if were are a better source that kind of what you guys that read. I think, it's a bit of a lot of economic data globally, it's a bit of a mixed picture. May be 1 interesting insights we might give you is t
componenttext: So, hey, I  maybe, on the economics, I'm not sure if were are a better source that kind of what you guys that read. I think, it's a bit of a lot of economic data globally, it's a bit of a mixed picture. May be 1 interesting insights we might give you is that I know there's been some articles that some of the GDP growth has come from leveraging up further some of this [indiscernible] enterprises and the regional governments. And it was interesting for us to see when we started through the details of our numbers. And we saw really good growth, of course, in the government sector when it came to lab. We also saw across the board a very good growth with multinationals. And that's an interesting comment in a sense that if you look over the last 3 years, the percentage of our total sales in China going to multinational has shrunk, but now we see a nice rebound in the first half of the year across product categories, and I think that, this famous comment that we talked about for a multinational company, they can do further for replacement cycle for a while on our products, but eventually it bounces back. And I think we see that a little bit there. It's probably less than the product side, but much more return to the normal replacement cycle. In terms of the order entry, the order entry was similarly positive to what we saw in the sales side. So it was a solid number, it wasn't -- it's not that we -- it's purely the order entry would make us cautious about the second half.  But just the realities of that still a market with some instability in it, and I think, I was remaining cautious makes sense. But I actually felt what we just shared with you about multinational was one of the more positive reading that we had in our data coming out of China.

componenttext: Sure. So in terms of our price increases, our net realized price increases were 230 basis points up in the second quarter. And on a year-to-date basis, they're now up at 2%. We did go and looked, and just to put that in a little bit of context, some of that was chasing some of the currency movements that kind of happened in the course of the earlier part of the end of the first quarter, early part of the second quarter. And so we are trying to do something in terms of mid-year prices. I would not expect the second half of the year to be worse than 2 at this point in time.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to our Second Quarter 2016 Mettler-Toledo International Earnings Conference Call. My name is Nicole, and I will be your audio coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn our presentat
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to our Second Quarter 2016 Mettler-Toledo International Earnings Conference Call. My name is Nicole, and I will be your audio coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn our presentation over to your host for today's call, Ms. Mary Finnegan. Please proceed, ma'am.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nicole, and good afternoon, everyone. I am Mary Finnegan. I'm the Treasurer, and I'm responsible for Investor Relations at Mettler-Toledo. I'm happy that you're joining us this evening. I'm joined by Olivier Filliol, our CEO; and Bill Donnelly,
componenttext:
Thanks, Nicole, and good afternoon, everyone. I am Mary Finnegan. I'm the Treasurer, and I'm responsible for Investor Relations at Mettler-Toledo. I'm happy that you're joining us this evening. 
I'm joined by Olivier Filliol, our CEO; and Bill Donnelly, our Executive Vice President.
I need to cover just a couple administrative matters. The call is being webcast and is available for replay on our website. A copy of the press release and the presentation that we refer to on today's call is also available on our website.
Let me summarize the Safe Harbor language, which we have on Page 2 of the presentation. Statements in this presentation, which are not historical facts, constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the U.S. Securities Act of 1933 and the U.S. Securities Exchange Act of 1934. These statements involve risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause our actual results, levels of activity, performance or achievements to be materially different from those expressed or implied by any forward-looking statements. For a discussion of these risks and uncertainties, please see our recent Form 8-K. All of the forward-looking statements are qualified in their entirety by reference to the factors discussed under the caption Factors Affecting Our Future Operating Results and in the Business and MD&A of our Financial Conditions and Results of Operations in our Form 10-K. And just one last thing, on today's call, we may use non-GAAP financial measures. More detailed information with respect to the differences between the non-GAAP financial measure and the most directly comparable GAAP measure is provided in the Form 8-K. I will now turn the call over to Olivier.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mary, and welcome to everyone on the call. I will start with the summary of the quarter, and then the Bill will provide details on our financial results and guidance. I will then have some additional comments before we open the lines for Q&A.
componenttext:
Thank you, Mary, and welcome to everyone on the call. I will start with the summary of the quarter, and then the Bill will provide details on our financial results and guidance. I will then have some additional comments before we open the lines for Q&A. 
The highlights for the quarter are on Page 3 of the presentation. Local currency sales growth was 6% in the quarter and better than we expected. We continue to generate very solid growth in the America. Asia / Rest of World, including China, had very good growth. Europe growth was solid. With the benefit of our margin and cause initiatives, we had good growth in margins, which contributed to excellent growth in our earnings per share. Cash flow was also strong in the quarter. We are very happy with our performance as well our outlook for the remainder of the year. We will cover this shortly, but let me now turn it to Bill to cover the numbers.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Olivier, and hello, everybody. Sales were $608.3 million in the quarter, and that's an increase of 6% in local currency. On a U.S. dollar basis, sales increased by 5% as currencies reduced sales by about 1% in the quarter. On Slide #4, which sho
componenttext:
Thanks, Olivier, and hello, everybody. Sales were $608.3 million in the quarter, and that's an increase of 6% in local currency. On a U.S. dollar basis, sales increased by 5% as currencies reduced sales by about 1% in the quarter. 
On Slide #4, which show local currency sales growth for the quarter, sales grew by 6% in the Americas, 4% in Europe and 8% in Asia / Rest of World. 
On the next slide, we show local currency sales growth of 5%. On a year-to-date basis, that includes the Americas at 6%, Europe at 2% and Asia / Rest of World has increased 6% in the first half. 
Starting page -- on Slide #6, we'll outline sales by product area. Laboratory had very good growth with local currency sales up 10%, industrial increased by 3% and food retail declined by 2%. All these comparisons are, of course, to the prior year. 
On the next slide, you'll see our year-to-date sales summary by product line. Lab has grown 7% in the first half, industrial 3% and food retail increased by 1%. 
Now I'd like to turn to Slide #8 and walk through the rest of the P&L. Our gross margins were 57.1%, that's a 160 basis-point improvement over the prior year amount of 55.5%. We are very happy with the strong performance in the quarter. On a year-to-date basis, our gross margins have increased in line with the expectations we had for our expansion for the full year. 
Pricing, material cost and mix all contributed to the increase in the quarter and was partly offset by some additional targeted investments in our service business. Currency had no impact on gross margins in the quarter. 
R&D amounted to $30.7 million in the quarter, and that's a 5% increase in local currency. SG&A was $187.8 million, that's a 9% increase in local currency over the prior year. Investment in our field turbo program and higher variable comp were offset in part by cost saving initiatives. 
Adjusted operating income was $129.1 million in the quarter, that's a 9% increase over the prior year amount of $118.3 million. Currency reduced operating profit by approximately $800,000 in the quarter. Adjusted operating profit margins were 21.2%, a 90 basis point increase over the prior year and, of course, a level of which we are pleased with. 
A couple of final comments on the P&L. Amortization was $8.7 million in the quarter while interest expense was $6.9 million. Our effective tax rate was 24%. You'll notice our reported tax rate was lower at 22.9%, which is due to the tax impact of the one-time pension charge, which I'll cover in a minute. 
Fully diluted shares for the quarter were 27.1 million, which is a 4.6% decline from the prior year amount and reflects the impact of our share repurchase program. Adjusted earnings per share was $3.22 per share, that's a 15% increase over the prior year amount of $2.80 per share. 
On a reported basis, earnings per share were $2.93 per share as compared to $2.73 per share. As we mentioned on our last call, during the quarter, we took a onetime, noncash pension settlement charge of $8 million before tax or $0.19 per share after tax. This relates to offering former employees of our U.S. plan a lump sum payout. The plan that we're talking about is frozen and the timing was advantageous to cash out divested proportion for these former employees. There is no cash flow impact to the company as we used pension plan assets to fund the payments. 
Reported EPS also includes $0.04 of purchased intangible amortization and $0.06 of restructuring charges. 
The next Slide shows the P&L for the first half of the year. We had local currency sales growth of 5%, operating income increased by 7% and adjusted earnings per share increased by 12%. Absent currencies, growth for the first half of the year would have been 14%. 
Now turning to cash flow. In the quarter, free cash flow was $108.9 million, which compares to $89.9 million in the prior year. We're pleased with our working capital management and achieved further improvements in DSO, which was reduced by 2 days to 38 days as compared to the prior year. ITO was 4.6. Cash flow for the 6 months was $138 million as compared to $131.3 million in the prior year. 
In the third quarter, we expect to complete the acquisition of substantially all of the assets of the business called Troemner which is focused in 2 areas: weights and weigh calibration as well as the manufacturing of basic lab equipment. We paid approximately 10x EBITDA for the business, and it should add about 1% to sales on a full year basis. 
It's a unique strategic fit with our business, and we're very happy to be able to close the business shortly. Olivier will provide some additional background on Troemner shortly. 
Now let's turn to guidance. We're raising our full year local currency sales guidance to approximately 5% versus 4% previously. We estimate that Troemner will contribute about 50 basis points of sales growth for the half year, so for 2016. Or to say it different, we raised our organic growth expectations for the full year by 50 basis points to approximately 4.5%. We've also raised our EPS guidance, and now expect adjusted EPS to be in the range of $14.40 per share to $14.50, which represents a growth rate of 11% to 12%. This compares to previous guidance of 10% to 11% EPS growth or $14.25 per share to $14.35 per share. We are raising the midpoint of our guidance by $0.15 to reflect our strong performance as well as the acquisition of Troemner.
With respect to the third quarter, we expect local currency sales growth between 5% and 6%. This includes about 75 basis points of growth from Troemner. We assume adjusted EPS will be in the range of $3.65 per share to $3.70 per share, which is a growth rate of 12% to 13%. 
In terms of currency, let me first comment on sales growth. We would expect currency to reduce sales growth by approximately 2% in the third quarter and 2% for the full year. In terms of the impact of currency on EPS, we do not expect it to have a meaningful impact on Q3 or for the full year. 
That's it from my side. And I now want to turn it back to Olivier.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Let me start with summary comments on business conditions. Lab had very good growth in the quarter with 10% increasing. Pipette analytical instruments and process analytics had excellent growth with balances and AutoChem also had good growth
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Let me start with summary comments on business conditions. Lab had very good growth in the quarter with 10% increasing. Pipette analytical instruments and process analytics had excellent growth with balances and AutoChem also had good growth. Growth was strong across all regions and reflects our robust product pipeline, benefit of field turbo investments and continued strong sales and marketing programs. 
Spending by our biopharma customers continues to be very favorable. Industrial increased 3% in the quarter, driven by a 6% increase in core industrial. Growth in core industrial was particularly strong in the Americas, which benefited from some project activity in transportation and logistics. We also had growth in core industrial in Europe and Asia, including China. 
Product Inspection was down slightly in the quarter. This business continues to perform well, but was impacted by timing of some activity and a strong comparison from the prior year. Product Inspection have strong order growth in the quarter, and we expect good sales growth in Q3. 
Finally, sales declined 2% in retail. This was pretty much as expected. We had growth in Europe and Asia, but decline in the Americas against good growth in the prior year. 
Now let me make some additional comments by geography. Sales growth in the Americas continues to be very solid with 6% growth. We had very good growth in lab and industrial, while sales declined in retail. Demand continues to be solid in the Americas, but tougher comps will impact the second half. 
Europe grew 4% in the quarter, an improvement over the first quarter, which we think was in part due to timing of Easter holiday. Lab had excellent growth in Europe while core industrial and retail also grew. Product Inspection was down, which would improve in the quarter. 
Asia / Rest of the World had growth of 8% in the quarter. China did very well and better than we expected as compared to the last time we spoke. Lab growth in China was double digits with almost all product lines showing very good growth. We are pleased with the performance, which reflects some improving demand and also the benefit of our actions to reduce -- redirect resources to faster-growing market segment. While industrial in China had modest growth, the fact is that overcapacity in the industrial manufacturing sector remains. 
While we're also pleased with our results in China, we expect growth in the second half to be in the mid-single digit range. 
Let me make some comments on service, which grew 5% in the quarter and on an year-to-date basis. Service represents about 23% of total sales, and it is a key competitive advantage and an important source of revenue growth. This is the fifth year in a row with service growth is outpacing product growth. Although this might not occur each and every quarter, over the medium term, we expect service growth to exceed product growth. We have a service force of approximately 2,600 personnel which is, by far, larger than our direct competitor. Our service team is specialized by product area, and we have made significant investments, including training of tools, which supports the daily activity. 
Core to our service growth strategy is increasing the percentage of our installed base under service contract and increasing the amount of service sold at a point of product sale. The long-term objective is to change the mix of our service business to be largely contract business versus great fix. Today, contract represent approximately 1/3 of our service sales. There are several reasons why this migration is a strategic imperative, including the increasing quality of our products, reducing the need for repair, contract work -- sorry, and on the other half, contract work is more usually planned. And therefore, our technicians can be more productive. And finally, our studies show that service contracts leads to high levels of cost -- customer satisfaction, and therefore, retention. 
The globalization and harmonization of our service offering, which we undertook several years ago, led the groundwork to drive the contract business. Our marketing campaigns under the Spinnaker initiative and our field turbo investments are helping to drive this strength [ph]. Overall, we continue to make very good progress. We believe service is one of our most important competitive advantage and should continue to be an important source of sales and profit growth. 
Those are all my comments on business strength. I now want to provide some context to our acquisition of Troemner. Located in the Philadelphia area, Troemner is the U.S. market leader for weights and weight calibration and a great strategic fit to our leadership position in Europe. Together, we are now the global leader in this niche market. Weights and weight recalibration services is an attractive market. It has a strong barriers to entry as it requires very specialized know-how and expertise. We have 14 calibration labs worldwide, and the acquisition of Troemner firmly positions us as the U.S. market leader. Troemner is a very strong brand in U.S. based on its word class metrology competence and solid infrastructure. 
Service, which consists primarily of weight calibration, is almost 20% of Troemner's business and growing quite well. This is an attractive business as customers must calibrate weights on a regular basis and only a very few players have the expertise to do it correctly. This is a good example of the kind of service business that fits well into our goal of moving our service business to more contract value-added service. 
Troemner is also a provider of basic lab product such as stirrers, mixers and shakers, which will be a good strategic fit to Ohaus offering. As a reminder, Ohaus is our second brand used for indirect distribution for laboratory products of certain industrial weighing products. 
Troemner will help us strengthen the life science portfolio for Ohaus, which we have worked to expand over the last few years in terms of channel presence and product portfolio. We also believe we can further expand this equipment offering internationally, particularly in emerging markets. We think this is a great opportunity to extend the offering of Ohaus. Troemner would add about 1% to sales growth with similar margins to our own. We anticipate synergy potential from top line growth as well as potential in operational synergies. We expect to complete the acquisition shortly and have already begun integration plan. We believe this is a solid strategic acquisition and are excited about the potential development in this attractive market segment. 
That concludes our prepared remarks. We have kept our comments brief as we will see many of you tomorrow at our Investor Meeting. Let me make some summary comments before opening it up for question. 
We are very pleased with strong results in the second quarter. Our outlook for the remainder of the year is good, but we acknowledge the uncertainty in the global economy. Our focus remains on factors we can control, namely successful execution of our initiatives. We feel very good about our new product launches, field turbo investment, Spinnaker marketing initiatives and productivity measures. We believe with continued strong execution, we can continue to gain share. I want now to ask the operator to open the line for questions.

U.K. is about the extent of our total revenue. U.K. had already some softness before Brexit and would associate some of their softness with the uncertainty and certainly after both the uncertainty of [indiscernible] we will expect some further softness in U.K.

So we're very happy with how that business performed in terms of execution and continue to think that the market dynamics are good in that business, Tycho.

componenttext: Just 2 things. Bill, the EPS guidance increased as you guys did. Is there any -- are you guys expecting any accretion in the back half here from the acquisition you've done here? And then I guess, secondly, so it's not everyday that you guys do a lot of M&A, but just wondering if there was any -- you think there are other future opportunities down the road for further consolidation of smaller lab manufacturers such as this?

componenttext: So let me -- so this is a case that fits perfectly in our franchise from a size perspective, it's equally core to us, [indiscernible] opportunities around we actually go for them. We have a radar of possible progress. There are more of these companies that actually [indiscernible] when they become available [indiscernible] So we really pursue them and whenever they materialize, we are more than happy to close them. And we are looking at smaller ones, too. But I wouldn't -- you shouldn't look that as a new part strategy that we're pursuing. It's -- we did a couple of technology adjacencies. And this time, we had a great opportunity to acquire actually a service business. And if that pops up again, we will do so.

componenttext: So we did compete. Troemner has a fantastic brand and competent in the U.S. that they build up over decades. That always made it difficult for Mettler-Toledo to compete. As in Europe, we have been the leader and it was difficult for Troemner to establish a presence in Europe.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I understand the comment. If you -- I think the comment that we've been making now over the last couple of quarters, Rick, is that given overcapacity as well as let's call it credit risk in the Chinese market, that it's worth quite a little bit of a disco
componenttext: I understand the comment. If you -- I think the comment that we've been making now over the last couple of quarters, Rick, is that given overcapacity as well as let's call it credit risk in the Chinese market, that it's worth quite a little bit of a discount on that piece of it. That would be kind of #1. And #2 would be in the details now, and I'm not counting a lot of basis points, but that we see some tougher comps in a couple of different areas. So if you look at our year-to-date number, we're plus 5% and we're saying, hey, by the end of the year, we should finish at 4.5% at the midpoint of the range and, I guess, closer to 5% at the high end of the range. So let's see how China and some of these comps play out. Biopharma has been a strong market for a while. I'd like to think that there is upside to the numbers, but we'll see as the quarter -- the second half plays out.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's great. And then just one last question, maybe for Olivier. The lab strength in China, is that somewhat traditional relative to the other geographies? In other words, is that coming out of the biopharm vertical? Or are we seeing more uptake there in other labs, environmental or food and beverage? Or is it -- does the strength there by vertical kind of matchup with U.S. or Europe?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, I would say yes to both what you said. Yes, too, that generally, the lab is doing well, but I would also say, yes, that the life science and biopharma is particularly strong in China.
componenttext: Hey, I would say yes to both what you said. Yes, too, that generally, the lab is doing well, but I would also say, yes, that the life science and biopharma is particularly strong in China.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So hey, I -- maybe on the economic stuff, I'm not sure if we're a better source than kind of what you guys read. I think it's a bit of a -- a lot of economic data globally, it's a bit of a mixed picture. Maybe one interesting insight we might give you is
componenttext: So hey, I -- maybe on the economic stuff, I'm not sure if we're a better source than kind of what you guys read. I think it's a bit of a -- a lot of economic data globally, it's a bit of a mixed picture. Maybe one interesting insight we might give you is that I know there's been some articles that some of the GDP growth has come from leveraging up further some of the state-owned enterprises and regional governments. And it was interesting for us to see when we sorted through the details of our numbers that we saw really good growth, of course, in the government sector when it came to lab. But we also saw across the board very good growth with multinationals. And that's an interesting comment in the sense that if you look over the last 3 years, the percentage of our total sales in China going to multinationals has shrunk. But now we see a nice rebound in the first half of the year across product categories, and I think that -- this famous comment that we talked about of -- for a multinational company, they can defer the replacement cycle for a while on our products, but eventually, it bounces back. And I think we see that a little bit there. It's probably a little less than the project side, but much more return to the normal replacement cycle. In terms of the order entry, order entry was similarly positive to what we saw in the sales side. So it was a solid number. It wasn't -- it's not that we -- that purely the order entry would make us cautious about the second half. It's just the realities of that, it's still a market with some instability in it, and I think us remaining cautious makes sense. But I actually felt what we just shared with you about multinational was one of the more positive readings that we had in our data coming out of China.

componenttextpreview: Sure. So in terms of our price increases, our net realized price increases were 230 basis points up in the second quarter. And on a year-to-date basis, they're now up at 2%. We did go and look, and just to put that in a little bit of context, some of that
componenttext: Sure. So in terms of our price increases, our net realized price increases were 230 basis points up in the second quarter. And on a year-to-date basis, they're now up at 2%. We did go and look, and just to put that in a little bit of context, some of that was chasing some of the currency movements that kind of happened in the course of the earlier part of the end of the first quarter, early part of the second quarter. And so we are trying to do something in terms of mid-year prices. I would not expect the second half of the year to be worse than 2 at this point in time.
