headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to our Second Quarter 2016 Mettler-Toledo International Earnings Conference Call. My name is Nicole, and I will be your audio coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn our presentat
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to our Second Quarter 2016 Mettler-Toledo International Earnings Conference Call. My name is Nicole, and I will be your audio coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn our presentation over to your host for today's call, Ms. Mary Finnegan. Please proceed, ma'am.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nicole, and good afternoon, everyone. I am Mary Finnegan. I'm the Treasurer, and I'm responsible for Investor Relations at Mettler-Toledo. I'm happy that you're joining us this evening. I'm joined by Olivier Filliol, our CEO; and Bill Donnelly,
componenttext:
Thanks, Nicole, and good afternoon, everyone. I am Mary Finnegan. I'm the Treasurer, and I'm responsible for Investor Relations at Mettler-Toledo. I'm happy that you're joining us this evening. 
I'm joined by Olivier Filliol, our CEO; and Bill Donnelly, our Executive Vice President.
I need to cover just a couple administrative matters. The call is being webcast and is available for replay on our website. A copy of the press release and the presentation that we refer to on today's call is also available on our website.
Let me summarize the Safe Harbor language, which we have on Page 2 of the presentation. Statements in this presentation, which are not historical facts, constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the U.S. Securities Act of 1933 and the U.S. Securities Exchange Act of 1934. These statements involve risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause our actual results, levels of activity, performance or achievements to be materially different from those expressed or implied by any forward-looking statements. For a discussion of these risks and uncertainties, please see our recent Form 8-K. All of the forward-looking statements are qualified in their entirety by reference to the factors discussed under the caption Factors Affecting Our Future Operating Results and in the Business and MD&A of our Financial Conditions and Results of Operations in our Form 10-K. And just one last thing, on today's call, we may use non-GAAP financial measures. More detailed information with respect to the differences between the non-GAAP financial measure and the most directly comparable GAAP measure is provided in the Form 8-K. I will now turn the call over to Olivier.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mary, and welcome to everyone on the call. I will start with the summary of the quarter, and then the Bill will provide details on our financial results and guidance. I will then have some additional comments before we open the lines for Q&A.
componenttext:
Thank you, Mary, and welcome to everyone on the call. I will start with the summary of the quarter, and then the Bill will provide details on our financial results and guidance. I will then have some additional comments before we open the lines for Q&A. 
The highlights for the quarter are on Page 3 of the presentation. Local currency sales growth was 6% in the quarter and better than we expected. We continue to generate very solid growth in the America. Asia / Rest of World, including China, had very good growth. Europe growth was solid. With the benefit of our margin and  initiatives we had good growth in margins, which contributed to excellent growth in our earnings per share. Cash flow was also strong in the quarter. We are very happy with our performance as well our outlook for the remainder of the year. We will cover this shortly, but let me now turn it to Bill to cover the numbers.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Olivier, and hello, everybody. Sales were $608.3 million in the quarter, and that's an increase of 6% in local currency. On a U.S. dollar basis, sales increased by 5% as currencies reduced sales by about 1% in the quarter. On Slide #4, which sho
componenttext:
Thanks, Olivier, and hello, everybody. Sales were $608.3 million in the quarter, and that's an increase of 6% in local currency. On a U.S. dollar basis, sales increased by 5% as currencies reduced sales by about 1% in the quarter. 
On Slide #4, which show local currency sales growth for the quarter, sales grew by 6% in the Americas, 4% in Europe and 8% in Asia / Rest of World. 
On the next slide, we show local currency sales growth of 5%. On a year-to-date basis, that includes the Americas at 6%, Europe at 2% and Asia / Rest of World has increased 6% in the first half. 
Starting page -- on Slide #6, we'll outline sales by product area. Laboratory had very good growth with local currency sales up 10%, industrial increased by 3% and food retail declined by 2%. All these comparisons are, of course, to the prior year. 
On the next slide, you'll see our year-to-date sales summary by product line. Lab has grown 7% in the first half, industrial 3% and food retail increased by 1%. 
Now I'd like to turn to Slide #8 and walk through the rest of the P&L. Our gross margins were 57.1%, that's a 160 basis-point improvement over the prior year amount of 55.5%. We are very happy with the strong performance in the quarter. On a year-to-date basis, our gross margins have increased in line with the expectations we had for our expansion for the full year. 
Pricing, material cost and mix all contributed to the increase in the quarter and was partly offset by some additional targeted investments in our service business. Currency had no impact on gross margins in the quarter. 
R&D amounted to $30.7 million in the quarter, and that's a 5% increase in local currency. SG&A was $187.8 million, that's a 9% increase in local currency over the prior year. Investment in our field turbo program and higher variable comp were offset in part by cost saving initiatives. 
Adjusted operating income was $129.1 million in the quarter, that's a 9% increase over the prior year amount of $118.3 million. Currency reduced operating profit by approximately $800,000 in the quarter. Adjusted operating profit margins were 21.2%, a 90 basis point increase over the prior year and, of course, a level of which we are pleased with. 
A couple of final comments on the P&L. Amortization was $8.7 million in the quarter while interest expense was $6.9 million. Our effective tax rate was 24%. You'll notice our reported tax rate was lower at 22.9%, which is due to the tax impact of the one-time pension charge, which I'll cover in a minute. 
Fully diluted shares for the quarter were 27.1 million, which is a 4.6% decline from the prior year amount and reflects the impact of our share repurchase program. Adjusted earnings per share was $3.22 per share, that's a 15% increase over the prior year amount of $2.80 per share. 
On a reported basis, earnings per share were $2.93 per share as compared to $2.73 per share. As we mentioned on our last call, during the quarter, we took a onetime, noncash pension settlement charge of $8 million before tax or $0.19 per share after tax. This relates to offering former employees of our U.S. plan a lump sum payout. The plan that we're talking about is frozen and the timing was advantageous to cash out divested proportion for these former employees. There is no cash flow impact to the company as we used pension plan assets to fund the payments. 
Reported EPS also includes $0.04 of purchased intangible amortization and $0.06 of restructuring charges. 
The next Slide shows the P&L for the first half of the year. We had local currency sales growth of 5%, operating income increased by 7% and adjusted earnings per share increased by 12%. Absent currencies, growth for the first half of the year would have been 14%. 
Now turning to cash flow. In the quarter, free cash flow was $108.9 million, which compares to $89.9 million in the prior year. We're pleased with our working capital management and achieved further improvements in DSO, which was reduced by 2 days to 38 days as compared to the prior year. ITO was 4.6. Cash flow for the 6 months was $138 million as compared to $131.3 million in the prior year. 
In the third quarter, we expect to complete the acquisition of substantially all of the assets of the business called Troemner which is focused in 2 areas: weights and weigh calibration as well as the manufacturing of basic lab equipment. We paid approximately 10x EBITDA for the business, and it should add about 1% to sales on a full year basis. 
It's a unique strategic fit with our business, and we're very happy to be able to close the business shortly. Olivier will provide some additional background on Troemner shortly. 
Now let's turn to guidance. We're raising our full year local currency sales guidance to approximately 5% versus 4% previously. We estimate that Troemner will contribute about 50 basis points of sales growth for the half year, so for 2016. Or to say it different, we raised our organic growth expectations for the full year by 50 basis points to approximately 4.5%. We've also raised our EPS guidance, and now expect adjusted EPS to be in the range of $14.40 per share to $14.50, which represents a growth rate of 11% to 12%. This compares to previous guidance of 10% to 11% EPS growth or $14.25 per share to $14.35 per share. We are raising the midpoint of our guidance by $0.15 to reflect our strong performance as well as the acquisition of Troemner.
With respect to the third quarter, we expect local currency sales growth between 5% and 6%. This includes about 75 basis points of growth from Troemner. We assume adjusted EPS will be in the range of $3.65 per share to $3.70 per share, which is a growth rate of 12% to 13%. 
In terms of currency, let me first comment on sales growth. We would expect currency to reduce sales growth by approximately 2% in the third quarter and 2% for the full year. In terms of the impact of currency on EPS, we do not expect it to have a meaningful impact on Q3 or for the full year. 
That's it from my side. And I now want to turn it back to Olivier.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Let me start with summary comments on business conditions. Lab had very good growth in the quarter with 10% increasing. Pipette analytical instruments and process analytics had excellent growth with balances and AutoChem also had good growth
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Let me start with summary comments on business conditions. Lab had very good growth in the quarter with 10% increasing. Pipette analytical instruments and process analytics had excellent growth with balances and AutoChem also had good growth. Growth was strong across all regions and reflects our robust product pipeline, benefit of field turbo investments and continued strong sales and marketing programs. 
Spending by our biopharma customers continues to be very favorable. Industrial increased 3% in the quarter, driven by a 6% increase in core industrial. Growth in core industrial was particularly strong in the Americas, which benefited from some project activity in transportation and logistics. We also had growth in core industrial in Europe and Asia, including China. 
Product Inspection was down slightly in the quarter. This business continues to perform well, but was impacted by timing of some activity and a strong comparison from the prior year. Product Inspection have strong order growth in the quarter, and we expect good sales growth in Q3. 
Finally, sales declined 2% in retail. This was pretty much as expected. We had growth in Europe and Asia, but decline in the Americas against good growth in the prior year. 
Now let me make some additional comments by geography. Sales growth in the Americas continues to be very solid with 6% growth. We had very good growth in lab and industrial, while sales declined in retail. Demand continues to be solid in the Americas, but tougher comps will impact the second half. 
Europe grew 4% in the quarter, an improvement over the first quarter, which we think was in part due to timing of Easter holiday. Lab had excellent growth in Europe while core industrial and retail also grew. Product Inspection was down, which would improve in the quarter. 
Asia / Rest of the World had growth of 8% in the quarter. China did very well and better than we expected as compared to the last time we spoke. Lab growth in China was double digits with almost all product lines showing very good growth. We are pleased with the performance, which reflects some improving demand and also the benefit of our actions to reduce -- redirect resources to faster-growing market segment. While industrial in China had modest growth, the fact is that overcapacity in the industrial manufacturing sector remains. 
While we're also pleased with our results in China, we expect growth in the second half to be in the mid-single digit range. 
Let me make some comments on service, which grew 5% in the quarter and on an year-to-date basis. Service represents about 23% of total sales, and it is a key competitive advantage and an important source of revenue growth. This is the fifth year in a row with service growth is outpacing product growth. Although this might not occur each and every quarter, over the medium term, we expect service growth to exceed product growth. We have a service force of approximately 2,600 personnel which is, by far, larger than our direct competitor. Our service team is specialized by product area, and we have made significant investments, including training of tools, which supports the daily activity. 
Core to our service growth strategy is increasing the percentage of our installed base under service contract and increasing the amount of service sold at a point of product sale. The long-term objective is to change the mix of our service business to be largely contract business versus great fix. Today, contract represent approximately 1/3 of our service sales. There are several reasons why this migration is a strategic imperative, including the increasing quality of our products, reducing the need for repair, contract work -- sorry, and on the other half, contract work is more usually planned. And therefore, our technicians can be more productive. And finally, our studies show that service contracts leads to high levels of cost -- customer satisfaction, and therefore, retention. 
The globalization and harmonization of our service offering, which we undertook several years ago, led the groundwork to drive the contract business. Our marketing campaigns under the Spinnaker initiative and our field turbo investments are helping to drive this strength. Overall, we continue to make very good progress. We believe service is one of our most important competitive advantage and should continue to be an important source of sales and profit growth. 
Those are all my comments on business strength. I now want to provide some context to our acquisition of Troemner. Located in the Philadelphia area, Troemner is the U.S. market leader for weights and weight calibration and a great strategic fit to our leadership position in Europe. Together, we are now the global leader in this niche market. Weights and weight recalibration services is an attractive market. It has a strong barriers to entry as it requires very specialized know-how and expertise. We have 14 calibration labs worldwide, and the acquisition of Troemner firmly positions us as the U.S. market leader. Troemner is a very strong brand in U.S. based on its word class metrology competence and solid infrastructure. 
Service, which consists primarily of weight calibration, is almost 20% of Troemner's business and growing quite well. This is an attractive business as customers must calibrate weights on a regular basis and only a very few players have the expertise to do it correctly. This is a good example of the kind of service business that fits well into our goal of moving our service business to more contract value-added service. 
Troemner is also a provider of basic lab product such as stirrers, mixers and shakers, which will be a good strategic fit to Ohaus offering. As a reminder, Ohaus is our second brand used for indirect distribution for laboratory products of certain industrial weighing products. 
Troemner will help us strengthen the life science portfolio for Ohaus, which we have worked to expand over the last few years in terms of channel presence and product portfolio. We also believe we can further expand this equipment offering internationally, particularly in emerging markets. We think this is a great opportunity to extend the offering of Ohaus. Troemner would add about 1% to sales growth with similar margins to our own. We anticipate synergy potential from top line growth as well as potential in operational synergies. We expect to complete the acquisition shortly and have already begun integration plan. We believe this is a solid strategic acquisition and are excited about the potential development in this attractive market segment. 
That concludes our prepared remarks. We have kept our comments brief as we will see many of you tomorrow at our Investor Meeting. Let me make some summary comments before opening it up for question. 
We are very pleased with strong results in the second quarter. Our outlook for the remainder of the year is good, but we acknowledge the uncertainty in the global economy. Our focus remains on factors we can control, namely successful execution of our initiatives. We feel very good about our new product launches, field turbo investment, Spinnaker marketing initiatives and productivity measures. We believe with continued strong execution, we can continue to gain share. I want now to ask the operator to open the line for questions.

componenttext: So you're right, it was modestly easier comps so in Q1 of '15, we grew by about 8% and in Q2 of '15, we grew by about 5%. headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not really. I think, actually, overall, the industrial business is not a super end  market. I don't see, I think, get worse at all. Contrary, you could say, very gradually, things get better. And in Europe, overall, I expect the next few quarters will be
componenttext: Not really. I think, actually, overall, the industrial business is not a super end  market. I don't see, I think, get worse at all. Contrary, you could say, very gradually, things get better. And in Europe, overall, I expect the next few quarters will be reasonably good. So the whole Brexit effect, I'm not saying it's positive, but it wasn't particularly negative with one exception, U.K. itself. But we need to put it in perspective. U.K. is about the extent of our total revenue. U.K. had already some softness before Brexit and would associate some of their softness with the uncertainty and certainly after both the uncertainty of softness we will expect some further softness in U.K.

componenttext: So regarding Switzerland, no. The currency is actually -- didn't move particularly. The currency moves that took place is impacting our producing organization in U.K. As you might know, we have -- for the Product Inspection, we have product inspection, and we have method inspection of the x-ray production there, this is in essence favorable for us but will not change something to our global manufacturing strategy or our footprint. So I don't see that this will impact our strategy in any significant way.

componenttext: So if I look at China in total, I think, the second quarter was marginally better than the first, that was largely driven by our lab business and, in particular, perhaps with analytics within the lab business. componenttext: So let me -- so this is a case that fits perfectly in our franchise from a size perspective, it's equally core to us, opportunities around we actually go for them. componenttext: So we did compete. Troemner has a fantastic brand and competent in the U.S. that they build up over decades. That always made it difficult for Mettler-Toledo to compete. As in Europe, we have been the leader and it was difficult for Troemner to establish a presence in Europe.

componenttext: Okay. Despite the strength you're seeing out of Asia Pac and even the reacceleration maybe in Europe, I mean, that's -- is that a high confidence forecast that that's all that, that would contribute in the second half? I would think that's geographically, it said Asia Pac seems to be driving more upside than that.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I understand the comment. If you -- I think the comment that we've been making now over the last couple of quarters, Rick, is that given overcapacity as well as let's call it credit risk in the Chinese market, that it's worth quite a little bit of a disco
componenttext: I understand the comment. If you -- I think the comment that we've been making now over the last couple of quarters, Rick, is that given overcapacity as well as let's call it credit risk in the Chinese market, that it's worth quite a little bit of a discount on that piece of it. That would be kind of #1. And #2 would be in the details now, and I'm not counting a lot of basis points, but that we see some tougher comps in a couple of different areas. So if you look at our year-to-date number, we're plus 5% and we're saying, hey, by the end of the year, we should finish at 4.5% at the midpoint of the range and, I guess, closer to 5% at the high end of the range. So let's see how China and some of these comps play out. Biopharma has been a strong market for a while. I'd like to think that there is upside to the numbers, but we'll see as the quarter -- the second half plays out.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's great. And then just one last question, maybe for Olivier. The lab strength in China, is that somewhat traditional relative to the other geographies? In other words, is that coming out of the biopharm vertical? Or are we seeing more uptake th
componenttext: Okay, that's great. And then just one last question, maybe for Olivier. The lab strength in China, is that somewhat traditional relative to the other geographies? In other words, is that coming out of the biopharm vertical? Or are we seeing more uptake there in other labs, environmental or food and beverage? Or is it -- does the strength there by vertical kind of matchup with U.S. or Europe?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, I would say yes to both what you said. Yes, too, that generally, the lab is doing well, but I would also say, yes, that the life science and biopharma is particularly strong in China.
componenttext: Hey, I would say yes to both what you said. Yes, too, that generally, the lab is doing well, but I would also say, yes, that the life science and biopharma is particularly strong in China.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So hey, I -- maybe on the economic stuff, I'm not sure if we're a better source than kind of what you guys read. I think it's a bit of a -- a lot of economic data globally, it's a bit of a mixed picture. Maybe one interesting insight we might give you is
componenttext: So hey, I -- maybe on the economic stuff, I'm not sure if we're a better source than kind of what you guys read. I think it's a bit of a -- a lot of economic data globally, it's a bit of a mixed picture. Maybe one interesting insight we might give you is that I know there's been some articles that some of the GDP growth has come from leveraging up further some of the state-owned enterprises and regional governments. And it was interesting for us to see when we sorted through the details of our numbers that we saw really good growth, of course, in the government sector when it came to lab. But we also saw across the board very good growth with multinationals. And that's an interesting comment in the sense that if you look over the last 3 years, the percentage of our total sales in China going to multinationals has shrunk. But now we see a nice rebound in the first half of the year across product categories, and I think that -- this famous comment that we talked about of -- for a multinational company, they can defer the replacement cycle for a while on our products, but eventually, it bounces back. And I think we see that a little bit there. It's probably a little less than the project side, but much more return to the normal replacement cycle. In terms of the order entry, order entry was similarly positive to what we saw in the sales side. So it was a solid number. It wasn't -- it's not that we -- that purely the order entry would make us cautious about the second half. It's just the realities of that, it's still a market with some instability in it, and I think us remaining cautious makes sense. But I actually felt what we just shared with you about multinational was one of the more positive readings that we had in our data coming out of China.

componenttext: Sure. So in terms of our price increases, our net realized price increases were 230 basis points up in the second quarter. And on a year-to-date basis, they're now up at 2%. We did go and look, and just to put that in a little bit of context, some of that was chasing some of the currency movements that kind of happened in the course of the earlier part of the end of the first quarter, early part of the second quarter. And so we are trying to do something in terms of mid-year prices. I would not expect the second half of the year to be worse than 2 at this point in time.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to our Second Quarter 2016 Mettler-Toledo International Earnings Conference Call. My name is Nicole, and I will be your audio coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn our presentat
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to our Second Quarter 2016 Mettler-Toledo International Earnings Conference Call. My name is Nicole, and I will be your audio coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn our presentation over to your host for today's call, Ms. Mary Finnegan. Please proceed, ma'am.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nicole, and good afternoon, everyone. I am Mary Finnegan. I'm the Treasurer, and I'm responsible for Investor Relations at Mettler-Toledo. I'm happy that you're joining us this evening. I'm joined by Olivier Filliol, our CEO; and Bill Donnelly,
componenttext:
Thanks, Nicole, and good afternoon, everyone. I am Mary Finnegan. I'm the Treasurer, and I'm responsible for Investor Relations at Mettler-Toledo. I'm happy that you're joining us this evening. 
I'm joined by Olivier Filliol, our CEO; and Bill Donnelly, our Executive Vice President.
I need to cover just a couple administrative matters. The call is being webcast and is available for replay on our website. A copy of the press release and the presentation that we refer to on today's call is also available on our website.
Let me summarize the Safe Harbor language, which we have on Page 2 of the presentation. Statements in this presentation, which are not historical facts, constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the U.S. Securities Act of 1933 and the U.S. Securities Exchange Act of 1934. These statements involve risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause our actual results, levels of activity, performance or achievements to be materially different from those expressed or implied by any forward-looking statements. For a discussion of these risks and uncertainties, please see our recent Form 8-K. All of the forward-looking statements are qualified in their entirety by reference to the factors discussed under the caption Factors Affecting Our Future Operating Results and in the Business and MD&A of our Financial Conditions and Results of Operations in our Form 10-K. And just one last thing, on today's call, we may use non-GAAP financial measures. More detailed information with respect to the differences between the non-GAAP financial measure and the most directly comparable GAAP measure is provided in the Form 8-K. I will now turn the call over to Olivier.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mary, and welcome to everyone on the call. I will start with the summary of the quarter, and then the Bill will provide details on our financial results and guidance. I will then have some additional comments before we open the lines for Q&A.
componenttext:
Thank you, Mary, and welcome to everyone on the call. I will start with the summary of the quarter, and then the Bill will provide details on our financial results and guidance. I will then have some additional comments before we open the lines for Q&A. 
The highlights for the quarter are on Page 3 of the presentation. Local currency sales growth was 6% in the quarter and better than we expected. We continue to generate very solid growth in the America. Asia / Rest of World, including China, had very good growth. Europe growth was solid. With the benefit of our margin and  initiatives we had good growth in margins, which contributed to excellent growth in our earnings per share. Cash flow was also strong in the quarter. We are very happy with our performance as well our outlook for the remainder of the year. We will cover this shortly, but let me now turn it to Bill to cover the numbers.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Olivier, and hello, everybody. Sales were $608.3 million in the quarter, and that's an increase of 6% in local currency. On a U.S. dollar basis, sales increased by 5% as currencies reduced sales by about 1% in the quarter. On Slide #4, which sho
componenttext:
Thanks, Olivier, and hello, everybody. Sales were $608.3 million in the quarter, and that's an increase of 6% in local currency. On a U.S. dollar basis, sales increased by 5% as currencies reduced sales by about 1% in the quarter. 
On Slide #4, which show local currency sales growth for the quarter, sales grew by 6% in the Americas, 4% in Europe and 8% in Asia / Rest of World. 
On the next slide, we show local currency sales growth of 5%. On a year-to-date basis, that includes the Americas at 6%, Europe at 2% and Asia / Rest of World has increased 6% in the first half. 
Starting page -- on Slide #6, we'll outline sales by product area. Laboratory had very good growth with local currency sales up 10%, industrial increased by 3% and food retail declined by 2%. All these comparisons are, of course, to the prior year. 
On the next slide, you'll see our year-to-date sales summary by product line. Lab has grown 7% in the first half, industrial 3% and food retail increased by 1%. 
Now I'd like to turn to Slide #8 and walk through the rest of the P&L. Our gross margins were 57.1%, that's a 160 basis-point improvement over the prior year amount of 55.5%. We are very happy with the strong performance in the quarter. On a year-to-date basis, our gross margins have increased in line with the expectations we had for our expansion for the full year. 
Pricing, material cost and mix all contributed to the increase in the quarter and was partly offset by some additional targeted investments in our service business. Currency had no impact on gross margins in the quarter. 
R&D amounted to $30.7 million in the quarter, and that's a 5% increase in local currency. SG&A was $187.8 million, that's a 9% increase in local currency over the prior year. Investment in our field turbo program and higher variable comp were offset in part by cost saving initiatives. 
Adjusted operating income was $129.1 million in the quarter, that's a 9% increase over the prior year amount of $118.3 million. Currency reduced operating profit by approximately $800,000 in the quarter. Adjusted operating profit margins were 21.2%, a 90 basis point increase over the prior year and, of course, a level of which we are pleased with. 
A couple of final comments on the P&L. Amortization was $8.7 million in the quarter while interest expense was $6.9 million. Our effective tax rate was 24%. You'll notice our reported tax rate was lower at 22.9%, which is due to the tax impact of the one-time pension charge, which I'll cover in a minute. 
Fully diluted shares for the quarter were 27.1 million, which is a 4.6% decline from the prior year amount and reflects the impact of our share repurchase program. Adjusted earnings per share was $3.22 per share, that's a 15% increase over the prior year amount of $2.80 per share. 
On a reported basis, earnings per share were $2.93 per share as compared to $2.73 per share. As we mentioned on our last call, during the quarter, we took a onetime, noncash pension settlement charge of $8 million before tax or $0.19 per share after tax. This relates to offering former employees of our U.S. plan a lump sum payout. The plan that we're talking about is frozen and the timing was advantageous to cash out divested proportion for these former employees. There is no cash flow impact to the company as we used pension plan assets to fund the payments. 
Reported EPS also includes $0.04 of purchased intangible amortization and $0.06 of restructuring charges. 
The next Slide shows the P&L for the first half of the year. We had local currency sales growth of 5%, operating income increased by 7% and adjusted earnings per share increased by 12%. Absent currencies, growth for the first half of the year would have been 14%. 
Now turning to cash flow. In the quarter, free cash flow was $108.9 million, which compares to $89.9 million in the prior year. We're pleased with our working capital management and achieved further improvements in DSO, which was reduced by 2 days to 38 days as compared to the prior year. ITO was 4.6. Cash flow for the 6 months was $138 million as compared to $131.3 million in the prior year. 
In the third quarter, we expect to complete the acquisition of substantially all of the assets of the business called Troemner which is focused in 2 areas: weights and weigh calibration as well as the manufacturing of basic lab equipment. We paid approximately 10x EBITDA for the business, and it should add about 1% to sales on a full year basis. 
It's a unique strategic fit with our business, and we're very happy to be able to close the business shortly. Olivier will provide some additional background on Troemner shortly. 
Now let's turn to guidance. We're raising our full year local currency sales guidance to approximately 5% versus 4% previously. We estimate that Troemner will contribute about 50 basis points of sales growth for the half year, so for 2016. Or to say it different, we raised our organic growth expectations for the full year by 50 basis points to approximately 4.5%. We've also raised our EPS guidance, and now expect adjusted EPS to be in the range of $14.40 per share to $14.50, which represents a growth rate of 11% to 12%. This compares to previous guidance of 10% to 11% EPS growth or $14.25 per share to $14.35 per share. We are raising the midpoint of our guidance by $0.15 to reflect our strong performance as well as the acquisition of Troemner.
With respect to the third quarter, we expect local currency sales growth between 5% and 6%. This includes about 75 basis points of growth from Troemner. We assume adjusted EPS will be in the range of $3.65 per share to $3.70 per share, which is a growth rate of 12% to 13%. 
In terms of currency, let me first comment on sales growth. We would expect currency to reduce sales growth by approximately 2% in the third quarter and 2% for the full year. In terms of the impact of currency on EPS, we do not expect it to have a meaningful impact on Q3 or for the full year. 
That's it from my side. And I now want to turn it back to Olivier.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Let me start with summary comments on business conditions. Lab had very good growth in the quarter with 10% increasing. Pipette analytical instruments and process analytics had excellent growth with balances and AutoChem also had good growth
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Let me start with summary comments on business conditions. Lab had very good growth in the quarter with 10% increasing. Pipette analytical instruments and process analytics had excellent growth with balances and AutoChem also had good growth. Growth was strong across all regions and reflects our robust product pipeline, benefit of field turbo investments and continued strong sales and marketing programs. 
Spending by our biopharma customers continues to be very favorable. Industrial increased 3% in the quarter, driven by a 6% increase in core industrial. Growth in core industrial was particularly strong in the Americas, which benefited from some project activity in transportation and logistics. We also had growth in core industrial in Europe and Asia, including China. 
Product Inspection was down slightly in the quarter. This business continues to perform well, but was impacted by timing of some activity and a strong comparison from the prior year. Product Inspection have strong order growth in the quarter, and we expect good sales growth in Q3. 
Finally, sales declined 2% in retail. This was pretty much as expected. We had growth in Europe and Asia, but decline in the Americas against good growth in the prior year. 
Now let me make some additional comments by geography. Sales growth in the Americas continues to be very solid with 6% growth. We had very good growth in lab and industrial, while sales declined in retail. Demand continues to be solid in the Americas, but tougher comps will impact the second half. 
Europe grew 4% in the quarter, an improvement over the first quarter, which we think was in part due to timing of Easter holiday. Lab had excellent growth in Europe while core industrial and retail also grew. Product Inspection was down, which would improve in the quarter. 
Asia / Rest of the World had growth of 8% in the quarter. China did very well and better than we expected as compared to the last time we spoke. Lab growth in China was double digits with almost all product lines showing very good growth. We are pleased with the performance, which reflects some improving demand and also the benefit of our actions to reduce -- redirect resources to faster-growing market segment. While industrial in China had modest growth, the fact is that overcapacity in the industrial manufacturing sector remains. 
While we're also pleased with our results in China, we expect growth in the second half to be in the mid-single digit range. 
Let me make some comments on service, which grew 5% in the quarter and on an year-to-date basis. Service represents about 23% of total sales, and it is a key competitive advantage and an important source of revenue growth. This is the fifth year in a row with service growth is outpacing product growth. Although this might not occur each and every quarter, over the medium term, we expect service growth to exceed product growth. We have a service force of approximately 2,600 personnel which is, by far, larger than our direct competitor. Our service team is specialized by product area, and we have made significant investments, including training of tools, which supports the daily activity. 
Core to our service growth strategy is increasing the percentage of our installed base under service contract and increasing the amount of service sold at a point of product sale. The long-term objective is to change the mix of our service business to be largely contract business versus great fix. Today, contract represent approximately 1/3 of our service sales. There are several reasons why this migration is a strategic imperative, including the increasing quality of our products, reducing the need for repair, contract work -- sorry, and on the other half, contract work is more usually planned. And therefore, our technicians can be more productive. And finally, our studies show that service contracts leads to high levels of cost -- customer satisfaction, and therefore, retention. 
The globalization and harmonization of our service offering, which we undertook several years ago, led the groundwork to drive the contract business. Our marketing campaigns under the Spinnaker initiative and our field turbo investments are helping to drive this strength. Overall, we continue to make very good progress. We believe service is one of our most important competitive advantage and should continue to be an important source of sales and profit growth. 
Those are all my comments on business strength. I now want to provide some context to our acquisition of Troemner. Located in the Philadelphia area, Troemner is the U.S. market leader for weights and weight calibration and a great strategic fit to our leadership position in Europe. Together, we are now the global leader in this niche market. Weights and weight recalibration services is an attractive market. It has a strong barriers to entry as it requires very specialized know-how and expertise. We have 14 calibration labs worldwide, and the acquisition of Troemner firmly positions us as the U.S. market leader. Troemner is a very strong brand in U.S. based on its word class metrology competence and solid infrastructure. 
Service, which consists primarily of weight calibration, is almost 20% of Troemner's business and growing quite well. This is an attractive business as customers must calibrate weights on a regular basis and only a very few players have the expertise to do it correctly. This is a good example of the kind of service business that fits well into our goal of moving our service business to more contract value-added service. 
Troemner is also a provider of basic lab product such as stirrers, mixers and shakers, which will be a good strategic fit to Ohaus offering. As a reminder, Ohaus is our second brand used for indirect distribution for laboratory products of certain industrial weighing products. 
Troemner will help us strengthen the life science portfolio for Ohaus, which we have worked to expand over the last few years in terms of channel presence and product portfolio. We also believe we can further expand this equipment offering internationally, particularly in emerging markets. We think this is a great opportunity to extend the offering of Ohaus. Troemner would add about 1% to sales growth with similar margins to our own. We anticipate synergy potential from top line growth as well as potential in operational synergies. We expect to complete the acquisition shortly and have already begun integration plan. We believe this is a solid strategic acquisition and are excited about the potential development in this attractive market segment. 
That concludes our prepared remarks. We have kept our comments brief as we will see many of you tomorrow at our Investor Meeting. Let me make some summary comments before opening it up for question. 
We are very pleased with strong results in the second quarter. Our outlook for the remainder of the year is good, but we acknowledge the uncertainty in the global economy. Our focus remains on factors we can control, namely successful execution of our initiatives. We feel very good about our new product launches, field turbo investment, Spinnaker marketing initiatives and productivity measures. We believe with continued strong execution, we can continue to gain share. I want now to ask the operator to open the line for questions.

componenttext: So you're right, it was modestly easier comps so in Q1 of '15, we grew by about 8% and in Q2 of '15, we grew by about 5%. And then last quarter, we grew 5% on the 8%, so about a 13% 2-year growth, and now the 10 would imply a 15% 2-year growth and a slight, therefore, acceleration in the 2-year growth. If we look out to next quarter, the comp will be 7%, so I think our view is that lab will grow well, the 2-year growth rate will continue to be in a similar kind of range to what we have on a year-to-date basis and specifically in terms of end markets and the you mentioned, biopharma spending is good. It should continue to be good but comps do matter a bit.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, we're still where we're at, I think, plus 80 on a year-to-date basis, and that might be a little bit more than we would expect in Q3 and Q4, but still something probably north of the 50 basis points in Q3 and Q4. As we mentioned on the last
componenttext: Yes, I think, we're still where we're at, I think, plus 80 on a year-to-date basis, and that might be a little bit more than we would expect in Q3 and Q4, but still something probably north of the 50 basis points in Q3 and Q4. As we mentioned on the last call, we really just had a very tough comp vis-Ã -vis in Q1 of the year ago on our gross profit margin. It was, by far, the biggest year-on-year increase that we had all year. And so I think things kind of work themselves out on a year-to-date basis in terms of mix. And so we feel that the gross profit margin expansion that you guys have gotten used to should continue now in the second half.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Bill on behalf of Paul. I just have one question. You were kind of highlighting services and products. If you could, maybe just by either by segment or by geography kind of where you're seeing strength for each of those if there's any ano
componenttext: This is actually Bill on behalf of Paul. I just have one question. You were kind of highlighting services and products. If you could, maybe just by either by segment or by geography kind of where you're seeing strength for each of those if there's any anomalies in terms of growth or demand.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if I take it by geography, actually I was happy with the performance across the geographies. But what I would highlight as particular is that we -- in Asia, is growing very nicely. China had actually good growth now for multiple quarters in the product
componenttext: So if I take it by geography, actually I was happy with the performance across the geographies. But what I would highlight as particular is that we -- in Asia, is growing very nicely. China had actually good growth now for multiple quarters in the product range, whereas [indiscernible] the service was growing. But that's a good reflection that our initiatives have actually -- will impact and that we can drive that growth. Now I highlight over the [indiscernible] any good, of course, our penetration [indiscernible] service is higher in mature markets and I'm seeing us catching up in emerging markets. If we talk about business segment, I particular would highlight Product Inspection where service is growing very nicely over the last couple of quarters and in terms of profitability, but also strategic benefit, this is a continuing effort for us. Service is increasingly a differentiator across all the business products actually in particular. So that's where we benefited, the flavor that I would give you by region.

componenttext: This is actually Elizabeth Anderson in for Ross. componenttextpreview: So we do and we have weights. Field additions have been very project oriented in the sense that we really drill down on the different territories of the business line as where we see additional opportunities with good payback. And what we do is we monitor
componenttext: So we do and we have weights. Field additions have been very project oriented in the sense that we really drill down on the different territories of the business line as where we see additional opportunities with good payback. And what we do is we monitor actually the progress of this. So monitor, on the one hand, the implementation of it. Are we successful in recruiting, onboarding, building up the pipeline is growing. We do kind of quarterly dashboard. But then when it comes to the financial results, of course, it's a little bit more difficult to isolate but we have also dashboard behind, that's where we look at are we successfully outgrowing average where we are adequate sourcing and there's a very nice correlation between where we accelerate and have growth. So I really feel good about it. Definitely, [indiscernible] results that this is paying off. We were talking about service before. Service is also an area where we did very positive addition more sales of services dedicated service. Sales is also a service and actually you are the good results there.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just one quick follow-up. Do you have any worries about any industrial softness or purchasing delays in Europe post Brexit?
componenttext: Great. And just one quick follow-up. Do you have any worries about any industrial softness or purchasing delays in Europe post Brexit?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not really. I think, actually, overall, the industrial business is not a super end  market. I don't see, I think, get worse at all. Contrary, you could say, very gradually, things get better. And in Europe, overall, I expect the next few quarters will be
componenttext: Not really. I think, actually, overall, the industrial business is not a super end  market. I don't see, I think, get worse at all. Contrary, you could say, very gradually, things get better. And in Europe, overall, I expect the next few quarters will be reasonably good. So the whole Brexit effect, I'm not saying it's positive, but it wasn't particularly negative with one exception, U.K. itself. But we need to put it in perspective. U.K. is about the extent of our total revenue. U.K. had already some softness before Brexit and would associate some of their softness with the uncertainty and certainly after both the uncertainty of softness we will expect some further softness in U.K.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Just a first question on regional performance. On Europe, you mentioned a 4% growth that was up by Easter. If you back that out, just wondering if there was another effect there in terms of market share or something else that would have allowed you to grow faster than the actual market.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Hey, I think, it's sometimes difficult to point specifically to market share gains. I think if we look in our lab, in particular within one quarter, Isaac, but if we look at how we're performing in lab and Product Inspection, I would say those are 2 categories that we would view ourselves doing very well competitively and very well specifically in Europe. As a reminder, Europe is the place where we have the largest percentage of direct sales. And so many of our Spinnaker initiatives are often most fruitful there.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And then on the acquisition, I was just trying to put together some of the numbers you gave us. I think you mentioned 50 basis points contribution in the back half. Curious if you could give us a little sense of that number, what it assumes in terms of timing of deal close in the third quarter just so we get a sense of like the annualized impact. And then as part of that, just wondering, I don't think you mentioned how the revenues will be allocated between lab and industrial. I apologize if I missed that.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So a couple of comments on it. On an annualized basis, it led about 1% of sales. And then we're assuming it's going to close in the next couple of weeks. So -- and if that -- at 1% on an annualized basis, if we're off by a week or 2, I think. That's
componenttext: Yes. So a couple of comments on it. On an annualized basis, it led about 1% of sales. And then we're assuming it's going to close in the next couple of weeks. So -- and if that -- at 1% on an annualized basis, if we're off by a week or 2, I think. That's -- won't make a material difference. And then the nature of the business would be that the vast majority of it will be inside the lab.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually in behalf of Dan. I just wanted to take a step back just given the macro shifts that we saw, at least in terms of Brexit over the last few weeks. Can I get an update on your view of how you guys think of the structure of your business? I
componenttext: This is actually in behalf of Dan. I just wanted to take a step back just given the macro shifts that we saw, at least in terms of Brexit over the last few weeks. Can I get an update on your view of how you guys think of the structure of your business? I remember, last year when you conversations were being had as to whether or not you guys would shift some of your cost to your dollars versus Swiss francs. And just kind of want to get an update on that in light of the Brexit, whether anything's fundamentally changed or not.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So regarding Switzerland, no. The currency is actually -- didn't move particularly. It would make a difference the Swiss something that initiated with a multi-year plan, and we are progressing very well on that plan, and I'm very happy with the progress t
componenttext: So regarding Switzerland, no. The currency is actually -- didn't move particularly. It would make a difference the Swiss something that initiated with a multi-year plan, and we are progressing very well on that plan, and I'm very happy with the progress that we are making. The currency moves that took place is impacting our producing organization in U.K. As you might know, we have -- for the Product Inspection, we have product inspection, and we have method inspection of the x-ray production there, this is in essence favorable for us but will not change something to our global manufacturing strategy or our footprint. So I don't see that this will impact our strategy in any significant way.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. No fundamental change to your hedging strategies either?
componenttext: Okay. No fundamental change to your hedging strategies either?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of hedging? No.
componenttext: In terms of hedging? No.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I guess another one for me is the incremental margin in 2Q, I have it right a little bit north of 30%. Kind of in line with what we're seeing over the last few years, maybe a little bit higher Q-on-Q. I'm just surprised given the 60% organic. I know
componenttext: Okay. I guess another one for me is the incremental margin in 2Q, I have it right a little bit north of 30%. Kind of in line with what we're seeing over the last few years, maybe a little bit higher Q-on-Q. I'm just surprised given the 60% organic. I know you guys have prioritized some investments so that would be net dilutive. I just kind of want to get a sense of how you guys look at it from our margins going forward, especially in the context of kind of a 3% to 4% growth and north and south of that, where you think it can go on the incremental basis.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so maybe a little bit of clarification in terms of the incremental margin. I think, at least where we calculated it, it's 31% in -- measured in actual balance, but it's actually 34%, 35% in constant currency. So probably closer to maybe what you expe
componenttext: Yes, so maybe a little bit of clarification in terms of the incremental margin. I think, at least where we calculated it, it's 31% in -- measured in actual balance, but it's actually 34%, 35% in constant currency. So probably closer to maybe what you expected. And then what was included in there was we did have to catch up. I made a reference to incentive payment in terms of our SG&A increase. And so we did trigger some reevaluation of where we expect to finish at the end of the year to be on target. And maybe the last point would be along the lines of that we've been talking about for a while is that we do like the effectiveness to date on the field turbo program, so there's certainly some [indiscernible] with regard to our field turbo program in the quarter end. And you'll see a little bit of that going forward. In terms of our incremental margin, I continue to think that numbers in the mid, high 30s are very realistic and, frankly, absent the adjustment incentive comp in the current quarter, which won't the impact full year numbers in a material way would've been there.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Can I sneak one last one in just on China industrial? I mean you guys were relatively happy to start the year and improve in 1Q in the sense of your outlook. It seems like it modestly improves in the second quarter as well. Is that accurate, one. An
componenttext: Okay. Can I sneak one last one in just on China industrial? I mean you guys were relatively happy to start the year and improve in 1Q in the sense of your outlook. It seems like it modestly improves in the second quarter as well. Is that accurate, one. And two, do you expect this to be relatively steady here? Do you think there's a few one-offs that might provide some momentum into the close of the year?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if I look at China in total, I think, the second quarter was marginally better than the first, that was largely driven by our lab business and, in particular, perhaps with analytics within the lab business. If we look at kind of where we are, we would
componenttext: So if I look at China in total, I think, the second quarter was marginally better than the first, that was largely driven by our lab business and, in particular, perhaps with analytics within the lab business. If we look at kind of where we are, we would expect a positive second half of the year, particularly vis-Ã -vis where our expectations were when we started the year, but probably a little less than what you saw here in the most recent quarter, I think. We grew our lab business in China by close to 20% in the second quarter. And I think we don't expect that kind of growth, a little bit large order driven, and particularly in the third quarter, we're probably sitting here today, we'd estimate that maybe the fourth quarter will be marginally better.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes, I think at this stage, I think mid-single digit would probably be a pretty good guess specifically in the second quarter, we were at 9.5%, 10% and about 20% on the lab.

componenttext: And then Product Inspection, that's been a bit of a drag for a while. I think you previously mentioned you're expecting something around high single digit for the year. Can you maybe just talk about some of dynamics? What caused the decline this quarter and when do you think things turn there?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, maybe just to clarify, at least for us, we're thinking this is the first kind from a sales report, a number -- the first week number, I think it's been pretty consistent. It was 7% in the first quarter, 6% last year. It's totally in backlog build. Ac
componenttext: Yes, maybe just to clarify, at least for us, we're thinking this is the first kind from a sales report, a number -- the first week number, I think it's been pretty consistent. It was 7% in the first quarter, 6% last year. It's totally in backlog build. Actually, the quarter entry in the quarter was high single digit and we were looking for a return to high single digit or better in the third quarter. In the details of the why, if you kind of looked at what happened in the product mix, as you know, it's one of the longer lead time products that began in the portfolio, and just the mix changed a bit in the quarter where there were a lot more within that -- which is even an extra couple of weeks then. So we're very happy with how that business performed in terms of execution and continue to think that the market dynamics are good in that business, Tycho.

componenttext: Let me double check the details. So -- maybe in the second half of the year, I -- we're -- we think we'll have some growth. I'm double checking to see if there are any large DNO orders or something in the second half of last year, but I don't think so. But -- so amount of low single digit growth.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Just 2 things. Bill, the EPS guidance increased as you guys did. Is there any -- are you guys expecting any accretion in the back half here from the acquisition you've done here? And then I guess, secondly, so it's not every day that you guys do a lot of M&A, but just wondering if there was any -- you think there are other future opportunities down the road for further consolidation of smaller lab manufacturers such as this?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first part of the question, but I'll let Olivier start with the second part of your question.
componenttext: I'll take the first part of the question, but I'll let Olivier start with the second part of your question.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me -- so this is a case that fits perfectly in our franchise from a size perspective, it's equally core to us, opportunities around we actually go for them. We have a radar of possible progress. There are more of these companies that actually when
componenttext: So let me -- so this is a case that fits perfectly in our franchise from a size perspective, it's equally core to us, opportunities around we actually go for them. We have a radar of possible progress. There are more of these companies that actually when they become available. So we really pursue them and whenever they materialize, we are more than happy to close them. And we are looking at smaller ones, too. But I wouldn't -- you shouldn't look that as a new part strategy that we're pursuing. It's -- we did a couple of technology adjacencies. And this time, we had a great opportunity to acquire actually a service business. And if that pops up again, we will do so.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And with regard to -- it should add a couple of pennies, maybe up to a $0.05 in the best case scenario. And that would include us making some investment in terms of different things on the growth side, for example, in terms of some international distribut
componenttext: And with regard to -- it should add a couple of pennies, maybe up to a $0.05 in the best case scenario. And that would include us making some investment in terms of different things on the growth side, for example, in terms of some international distribution of the product.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Eastman from Robert W. Baird.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of follow-ups on the Troemner acquisition. Olivier, did they compete with you? Or is this kind of still a regional hole in your service capabilities? Is that part of the fit here?
componenttext: Just a couple of follow-ups on the Troemner acquisition. Olivier, did they compete with you? Or is this kind of still a regional hole in your service capabilities? Is that part of the fit here?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we did compete. But while in Europe, we are a market leader, in U.S., Troemner was the market leader, and we had a relatively small weight and weights calibration of business in U.S. And so it perfectly fits in our franchise. Troemner has a fantastic b
componenttext: So we did compete. But while in Europe, we are a market leader, in U.S., Troemner was the market leader, and we had a relatively small weight and weights calibration of business in U.S. And so it perfectly fits in our franchise. Troemner has a fantastic brand and competent in the U.S. that they build up over decades. That always made it difficult for Mettler-Toledo to compete. As in Europe, we have been the leader and it was difficult for Troemner to establish a presence in Europe.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I see. And did they route to market for their mixers and stirrers and some of the basic lab equipment? Did that go through Ohaus? Or how do they get to market with those products?
componenttext: I see. And did they route to market for their mixers and stirrers and some of the basic lab equipment? Did that go through Ohaus? Or how do they get to market with those products?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. So they use other indirect channels and -- but Ohaus was not a partner of them, and they have multiple brands that they're also leveraging at this current stage, and we got to maintain that. But in addition, we definitely want to leverage the Ohaus br
componenttext: No. So they use other indirect channels and -- but Ohaus was not a partner of them, and they have multiple brands that they're also leveraging at this current stage, and we got to maintain that. But in addition, we definitely want to leverage the Ohaus brand or the Ohaus franchise to expand, in particular, also in international markets where Troemner was, in particular, strong with their lab equipment business.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I see. Okay. And then, Bill, just a question. We took up '16's core growth guide from 4% previously to now more like 5%. And did you suggest earlier that 50 basis points of that increase was due to Troemner?
componenttext: I see. Okay. And then, Bill, just a question. We took up '16's core growth guide from 4% previously to now more like 5%. And did you suggest earlier that 50 basis points of that increase was due to Troemner?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct. So we raised the pure organic number by 50 bps.
componenttext: Correct. So we raised the pure organic number by 50 bps.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Despite the strength you're seeing out of Asia Pac and even the reacceleration maybe in Europe, I mean, that's -- is that a high confidence forecast that that's all that, that would contribute in the second half? I would think that's geographically,
componenttext: Okay. Despite the strength you're seeing out of Asia Pac and even the reacceleration maybe in Europe, I mean, that's -- is that a high confidence forecast that that's all that, that would contribute in the second half? I would think that's geographically, it said Asia Pac seems to be driving more upside than that.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I understand the comment. If you -- I think the comment that we've been making now over the last couple of quarters, Rick, is that given overcapacity as well as let's call it credit risk in the Chinese market, that it's worth quite a little bit of a disco
componenttext: I understand the comment. If you -- I think the comment that we've been making now over the last couple of quarters, Rick, is that given overcapacity as well as let's call it credit risk in the Chinese market, that it's worth quite a little bit of a discount on that piece of it. That would be kind of #1. And #2 would be in the details now, and I'm not counting a lot of basis points, but that we see some tougher comps in a couple of different areas. So if you look at our year-to-date number, we're plus 5% and we're saying, hey, by the end of the year, we should finish at 4.5% at the midpoint of the range and, I guess, closer to 5% at the high end of the range. So let's see how China and some of these comps play out. Biopharma has been a strong market for a while. I'd like to think that there is upside to the numbers, but we'll see as the quarter -- the second half plays out.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's great. And then just one last question, maybe for Olivier. The lab strength in China, is that somewhat traditional relative to the other geographies? In other words, is that coming out of the biopharm vertical? Or are we seeing more uptake th
componenttext: Okay, that's great. And then just one last question, maybe for Olivier. The lab strength in China, is that somewhat traditional relative to the other geographies? In other words, is that coming out of the biopharm vertical? Or are we seeing more uptake there in other labs, environmental or food and beverage? Or is it -- does the strength there by vertical kind of matchup with U.S. or Europe?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, I would say yes to both what you said. Yes, too, that generally, the lab is doing well, but I would also say, yes, that the life science and biopharma is particularly strong in China.
componenttext: Hey, I would say yes to both what you said. Yes, too, that generally, the lab is doing well, but I would also say, yes, that the life science and biopharma is particularly strong in China.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brandon Couillard from Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brandon Couillard from Jefferies.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just, Bill, circling back on China. Just give us an update kind of how you're -- what the current or latest KPI readings, how they're faring in China in general? And if you could give us the order growth rate in the period.
componenttext: Just, Bill, circling back on China. Just give us an update kind of how you're -- what the current or latest KPI readings, how they're faring in China in general? And if you could give us the order growth rate in the period.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So hey, I -- maybe on the economic stuff, I'm not sure if we're a better source than kind of what you guys read. I think it's a bit of a -- a lot of economic data globally, it's a bit of a mixed picture. Maybe one interesting insight we might give you is
componenttext: So hey, I -- maybe on the economic stuff, I'm not sure if we're a better source than kind of what you guys read. I think it's a bit of a -- a lot of economic data globally, it's a bit of a mixed picture. Maybe one interesting insight we might give you is that I know there's been some articles that some of the GDP growth has come from leveraging up further some of the state-owned enterprises and regional governments. And it was interesting for us to see when we sorted through the details of our numbers that we saw really good growth, of course, in the government sector when it came to lab. But we also saw across the board very good growth with multinationals. And that's an interesting comment in the sense that if you look over the last 3 years, the percentage of our total sales in China going to multinationals has shrunk. But now we see a nice rebound in the first half of the year across product categories, and I think that -- this famous comment that we talked about of -- for a multinational company, they can defer the replacement cycle for a while on our products, but eventually, it bounces back. And I think we see that a little bit there. It's probably a little less than the project side, but much more return to the normal replacement cycle. In terms of the order entry, order entry was similarly positive to what we saw in the sales side. So it was a solid number. It wasn't -- it's not that we -- that purely the order entry would make us cautious about the second half. It's just the realities of that, it's still a market with some instability in it, and I think us remaining cautious makes sense. But I actually felt what we just shared with you about multinational was one of the more positive readings that we had in our data coming out of China.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Helpful. And just 2 other quick steps. Could you give us the net ASP in the second quarter? How you're feeling about the second half? And then should we assume the tax rate is still 24% in the second half?
componenttext: Helpful. And just 2 other quick steps. Could you give us the net ASP in the second quarter? How you're feeling about the second half? And then should we assume the tax rate is still 24% in the second half?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So in terms of our price increases, our net realized price increases were 230 basis points up in the second quarter. And on a year-to-date basis, they're now up at 2%. We did go and look, and just to put that in a little bit of context, some of that
componenttext: Sure. So in terms of our price increases, our net realized price increases were 230 basis points up in the second quarter. And on a year-to-date basis, they're now up at 2%. We did go and look, and just to put that in a little bit of context, some of that was chasing some of the currency movements that kind of happened in the course of the earlier part of the end of the first quarter, early part of the second quarter. And so we are trying to do something in terms of mid-year prices. I would not expect the second half of the year to be worse than 2 at this point in time.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
