headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to our Third Quarter 2016 Mettler-Toledo International Earnings Conference Call. My name is Jennifer, and I will be your audio coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn our presenta
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to our Third Quarter 2016 Mettler-Toledo International Earnings Conference Call. My name is Jennifer, and I will be your audio coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn our presentation over to your host for today's call, Ms. Mary Finnegan. Please proceed, ma'am.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jennifer, and good evening, everyone. I am Mary Finnegan. I'm the Treasurer and responsible for Investor Relations at Mettler-Toledo and happy that you're joining us tonight. I'm joined by Olivier Filliol, our CEO; and Bill Donnelly, our Executive
componenttext:
Thanks, Jennifer, and good evening, everyone. I am Mary Finnegan. I'm the Treasurer and responsible for Investor Relations at Mettler-Toledo and happy that you're joining us tonight. I'm joined by Olivier Filliol, our CEO; and Bill Donnelly, our Executive Vice President.
I need to cover just a couple of administrative matters. The call is being webcast and is available for replay on our website. A copy of the press release and the presentation that we will refer to on today's call are also available on the website.
Let me summarize the safe harbor language, which we have on Page 2 of the presentation. Statements in this presentation, which are not historical facts, constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the U.S. Securities Act of 1933 and the U.S. Securities Exchange Act of 1934. These statements involve risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause our actual results, levels of activity, performance or achievements to be materially different from those expressed or implied by any forward-looking statements.
For a discussion of these risks and uncertainties, please see our Form 8-K. All of the forward-looking statements are qualified in their entirety by reference to the factors discussed under the caption Factors Affecting Our Future Operating Results and in the Management Discussion and Analysis section of our Form 10-K.
Just one last item. On today's call, we may use non-GAAP financial measures. More detailed information with respect to the use of and the differences between non-GAAP financial measures and the most directly comparable GAAP measure is provided in our Form 8-K.
I will now turn the call over to Olivier.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mary, and welcome to everyone  on the call. I will start with a summary of the quarter, and then Will will provide details on our financial results and guidance. I will then have some additional comments before we open the lines for Q&A.The h
componenttext:
Thank you, Mary, and welcome to everyone  on the call. I will start with a summary of the quarter, and then Will will provide details on our financial results and guidance. I will then have some additional comments before we open the lines for Q&A.
The highlights for the quarter are on Page 3 of the presentation. Let me start by saying it was a very good quarter and reflected strong strategy execution by our teams around the globe. Local currency sales growth was 9% in the quarter, with broad-based growth in all regions and most product lines. Demand in the Americas and Europe was very good. Asia/Rest of World did particularly well with good growth in China and strong growth in most other countries in this region. We are very happy with these results, which reflects solid market conditions and, as already mentioned, continued strong execution of our strategies. With the benefit of our margin and cost initiatives, we had good growth in margins which contributed to excellent growth in earnings per share. Cash flow was also quite good in the quarter. 
We are very happy with our performance as well our outlook for the remainder of the year and 2017.
Before I turn it over to Bill to cover the numbers, let me comment on the management changes that we announced today. Many of you have met Shawn Vadala most recently at our investor meeting in California in July. He has worked with Bill for almost 20 years and was promoted to CFO 3 years ago. Shawn is highly respected within our organization for his knowledge of our business and its processes as well as his business acumen. Shawn has been a key contributor to many of our margin enhancement programs. For example, pricing has been an important profit driver for us, and Shawn has led our efforts in pricing since the beginning. Shawn has also played an important role in helping effectively shape the resource allocations within the organization toward our strategic priorities of the faster-growing, more profitable businesses. Shawn has also worked closely with me to initiate our big data analytics program. For the next 12 months, we expect Shawn to continue to focus on his existing responsibilities, and we will gradually see him more on the Investor Relations front beginning in about a year from now.
Some of you have also met Oliver Wittorf at our investor meeting. Oliver has been with us for 13 years and has one of the most diverse careers within our management team. Oliver has held a number of important roles, including being head of operations for our Boston-based Process Analytics business. He was the project lead in China for our Blue Ocean program. And for the last few [ph] years, he has held our global supply chain team lead, which included our very successful procurement program and the establishment of our regional hubs. He will keep the supply chain responsibilities and take over daily responsibility for IT and Blue Ocean. He's ideally suited for this expanded role within the organization.
I am confident that both Shawn and Oliver have the experience and track record to be strong contributors to our executive team and to further the development of the finance, supply chain, IT and Blue Ocean functions within our organization. I have worked with both of them over many years and look forward to many more years with them in their expanded roles.
From an investor perspective, very little will change over the next 12 months, and Bill and Mary will remain your principal contacts. Bill will gradually reduce his time commitment and beginning in 2018, Bill will begin to hand over the Investor Relations activities to Shawn and into a smooth transition. Mary will continue in her role in Investor Relations and Treasury and will continue to be your day-to-day contact. 
Finally, I want to express how pleased I am that we have orchestrated a smooth and well-planned succession for Bill and that we can continue to leverage Bill's unique contribution to the company for another 2 years. Bill demonstrated his great leadership and nurturing his successes and also in working with me to make his gradual transition, which I'm very grateful for.
Let me hand it over now to Bill.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Olivier, and hello, everybody. Let me reiterate or reinforce Olivier's last point. I'm pleased about the transition that we put in place and proud that we have developed these 2 strong highly capable leaders in Shawn and Oliver. Further, happy to
componenttext:
Thanks, Olivier, and hello, everybody. Let me reiterate or reinforce Olivier's last point. I'm pleased about the transition that we put in place and proud that we have developed these 2 strong highly capable leaders in Shawn and Oliver. Further, happy to continue to serve this great company and help drive its development for the coming 2 years. And of course, I also look forward to working with all of you.
Now let me come back to the quarter and cover the financials. Sales were $650.6 million in the quarter. That's an increase in 9% in local currency. The Troemner acquisition contributed about 1% to that growth. And on dollar basis, our sales grew by 8% as currencies reduced sales by about 1% in the quarter. 
On Slide #4, you have local currency sales growth for the third quarter. Our sales grew 7% in the Americas, 8% in Europe and 11% in Asia/Rest of World. Americas growth excluding Troemner was about 6%. 
In the next slide, we provide year-to-date local currency sales growth, which was 6%. By region, Americas had a growth of 7%, Europe is 4% and Asia/Rest of World has increased 8% on a year-to-date basis.
Now on to Slide #6. We outlined sales growth by product area for the quarter. Lab had good growth with local currency sales growth of 9%, of which approximately 2% was from Troemner. Industrial increased by 8%, and food retail increased by 13%. All these comparisons are versus the prior year. 
The next slide summarizes year-to-date sales by product line. Lab had local currency sales growth of 8%; industrial, 5%; and food retailing, 6%. 
Now to Slide #8. Let me walk you through the key items in our P&L for the quarter. Our gross margins were 56.8%. That's a 60 basis point improvement over the prior year amount of 56.2%. Pricing and material costs decreased as pricing increases and material cost decreases contributed to the improved margin, which was offset in part by some targeted investments in our service business as well as an unfavorable mix.
R&D amounted to $30.1 million. That's a 6% increase in local currency. SG&A amounted to $187.7 million. That's an increase of 8% in local currency over the prior year. Higher variable comp largely explained by assumed higher performance against our budget targets as well as investments in our field turbo program were offset by cost savings in other parts of the business. 
Adjusted operating income was $151.7 million in the quarter. That's a 13% increase over the prior year amount of $134.3 million. Currencies benefited operating profit by $1.5 million. And yes, that was not a typo. We had a currency benefit this quarter. The first one in sometime. Adjusted operating margins were 23.3%. That's 110 basis point increase over the prior year. 
A couple of comments to the P&L. Our amortization was $9.1 million, while our interest expense was $7.2 million. Our effective tax rate continue to be 24%. Our fully diluted shares for the quarter were 26.9 million. That's a 4.4% decline from the prior year, reflecting the impact of our share repurchase program. Adjusted earnings per share was $3.89 per share, a 19% increase over the prior year amount of $3.26 per share. On a reported basis, earnings per share was $3.77 as compared to $3.16 in the prior year. Reported EPS includes $0.04 of restructuring, $0.05 of purchased intangible asset amortization and $0.03 of acquisition transaction costs related to Troemner.
The next slide shows the year-to-date P&L. We have local currency sales growth of 6%. Operating income increased by 9%, and adjusted earnings per share increased by 15%.
Now taking a look at cash flow. In the quarter, free cash flow amounted to $125.6 million as compared to $107.1 million in the prior year. We remain pleased with working capital management and achieved further improvements in DSO. ITO was 4.6, which was flat with last quarter. Cash flow on a year-to-date basis amounted to $263.7 million. That's an increase of 16% on a per share basis. For the year, we expect free cash flow in the $380 million range.
Now let's turn to guidance. We're raising our full year 2016 local currency sales guidance to approximately 6% versus 5% previously. This reflects organic growth of approximately 5.5% and about 50 basis points of sales growth from the Troemner acquisition. We have also raised our earnings per share guidance and now expect adjusted EPS to be in the range of $14.61 per share to $14.66 per share. That's a growth of approximately 13%. This compares to our previous guidance of 11% to 12% growth or $4.40 to $4.50 per share.
With respect to the fourth quarter, we expect local currency sales growth to be approximately 5%. This includes approximately 1% growth from Troemner. We assume adjusted EPS will be in the range of $5.80 to $5.13. This reflects a growth rate of 9% to 10%.
Now let's turn to 2017. We're coming off a very strong third quarter, and we have expectations for a solid Q4 as well. We believe we are executing well. We have a strong product pipeline. Our Spinnaker sales and marketing programs as well as our field turbo investments are yielding tangible results. These factors are within our control, and we feel confident about them. Offsetting these positives are some lingering questions regarding global economy. In particular, we see continued risk in China, some uncertainty in Europe, and we will face tougher comps, for example, in our lab business as well as the Americas.
Taking account these factors, we expect local currency sales growth to be about 5% in 2017. This will include 50 basis points from the Troemner acquisition. This will -- should result in adjusted EPS in the range of $16.05 to $16.25 per share, and that's a growth rate of 10% to 11%. We expect currency to reduce adjusted EPS growth by about 1% in 2017. 
In terms of quarterly guidance for 2017, as usual, we'll provide that on our upcoming calls. However, I know you'll be updating our model, and I just want to point out that we will have a tough comp in Q3 next year, given the very strong results that we are reporting today.
In terms of currency impact on sales growth, we expect currency to reduce sales by about 1.5% in the fourth quarter. This will result in a 2% impact on sales growth for the full year 2016. And in 2017, currency should reduce sales by about 1.5%. 
Finally, in terms of cash flow next year, we expect free cash flow to be in the $390 million range. This reflects a 6% growth on a per share basis, which is below our normal target and has to do with higher capital expenditures. As we explained last year, our CapEx levels in '16 and '17 are higher due to facility expansions related to our product inspection businesses as well as the facility consolidation we're doing in Switzerland. These expansions will amount to approximately $55 million in 2017. We built into our assumptions $500 million of share repurchases next year, which is the same amount as we did this year.
Okay. That's it for my side, and then I want to take it back to Olivier.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Let me start with summary comment on business conditions. Lab had a very good growth in the quarter. All product lines performed well. Our strong product pipeline benefit of improved investments continued strong sales and marketing programs
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Let me start with summary comment on business conditions. Lab had a very good growth in the quarter. All product lines performed well. Our strong product pipeline benefit of improved investments continued strong sales and marketing programs are all contributing to favorable results. Spending by our bio pharma customers continues to be favorable. While government and academia was not strong in the west, it's not a big segment for us. Industrial was strong and unexpected in the quarter, including core industrial, which increased mid-single digits. Core industrial was particularly strong in Asia/Rest of World but was up in China as well. In the Americas and Europe, we benefited from some projects in transportation and logistics, but the core industrial markets remained difficult. 
Product Inspection was up strongly in the quarter, with particularly good growth in Americas and Europe. We continue to penetrate large multinational food companies as the supply of choice as they seek to standardize the Product Inspection equipment. We have made some good inroads over the last 12 to 24 months, and we expect good results in the fourth quarter as well as. 
Finally, retail increased 13% in the quarter, much better than we had expected as our projects moved forward for Q4. We had good growth in all regions. We would expect retail to be down in the fourth quarter.
Now let me make some additional comments by geography. Sales growth in the Americas continues to be very solid. Bio pharma and food were our strongest segments. Lab had growth against strong comparisons in the prior year. Product Inspection retail did very well in the quarter with a number of large projects. Core industrial also had growth and benefited from some project activity in transportation and logistics, but as expected, many industrial segments remain weak. 
Europe's growth exceeded expectation. Similar to the U.S., biopharma and food were good segments. Lab and Product Inspection benefited from these trends. Core industrial benefited from some transport -- transportation and logistics activities but similar to the U.S., many industrial segments were weak. Finally, retail also has very good growth and as was already mentioned, was partially due to some projects moving from Q4 to Q3.
Asia/Rest of World grew double digits in the quarter. Last growth in China was again in double digits, with almost all product lines showing very good growth. We continue to be very pleased with this performance, which reflects good demand, particularly in life sciences as well as the benefit of our actions to redirect resources to faster growing market segments. Industrial in China had modest growth as we continue to be impacted by the overcapacity in the industrial manufacturing sector. We're seeing good growth in certain industrial markets such as chemical pharma and OEM, but this is being overshadowed by weakness in markets such as cement and metals. 
One final comment on the business. Service grew 6% in the quarter. 
Those are all my comments on current business trends. Now let me provide a broader update on our strategy and how it continues to evolve and positions us well for the next year and beyond.
Let me start with our sales and marketing strategy. At our Investor Day in July, we discussed one of our new initiatives in this area, and that is our efforts to generate lead and better focus our sales efforts by leveraging data. Our data sources include our compact database, our installed base of instruments, hits on NT.com and increasingly rich data streams from Blue Ocean as well as some third-party data. We are becoming more sophisticated in how we use this data to target incremental growth. We are in the early stages of developing the potential big data that we already see opportunities our current strategy and identify new sources of growth and sales productivity.
As shared at the Investor Day, we are using big data to help us identify where customers are investing, account locations that need more focus on cross-selling and the likely effective means to succeed. We also recently launched Spinnaker 5, which is focused on increased sales productivity. The tools from Spinnaker 5 are being used to help units, refine the channel strategy, more effectively balance the resources between field and inside sales and achieve better results in account penetration and cross-selling.
Finally, we have started our next wave of field turbo and expect to add 200 additional field resources in 2017. We believe the first waves of this field turbo program have been effective in helping us gain share.
We talk to you a lot about sales and marketing but, our share gains will not be possible without an excellent product pipeline. It continues to be very strong, particular on the lab and Product Inspection side. Let me give you one example from our waning Pipette business. As a reminder, we have proprietary pipettes with superior economic design and which each have an embedded chip for tracking. The team is now launching smart step, an easy to use pipette asset management system. This instrument can store up to 4 pipettes and read the embedded RFID chip to immediately determine if the pipette is within the required calibration specification. For regulated labs in the pharma biotech industries, this is a major support tool that eliminates the time-consuming process of tracking calibration dates to verify the pipette is proper to use. Our pipette has long been known for the ability to provide reproducible data. Smartphones further helps our customers to ensure this data was generated on a verified pipette. We believe it will help drive our service business as well as lab conversion as more researchers seek to benefit from our RFID-enabled pipette. This is one on many new product launch that we presented of how we continue to drive value of our customers.
As you can see, we have much underway in terms of targeting top line growth. We also continue to make very good progress on our margin initiatives. Our pricing, productivity and supply chain initiatives continue to evolve and yield tangible results. There is a lot of work behind all of this, particularly in an organization as ours that has so many complexities. With continued diligence, we can move these initiatives to the next level.
That concludes our prepared remarks. In summary, we believe we are executing well, and market conditions are good enough for our customers to keep their replacement cycle. With the benefit of our growth initiatives, we believe we are continuing to gain share and continue to improve our margin. Assuming demand in our markets remain stable, we expect to continue to generate good sales and earnings growth.
I want to now ask the operator to open the line for questions.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Tim Evans with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Tim Evans with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the strength in industrial, it sounded like the growth there was driven primarily or the surprise, I should say, was driven primarily by a couple of transportation and logistics items. If you strip those out, would the underlying growth that's kind of
componenttext: On the strength in industrial, it sounded like the growth there was driven primarily or the surprise, I should say, was driven primarily by a couple of transportation and logistics items. If you strip those out, would the underlying growth that's kind of been the low single digit territory where it's been running? And secondarily, I was wondering of those 2 projects were pulled forward from Q4.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So maybe -- so first, for our industrial business in total, the key good performer was actually Product Inspection. Product Inspection grew by low double digits in the quarter. We did do mid-single-digit kind of growth in our what we will refer to as our
componenttext: So maybe -- so first, for our industrial business in total, the key good performer was actually Product Inspection. Product Inspection grew by low double digits in the quarter. We did do mid-single-digit kind of growth in our what we will refer to as our core industrial business. That business would have been maybe -- trying to do the math here, maybe 1.5 points less without the T&L projects. The T&L projects maybe weren't as close on our radar screens and frankly, they're a little bit smaller. The retail projects did move from Q4 into Q3, and that's the one that was in line with that reference coming little earlier than expected. The T&L project largely came in maybe a total of little better than we expected but wasn't so much different than we expected from a timing point of view.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Eastman with Robert W Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Eastman with Robert W Baird.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick things. Could you just dig into pricing here a little bit, not just on this quarter but also what kind of price did we trend line price out into '17 when you talked about guidance?
componenttext: A couple of quick things. Could you just dig into pricing here a little bit, not just on this quarter but also what kind of price did we trend line price out into '17 when you talked about guidance?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we did. We ran a couple of different scenarios. So I think the good news on pricing is that the tools we have, the strategies we have, the products we get to apply pricing to continue to get better but it is a lower inflation environment globally. Th
componenttext: Yes, we did. We ran a couple of different scenarios. So I think the good news on pricing is that the tools we have, the strategies we have, the products we get to apply pricing to continue to get better but it is a lower inflation environment globally. That represents some different challenges. So I think kind of a baseline level, I could imagine we may be only do 150 bps next year, but I also see some upside in terms of Shawn and the team are putting together some new things in the area, for example, of services where I think we had some opportunity and also reaching out to some other countries. So I hope that there's a little bit upside to that number, too.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I also just had a question. Olivier, when you talked about the 5% growth for '17, would you just kind of handicap the risk to that number, either geographically or by product segments? I'm curious where might you see the biggest risk and co
componenttext: Okay. And then I also just had a question. Olivier, when you talked about the 5% growth for '17, would you just kind of handicap the risk to that number, either geographically or by product segments? I'm curious where might you see the biggest risk and conversely, maybe the 1 area or 2 areas where you see the best possibility of upside.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of risk, if I look to Asia, in particular China and how will industry do in China, that's rather difficult to predict. As we described before, for industry China, their segments do well, chemical food, difficult. But for costing and anticipating
componenttext: In terms of risk, if I look to Asia, in particular China and how will industry do in China, that's rather difficult to predict. As we described before, for industry China, their segments do well, chemical food, difficult. But for costing and anticipating how the Chinese economy do overall is difficult. Our industrial business is particularly exposed to the cycles in China. And of course, we have also comparison topics. We have, for example, a very strong performance in biopharma, and highlights including also in Europe, and we're going to feel that next year. How will this evolve is, in that sense, has certain risks to it. Now on the upside, I would say China industry could actually clearly come strongly and expected. As I mentioned before, there is a high volatility on that front. So that's one. If biopharma continues to be that strong, we would benefit across many businesses. That would be really nice. And then there is a certain pent-up demand that we had always seen when overall economy strengthen and pent-up demand in CapEx where industrial would benefit. So that's another upside that I could see.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one last question, just kind of open ended question here. I think, Olivier, I think you and Bill if I'm not mistaken, kind of do your annual budget global tour of your regions in September-October period and I'm just curious if there's
componenttext: Okay. And then just one last question, just kind of open ended question here. I think, Olivier, I think you and Bill if I'm not mistaken, kind of do your annual budget global tour of your regions in September-October period and I'm just curious if there's any next-level observations, either politically or from a business perspective, that if I'm right on timing of your tour that you brought back with you from, in particular, China.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Particular China. Actually...
componenttext: Particular China. Actually...

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the one thing the guys told us about is at the beginning of next year, the Chinese [indiscernible] will do their changes. The 2 top guys will stay in place. If we look back at that historically, this has typically been a time where you maybe see a
componenttext: I think the one thing the guys told us about is at the beginning of next year, the Chinese [indiscernible] will do their changes. The 2 top guys will stay in place. If we look back at that historically, this has typically been a time where you maybe see a little bit of like people kind of wait and see, but the guys are a little bit more optimistic this year because with the 2 top guys staying in place and a lot of people frankly worried about the Chinese economy that there'll be more emphasis to kind of keep growing. And so I don't think the 5-year plan's in place, and I think it's just their optimistic that we won't see kind of a slow down there.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, in that context, we -- the change takes place early in the year, and everybody feels like by Chinese New Year, the uncertainty should be gone. This is different to past changes, and past changes where really the whole team. At this time, it's fe
componenttext: Actually, in that context, we -- the change takes place early in the year, and everybody feels like by Chinese New Year, the uncertainty should be gone. This is different to past changes, and past changes where really the whole team. At this time, it's few people that will retire age-wise, and so there is continue political leadership. One other highlight that we saw during this business review in China was our strengthening positioning in lab and in particular, actually pipette and pH. I was very pleased to hear that we are kind of winning marked position becoming leaders in pipette and pH in China, which is typically takes a couple of years and is very attractive because, of course, our businesses with great profitability, great consumable stream. So this is our examples. We had certainly many more from other countries, too. One that, for example, just to share. In India, we are so pleased to see how growth goes there. We talked a lot about made in India how this is helping. I mentioned that a little bit because for us, we always depend also that the industrial manufacturing is important and drives quality and drives to export industry and that's, for example, something that I could feel very strongly when I met the Indian team. We see it I want to say next year they are moving to a tax structure. And that puts, in the short term, impact our EBITDA  numbers. So every calendar has something specific, and it was good to sense it. All in all, we came back from the 2 in a very positive way. Extremely pleased by the plan, but also I'd I think a little bit economic and the government environment, we feel good about that.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ross Muken with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ross Muken with Evercore ISI.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm curious on the biopharma side, whether by any of the sort of distinct customer subsegments you saw notable sort of changes in demand or whether there was any bias between higher-priced instrumentation, lower-priced instrumentation, because we've defin
componenttext: I'm curious on the biopharma side, whether by any of the sort of distinct customer subsegments you saw notable sort of changes in demand or whether there was any bias between higher-priced instrumentation, lower-priced instrumentation, because we've definitely seen some choppiness from maybe not peers but others who address the customer base just trying to discern if it was a price point question or really it's sort of maybe more specific to certain subsegments.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's actually really broad-based. And important to say, it's certainly not particular the big pharma we even saw Q1 in big pharma that slowed down some of their purchasing due to internal things like new procurement initiatives and so on. Now it w
componenttext: Well, that's actually really broad-based. And important to say, it's certainly not particular the big pharma we even saw Q1 in big pharma that slowed down some of their purchasing due to internal things like new procurement initiatives and so on. Now it was, in essence, broad-based. We see a good activities with CMOs. We see good activities with CPOs, and we have many businesses that serve this market. So from production to research, we benefited. And I didn't see any particular part between the more sophisticated, more valued instruments. It was broad-based.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. And Bill, just quickly on the tax line for next year, I would have thought you guys -- maybe you mentioned it. I missed it but a little bit of a benefit from the stock shield. I'm just curious what the assumption is there.
componenttext: Excellent. And Bill, just quickly on the tax line for next year, I would have thought you guys -- maybe you mentioned it. I missed it but a little bit of a benefit from the stock shield. I'm just curious what the assumption is there.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we assumed a 24% rate now. We're kind of working through the models. As you guys know we're -- we've been kind of hit in this 24% tax rate for a while but running a cash tax rate lower than that, in part explained by stock options. So I -- we're going
componenttext: So we assumed a 24% rate now. We're kind of working through the models. As you guys know we're -- we've been kind of hit in this 24% tax rate for a while but running a cash tax rate lower than that, in part explained by stock options. So I -- we're going to go through and see what the accountants -- where we come out, but I would assume that that could benefit us a couple of percentage points when things get final. I think -- I'm not sure how much you studied it yourself, Ross, but one of the things that they think is awkward about it is it's going to mean people could have quite different tax rates by quarter. So one of the things we're dealing with is we could maybe estimate what the full year impact was, but the nature of it would make our tax rate jump around quite a bit in the quarters. And I think it will take an increased level of investor communication to predict that and in part, that's why I think we'll wait until maybe February to elaborate on what it will precisely mean for us. But you're right. It's positive.

componenttext: I want to spend a minute on Europe. Just you had a big quarter there, and I know you called out the pull-forward effect in the retail business. Hoping you could maybe quantify how much that contributed to the local currency growth. And wondering if maybe there was secondary effects where maybe your market share gains that you referenced concentrated in the region and that also helped. Just trying to reconcile the fact you grew so well there versus what we're seeing everywhere else.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We will talk about the quarter effect. Let me just say, overall, it was a great quarter for Europe. And lab and Product Inspection was particularly strong, really. And also for Q4, in general, good but we will have declines in retail but, for example, Pro
componenttext: We will talk about the quarter effect. Let me just say, overall, it was a great quarter for Europe. And lab and Product Inspection was particularly strong, really. And also for Q4, in general, good but we will have declines in retail but, for example, Product Inspection that did very well in Q3 will continue to do well in Q4. So maybe Bill, just on the effect between the 2 quarters.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So our retail business in Europe was up -- sorry, I lost my slide -- was up about 14%. And I think it will be down probably double digits in the fourth quarter, so it's just kind of a timing topic. As you know, our retail business at the gross and operati
componenttext: So our retail business in Europe was up -- sorry, I lost my slide -- was up about 14%. And I think it will be down probably double digits in the fourth quarter, so it's just kind of a timing topic. As you know, our retail business at the gross and operating margin line is a little less than the other businesses, so not such a material impact in terms of operating margin and profitability flow-through. But yes, timing wise, that was the impact.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just a clarification question on China. Appreciate your comments on the political drop backdrop. Just want to clarify if that's the reason when you guys kind of called out the potential for little risk next year in that region as opposed
componenttext: Got it. And then just a clarification question on China. Appreciate your comments on the political drop backdrop. Just want to clarify if that's the reason when you guys kind of called out the potential for little risk next year in that region as opposed to any fundamental changes in key end markets. Just want to make sure I understood the sources of risk that you guys are keeping an eye on.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say on China, we have seen that predicting China is a little bit more difficult. And I think we -- particularly for the industrial business. And it's difficult to say when certain industry will pick up again and start to really invest in capacity
componenttext: I would say on China, we have seen that predicting China is a little bit more difficult. And I think we -- particularly for the industrial business. And it's difficult to say when certain industry will pick up again and start to really invest in capacity expansion and all these things, and it could also turn in the other direction. So we are cautious about -- particularly, the industrial business. On the lab business, I feel much more comfortable that we will have steady growth.

componenttext: 40 basis points, 45 basis points, something in that range up to 50, depending on how currency plays out and also, of course, the comments on our pricing initiatives as well, whether we do a little bit better than 150 bps.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And the -- at your Analyst Day, you mentioned and you just mentioned  on the call here, your initiatives to sort of target and discover where your installed base is and targeting upgrades replacements and that. I guess how far in that initiative ar
componenttext: Great. And the -- at your Analyst Day, you mentioned and you just mentioned  on the call here, your initiatives to sort of target and discover where your installed base is and targeting upgrades replacements and that. I guess how far in that initiative are you? And I guess when we really start seeing some incremental benefits of that? And the question is how much of your install base you think is amenable to that sort of activity?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we have 2 big data initiatives that we talked about at the Investor Day. One was this old product replacement initiatives where we have today a very good transparency on all our products installed around the world, and we data mined this and associate
componenttext: So we have 2 big data initiatives that we talked about at the Investor Day. One was this old product replacement initiatives where we have today a very good transparency on all our products installed around the world, and we data mined this and associate specific marketing program to bring these products, either under the service contract or upgrade replace the product. And this is ongoing and in that sense, we have already benefit, but it's a long journey. This is -- the installed base is so huge and of course, customers don't instantly replace it just because we send the marketing materials or we sent over a salesperson with a dedicated value proposition. So I see that as one of many initiatives that we have that help us drive further growth. We see already the benefits. It will continue to benefit us for many more years. And the same is true actually for the second initiatives where we generate sales force targets based on big data analytics. This is something we started to pilot early in the year, and we have been scaling it up in Q2. We start to see the benefits, but we have many more years to go until we see saturation in the upside of that.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Great. And then just one other clarification. For '17, what's embedded in terms of the interest income expense line?

componenttext: Can you maybe talk on expectations by segment for '17, what's embedded in the guidance for each of the divisions? And then, can you quantify what you're expecting for growth in China as well?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So let me start with the product areas. I think something in the mid-single digits for the lab business makes sense, 5%, 6%. I can use now the midpoint of our overall range. In terms of our industrial business, something in the 5% range as well, mid
componenttext: Sure. So let me start with the product areas. I think something in the mid-single digits for the lab business makes sense, 5%, 6%. I can use now the midpoint of our overall range. In terms of our industrial business, something in the 5% range as well, mid-single digits. But maybe the mix in there would be our Product Inspection business growing faster than our core industrial business and then flatter maybe low single-digit growth in retail get you to the overall picture. And then if you look at it geographically, we're thinking Europe could be low to mid, depending on best case, worst case. The Americas, probably mid-single digits. And then both Asia and China, overall, we think mid-single digits probably anyway, could be in the high single digits.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And can you comment on linearity in the quarter? I know you had a question before about your global tour. But I'm actually just wondering how things progress throughout the quarter and any commentary on October, in particular, if things were off tre
componenttext: Okay. And can you comment on linearity in the quarter? I know you had a question before about your global tour. But I'm actually just wondering how things progress throughout the quarter and any commentary on October, in particular, if things were off trend relative to what you saw in 3Q [ph].

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean we finished with good order entry, which would be an early indicator for us in terms of September. I think the combination of October and November, which is the we have the most visibility on remains pretty solid. I think, as you know, Tyco, many o
componenttext: I mean we finished with good order entry, which would be an early indicator for us in terms of September. I think the combination of October and November, which is the we have the most visibility on remains pretty solid. I think, as you know, Tyco, many of us in the peer group have a certain amount of budget flush. We think we made a reasonable assumption in terms of it being a typical year with budget flush, but December is always the hardest one to predict. Things just come that you didn't have on your radar at all, and you just hope you got at least as many as last year.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly on food retail, I know you talked about that being down in 4Q but just visibility on kind of orders there. I mean are there bigger tenders coming through? Obviously, you saw some pull forward in Q2. Just wondering what the outlook on that...

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you're okay, I think you might have a little bit. It tends to be at the -- after Thanksgiving and people tend to avoid in the holiday season doing -- delivering on big projects, but there's a lot of work done by our customers in terms of thinking about
componenttext: If you're okay, I think you might have a little bit. It tends to be at the -- after Thanksgiving and people tend to avoid in the holiday season doing -- delivering on big projects, but there's a lot of work done by our customers in terms of thinking about the next year. So maybe when we see or when we talk again in February we have a bigger better way to answer that. At this point, there are a number of big jobs and that are in place, but the way those work out what percentage of the big job you get, you won't know for a little while, much less the timing on it.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Dan Arias with Citigroup.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, you touched on service. Do you think service growth outstrips product growth again next year? And if so, how, why do you sort of envision that spread for the time being?
componenttext: Bill, you touched on service. Do you think service growth outstrips product growth again next year? And if so, how, why do you sort of envision that spread for the time being?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, this is our strategy. We feel like we can grow service. We want to grow service more than the product growth. And yes, this is part of our plan for next year. If we grow as we guide you, this should actually be possible. We have very good progra
componenttext: Actually, this is our strategy. We feel like we can grow service. We want to grow service more than the product growth. And yes, this is part of our plan for next year. If we grow as we guide you, this should actually be possible. We have very good programs in place, and we have seen actually different regions with very strong growth year-to-date in service. I would highlight, for example, Asia. So yes, I have that expectation for next year.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe just on the margin opportunity next year, if you look at indirect spend, which is something you guys have been targeting, how much of what you see there in percentage terms is what you might call effectively managed or sort of where y
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe just on the margin opportunity next year, if you look at indirect spend, which is something you guys have been targeting, how much of what you see there in percentage terms is what you might call effectively managed or sort of where you want it versus what's still open for improvement? And do you think that can be a meaningful source of savings next year as we look to 2017?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So our indirect spend number is actually the base of it, so number in excess of our material spend or direct material spend. I think it's the amount we have under control is in the $500 million range. We have -- or sorry, the amount of it is in the
componenttext: Sure. So our indirect spend number is actually the base of it, so number in excess of our material spend or direct material spend. I think it's the amount we have under control is in the $500 million range. We have -- or sorry, the amount of it is in the $500 million range, and I think we have more than 50% now being under what we refer to as category management, so I think that number will climb a little bit. But I think the way we look at that is we're always trying to come up with new programs that can drive further savings in there. I think, we, this year will save a number in the high single-digit million Lab range, and I think we should be able to deliver a number in that range again next year.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext:
I'll have to say it's a sad day to get the press release that you're leaving, although I've been talking to a few clients say you guys [indiscernible] the quarter and leave yourself 2 years for the transition, so I appreciate that.
I guess just a couple of follow-ups here. Around the quarter itself, it looks like maybe about [ph] $0.05 in the quarter, you didn't pass on to the full year. Is that just conservatism? Is that some of the pull forward? Maybe talk a little bit about that.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. A little bit the movement on the retail is probably the retail project is probably the biggest piece. I think Mary told me currency got worse by a $0.01 or $0.02, I think, as well.
componenttext: Yes. A little bit the movement on the retail is probably the retail project is probably the biggest piece. I think Mary told me currency got worse by a $0.01 or $0.02, I think, as well.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the field turbo update, I mean you had 200 people in '17. Any particular geography or customer segmentation standout in terms of where those are going?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the field turbo update, I mean you had 200 people in '17. Any particular geography or customer segmentation standout in terms of where those are going?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It gets quite some attention. We will add a couple of people. For example, for our Automated Chemistry business that we presented to you also in July. We are adding a couple of people for our pH lab business that have high profitability. And from a geogra
componenttext: It gets quite some attention. We will add a couple of people. For example, for our Automated Chemistry business that we presented to you also in July. We are adding a couple of people for our pH lab business that have high profitability. And from a geographic standpoint, we have put some Southeast Asia where we're adding again quite a significant number of people in the context of building up Philippines, Indonesia. That is relatively broad-based. It's presented today to the board in the annual plan where we're adding a tool that we had a geographic it is nice to see how well spread it is, and that's actually the strength of the program that we are working on many projects in parallel, and you have many managers that are also supervising and managing these.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Beuchaw with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Beuchaw with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to ask just one question, but it's a three-parter so limiting myself to just one. Basic topic is are there any items you might want to flag in terms of the progression over the next year or so from quarter-to-quarter. Specifically, I'm wondering
componenttext: I'm going to ask just one question, but it's a three-parter so limiting myself to just one. Basic topic is are there any items you might want to flag in terms of the progression over the next year or so from quarter-to-quarter. Specifically, I'm wondering and, I guess, follow-up to Tim's questions or any impact from timing items in the third quarter that might actually impact 2017, given you mentioned some of those are actually items that were further out. The second piece would be selling days. Any selling days either actually in the third quarter or looking forward. And then the third part of my three-parter is anything next year aside from the tough comp that we should consider as we think about the progression of incremental margins.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Good questions. I have answers to at least some of them. Let me start with those, and I have Mary flipping me some lines as well as Shawn. So progression for quarter-to-quarter, I think we kind of mentioned in the conference call script that I think
componenttext: Okay. Good questions. I have answers to at least some of them. Let me start with those, and I have Mary flipping me some lines as well as Shawn. So progression for quarter-to-quarter, I think we kind of mentioned in the conference call script that I think Q3 has got to be a tough comp a year from now. I think you can kind of play it out that way. Not all of it will -- if you look at incremental margins, it won't be as big of an issue there because of the high retail content. You can also assume that we get about 1% or so of sales growth from Troemner in the first 2 quarters, and that stops in Q3 and Q4. In terms of working days, I think the -- it's flat in Q3 of this year, and Q4 is minus 2 working days. And for 2017, I think there's, hey, a day difference that we have to stay more in Q1 of '17, and we catch it back up in Q2, and then it looks like there's one last day in Q3. But I don't think those should be so material. In terms of other things to think about, I can't think another one might be kind of timing of some of our Blue Ocean go-lives. I -- those don't jump out to me right now in terms of being particularly large units. So I think that, that shouldn't be so much of an issue. Hey, I -- yes, I think all of us are kind of nodding that those would be the key items. I think the one other item would be in response to like a follow-up to make sure it resonated with people. Ross asked earlier about this new accounting regulations surrounding accounting for the income tax benefits of stock options in excess of the value. I think that we're working on trying to estimate that impact now for the full year, but I do think the way the accounting rules are written, it will lead to quite a bit of volatility by quarter, and that's something that I think we're going to almost have to guide you quarter-by-quarter at this stage. And so I would maybe suggest people just leave it a typical Mettler flat 24 for now, and that's what we've given you in terms of guidance, but it will probably be an improved number when we talk to you in February, but we're still estimating what that will be. Did I get all the parts to your question, Steve?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry. And the impact of timing items in the third quarter on revenues in the first half. It sounded like some of the timing in the third quarter impacted evidence that you actually thought was further out.
componenttext: Sorry. And the impact of timing items in the third quarter on revenues in the first half. It sounded like some of the timing in the third quarter impacted evidence that you actually thought was further out.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's mostly a retail topic, and it's mostly -- will work itself out Q3 to Q4. So at this stage, I don't see anything, but we'll let you know. I don't see anything happening in the fourth quarter that would push things out to Q1 in particular.
componenttext: I think it's mostly a retail topic, and it's mostly -- will work itself out Q3 to Q4. So at this stage, I don't see anything, but we'll let you know. I don't see anything happening in the fourth quarter that would push things out to Q1 in particular.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Couillard with Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Couillard with Jefferies.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, you may have just answered my question in the context of the number of days in the fourth quarter. But even if we strip out the pull forward of the food retail surge in the third quarter, on the 2-, 3-, 4-year stock comp basis, you still accelerated
componenttext: Bill, you may have just answered my question in the context of the number of days in the fourth quarter. But even if we strip out the pull forward of the food retail surge in the third quarter, on the 2-, 3-, 4-year stock comp basis, you still accelerated on each of those metrics pretty materially in the third quarter, which your guidance seems to suggest a step backward in the fourth. Is that simply the days effect?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Hey, I think if you look kind of the impact of the retail moving between the 2 quarters is 2%. So if you kind of start by reconciling, we grew 9, 8 organically, you kind of get 2 points off to compare the 2 quarters, and then there's a point or 1.5 p
componenttext: Yes. Hey, I think if you look kind of the impact of the retail moving between the 2 quarters is 2%. So if you kind of start by reconciling, we grew 9, 8 organically, you kind of get 2 points off to compare the 2 quarters, and then there's a point or 1.5 points left, and some of that could be working days. Some of it is just the forecast of how we see things. Some of it might be we're just underestimating budget flush. I think I would acknowledge that it's the -- it's the quarter for us that we find most difficult to forecast Brendan. But we have done the same stack analysis you did along with the series of other internal forecasting measures to kind of come up with this number, and we think it's realistic but, I guess, we'll see when the numbers come through.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then 2 more. Did you actually give the China growth rate in the third quarter? And then secondly, you pointed to, I think, a 1% headwind on EPS next year from currency. Does that include the hedge roll-off effect?
componenttext: Okay. And then 2 more. Did you actually give the China growth rate in the third quarter? And then secondly, you pointed to, I think, a 1% headwind on EPS next year from currency. Does that include the hedge roll-off effect?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that includes the hedge roll-off effect, and our growth in China in the quarter was 8%, and it's 8% for the full year-to-date.
componenttext: Yes, that includes the hedge roll-off effect, and our growth in China in the quarter was 8%, and it's 8% for the full year-to-date.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Steve Willoughby with Cleveland Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Steve Willoughby with Cleveland Research.

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two quick things for you. I wonder if you could comment about what you're seeing in the U.K. in the last few months post-Brexit. And then secondly, just on field turbo, now that you're in the third wave of adding people if you could provide any color on h
componenttext: Two quick things for you. I wonder if you could comment about what you're seeing in the U.K. in the last few months post-Brexit. And then secondly, just on field turbo, now that you're in the third wave of adding people if you could provide any color on how quickly these headcount additions are ramping up and how quickly they basically start paying for themselves?

headline: Mettler-Toledo International Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the first one, so just to put in perspective, the U.K. is about 3% of our revenue. And yes, our business has slowed down, and it certainly also is associated with the Brexit discussions that we have.  Of course, our customer base is faced with uncertai
componenttext: On the first one, so just to put in perspective, the U.K. is about 3% of our revenue. And yes, our business has slowed down, and it certainly also is associated with the Brexit discussions that we have.  Of course, our customer base is faced with uncertainty, and we see it in our business. What we also that we have significant price increases that we implemented in the U.K. to offset, of course, the weakening of the pound. Now just talking about the pound, I want you to be aware that we have [indiscernible] position within the pound, because we have 2 major manufacturing plants of our Product Inspection. So that's at least on the positive side for us. And we'll see how it further develops. Typically, when these kind of things happen in a country, you have, in the short term, an impact and then things rebalance. The second question about the we have these different ways so many different products that I described before. So not all of them have the same payback time the investments that we do in Southeast Asia that will have faster paybacks and fortunately investments that I referred to in Automated Chemistry. But all in all, we'd say we want to have them to reach a breakeven after a year. And kind of after 2 years, they should cover their initial investments. And that's also the beauty when we do this in ways but on a regular base, all the ways kind of also helped fund the new ways.
